PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating should be condemned for his disgraceful public attack on our national flag in a foreign country. The petitioners note that his public remarks
discredited our proud history and unique culture
degraded the efforts of all servicemen and women
insulted and embarrassed proud Australians
damaged our international reputation as a united and patriotic democratic nation
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Mr Keating apologise to the Australian people for his demeaning behaviour in a foreign country.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia should retain the current National Flag which has flown over the country since Federation. This flag
symbolises the world's oldest democracy
represents our history, our culture and our language
enjoys the support of the vast majority of the Australian people
symbolises the sacrifice of our armed servicemen and women
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should retain the current national flag.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PETITION.PARA: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PARA.TAB: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PETITION.PARA: maintained national unity in a federation

PARA.TAB: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a democratic constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our Head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.

PETITION.TITLE: Adult Migrant Education Program
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the Speaker, and the Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned residents of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that the Adult Migrant Education Program (AMEP), including Workplace English Language and Literacy, must continue as a fully Government funded educational program with equality of access for all non-English speaking permanent residents. The implementation of fees for adult English as a Second Language (ESL) programs will disadvantage migrants who cannot afford to pay. The limit of 510 hours tuition will disadvantage most students who need a minimum of 900 hours of English for work or further study.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the Senate restore access to all migrants and refugees regardless of length of residence in Australia and employment status, and to provide continuing funding for all adult ESL Programs to public education institutions, in particular AMES.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: (1)Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2)The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3)These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to remove these services so that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: British Commonwealth Occupation Forces, Japan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully request:

That all former members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (B.C.O.F.) Japan, who have not established eligibility through other military service, be granted eligibility for the Service Pension, and all benefits thereto, including the issue of campaign medals.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to so grant this request by legislation enacted by Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pornographic Material
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we the undersigned, having great concern because of the spread of moral pollution in our nation call upon the Government to introduce immediate legislation:

(1)To provide strict controls over importation, production, sale, hire or mailing of video-cassettes with the open sale of only G, PG, and M rated video-cassettes; and the total prohibition of the sale of R rated video-cassettes so that R rated films can only be viewed in an adult theatre by persons over 18 years. We totally reject the concept of `X' rated video-cassettes which would allow the legal sale of hard-core pornographic films for screening in the homes of our nation, which endanger our children.

(2)To dramatically improve the Federal Attorney-General's Guidelines for Classification of Video tapes/discs which restrict the importation, production, sale or hire, screening in private homes and mailing by Australia Post so as to include the total prohibition of any pornographic, obscene or blasphemous video cassette, or film containing child pornography, bestiality, sodomy, group sex, violent sex acts with women, such as rape and pack rape, sadism and torture, etc.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your Honourable House will protect our society, especially women and children from moral pollution and its harmful effects. And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION BILL 1992ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 1 December.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there is an agreement that certain of the Australian Democrats' amendments be taken in block. If that is the wish of the Committee, we will proceed according to the running sheet, but put those amendments that are not in the block list in the order in which they come. For instance, the first block starts with amendment No. 3. Therefore, we will take amendment No. 1 first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we get to the appropriate clause, I will point to the other clauses that an amendment to that clause would affect. We would be taking them sequentially, but some of them are interrelated. I will undertake to draw attention to those other clauses that would be affected by the amendment when it first appears in the debate.

—The sheet I have in front of me says that many of the 82 amendments have been grouped together. However, some are to be put alone as they do not lend themselves to grouping. I note that amendment No. 14 should have been split in two as follows: 14, interim listing of native species, et cetera; and 14A, public may nominate native species, et cetera. Under impact assessment conservation orders are amendments Nos. 3, 5, 23, 34, 37, 38, 51 and 57. If it is possible to proceed in that way, it would probably be better than proceeding clause by clause, unless the Committee wishes otherwise.

—That is essentially what I am suggesting: that we go through them and, as we get to them in the order in the Bill, I will mention the other amendments that are consequential upon that amendment, so that we can deal with those as a block. It is the same process.
—We will start with amendment No. 1, then go to amendment No. 2; and when we get to amendment No. 3, we will consider amendments 3, 5, 23 and so on.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 3, page 2, paragraph (1)(a), lines 3 and 4, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(a)ensure the recovery of species and ecological communities that are endangered and vulnerable, in order to ensure the short and long term survival of viable populations; and".

SPEECH.PARA: I begin by pointing out several preliminary things. Senator Chamarette will not be here today. She has been kind enough to write me a letter which, in part, says that she supports all the Democrats' proposed amendments and sincerely regrets that she will not be present to vote for them. Senator Chamarette has gone to Queensland to speak at the symposium on Burma at Griffith University. While she is not here, I draw the Committee's attention to the fact that she is supporting these amendments.

PARA.TAB: I also draw the Committee's attention to the very wide support that all these amendments have attracted. The World Wide Fund for Nature, Greenpeace Australia, and the Nature Conservation Council of New South Wales have all written in recent days strongly supporting the amendments I will be moving.
Turning to this amendment to clause 3, under the objects of the Bill—it is important to stress that this is what the Bill seeks to achieve—it says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . promoting the recovery of species and ecological communities that are endangered or vulnerable.

One can promote something at various levels. One can promote something strongly or weakly; it is still promotion. The Bill should be seeking to ensure the recovery of species and ecological communities. The amendment seeks to make it quite clear that the object of the Bill, the intention of the Bill, is to take the strongest possible action to ensure—and I stress `ensure'—the recovery of species and ecological communities that are endangered and vulnerable.

PARA.TAB: We all recognise that that object may not be achieved. Nonetheless, it is better to set out with a piece of legislation with a much stronger intention than it is to accept simply the words `to promote', because that can indicate any sort of weak action that the Government might choose to take. I strongly urge this amendment on the Government and the Opposition. I think both of the old parties recognise the importance of this legislation and I call on them to support this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting this amendment, although we will be supporting a number of Democrat amendments, and we have given the Democrats notice of our intention to do so. We will not be supporting this amendment because it imposes upon the government of the day a totally unrealisable goal, that is, the need to ensure the preservation of a species. All that it is within the Government's physical power to promote is the preservation of a species. By the very promulgation of this legislation—which has been attacked by people who are anti-conservation—we do promote the preservation of a species. To create an onus of ensuring that a species is protected would put the Government in a position where we would have to do things such as stop cyclones and cure diseases.

—I cannot really accept what the Minister has said. Every piece of legislation that we deal with in this place has certain objectives and we all know that those objectives are frequently not met. But that is not an argument for not setting out to attempt to ensure—and I use that word again—that those objectives are met. To argue that under this legislation we would have to stop cyclones is ridiculous. The Act clearly sets out the mechanisms by which these objectives are to be encouraged or processed. The rest of the Act sets out those procedures. But we are talking about the objective of the Act and that surely should be to ensure the survival of species. It is not semantically correct to say that we cannot use the word `ensure' in the objectives simply because further down the track we might not achieve that objective. I just do not accept that.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 2.Clause 3, page 2, after paragraph (1)(b), insert the following paragraph:

TAB.TAB: "(ba) ensure the protection of habitats of endangered and vulnerable species and endangered and vulnerable ecological communities; and".

SPEECH.PARA: The second amendment of the Australian Democrats, which is also to clause 3 of the Endangered Species Protection Bill, seeks to insert another paragraph after paragraph (1)(b) to ensure the protection of habitats of endangered and vulnerable species and endangered and vulnerable ecological communities. The Bill recognises both species and ecological communities. This amendment will insert the notion that habitats also need to be protected. Again, it uses that word `ensure'. There are two aspects of this amendment: first, it seeks to strengthen the intention of the legislation by using the word `ensure'; and, second, it seeks to extend the notion of protection to habitats.

PARA.TAB: Most people in this chamber would be aware that a species cannot be protected in isolation and that the preservation of a species ultimately depends upon the protection of its habitat. I draw the attention of the Committee to an AAP report yesterday which is headed, `Mulga land degradation costing millions'. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: Land degradation in Queensland's south-western Mulga region is costing $52 million a year in failed production . . .

It talks about the enormous problems of soil erosion, which bears very much on the habitat of animals such as the bilby—a very endangered species that was in plentiful numbers roughly a century ago. We strongly argue that the notion of habitat protection is crucial, if one is to effectively protect either species or ecological communities to which the Bill in other parts refers.

PARA.TAB: This clause sets out the objects of the Bill. This is the introductory clause which sets out what the Bill is attempting to do. In our view, it is desirable to make those objectives as clear and as forceful as possible so that nobody reading those objectives is in any doubt as to what this legislation seeks to do. To leave out the notion of habitat is to ignore what any biologist, and I think anybody in this chamber, would recognise as an absolutely essential component in the proper protection of endangered species.

Again, I draw attention to the fact that Australia has an absolutely shocking record when it comes to loss of species of both animals and plants. We need to draw the scientific data on the processes of protection as wide as possible so that those things that are currently included, the species and ecological communities, are properly protected. Therefore, I strongly commend this amendment to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting this amendment. We believe that it casts the net far too wide at this point. Indeed, Senator Coulter, in his explanation of the reason why the Democrats are putting this amendment, gave the very reasons why the Government cannot support it.

—The coalition will not be supporting this amendment either, on the same grounds as the Minister has explained. We are concerned about the need to protect the habitats of endangered and vulnerable species. However, this amendment requires all habitats, no matter what the consequences, to have their protection ensured. That, in fact, pre-empts all consultative processes and all determinations. To that extent we cannot support it.

PARA.TAB: It may emerge that disturbing the habitat of what is defined as a vulnerable species would not be disastrous. This proposal removes any flexibility in examining matters of that kind and, to that extent, in our view, is extending the need to protect habitats to a position which is unsustainable.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot accept what the Opposition has said. It has claimed that this amendment would involve the protection of all habitats. The proposed new paragraph clearly says `the habitats of endangered and vulnerable species'. It certainly does not extend to all habitats. It is not, as I think Senator Baume seemed to be implying, that—
—All habitats are vulnerable. The amendment refers to `all habitats of vulnerable species', and I am saying that it extends the definition and pre-empts decisions.

—Again I point out that this is in the objects of the Act. This sets out the procedures which will be used. We have procedures in this Act whereby scientific committees will look at these things and give advice, and Ministers will take certain actions that certain things will flow from. But the objects of the Act should quite clearly identify those things which are essential to the protection of endangered species. After all, this is supposed to be a piece of legislation which seeks to protect endangered species.

PARA.TAB: We must accept—it is absolutely non-arguable—that we cannot protect endangered species and ecological communities unless we protect the habitats in which they occur. I think every biologist would concede that point. To argue that this would necessarily mean that all habitats had to be protected is stretching a very long bow when we look at the actual procedures set out in the Act which would be invoked if this were accepted as an objective. But as an objective it should be non-arguable that habitats of endangered and vulnerable species need to be protected.

Most of the loss of species in Australia has occurred because habitat has been lost; it has not been specifically because people have actually gone out and deliberately shot at those particular animals, although there are such examples in Australia. In most instances, it has been the loss of the habitat in which those animals and plants occur which has resulted in the loss of those species. So I find it very difficult to understand how either the Government or the Opposition can argue against the protection of habitat.

Just a moment ago, we did not accept the replacement of the word `promote' by `ensure'. I wonder whether the Government would find it more acceptable if the amendment were to include the word `promote' rather than `ensure'. Clearly, two principles are involved in the debate over this amendment. If that were the case, I would certainly find it acceptable, in view of what we have just decided, to accept the word `promote' but to at least include the notion of habitat protection. I ask the Minister whether he is prepared to accept that amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is no, because the Government is satisfied that the provisions of the Bill, as it is currently before the Committee, achieve the purposes that Senator Coulter wants to achieve. Considering the tortuous and difficult negotiation that went into getting this legislation in its present form, we do not believe that it is appropriate to make this kind of change.

PARA.TAB: The Government acknowledges that species cannot be protected in isolation from the habitat in which they live. Therefore, the very objects of the Act in promoting the recovery and protection of a species, by definition, involve the question of habitat where it is determined by scientific assessment at that time that the protection of the habitat is essential to the protection of the particular species. So it is already covered by the provisions of the Act and, in that sense, this amendment is unnecessary.

I would also like to note for the benefit of the Committee that the provisions of the Bill mention habitat in achieving the objectives of the Bill in a number of other areas—for example, recovery plants, conservation orders and conservation agreements all cover the question of habitat.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ensure—using the failed word of the previous amendment—that there is no scope for misunderstanding the coalition's position. We are not arguing against the protection of habitats. The suggestion by Senator Coulter that he could not understand why the Opposition was arguing against it is, in fact, a nonsense. We are not arguing against it. We are arguing against the clause that he himself now has recognised may well be improved by using the word `promotion'. At least in political terms it would be improved in the sense that it would have a greater prospect of getting through.

PARA.TAB: We are strongly in favour of the protection of habitats but we recognise that this is a process that involves scientific examination in cases for and against. We want to ensure that the Bill itself does not, in a sense, pre-empt determinations by requiring the proceedings under the Bill to ensure the protection of all vulnerable habitats, which is what it would do in the basic way that it had been moved. There may be some instances where that matter should be argued—where scientific evidence should allow a situation that did not ensure the protection of all vulnerable species. I recognise that there is a clear link between habitats and species. Obviously, the bulldozing of mangroves may seriously limit the prospects of survival of, say, rare fish species—that is self-evident. We are concerned to see that, all things being equal, that does not happen.

Senator Coulter has suggested that instead of the word `ensure' we should use the word `promote'. That would have been an interesting matter for us to have discussed had we had any time to do so. The Democrats came to us yesterday afternoon with 81 amendments, which they are amending further today, and they expect us to have a rational response when we have not been able to establish the consequences of them.

One of the worst things about legislation is the unintended consequences. Something is put down which sounds sensible, rational and reasonable and then one finds out that it has an appalling unintended consequence for a lot of people. The proper method of making law in Australia is to examine what on earth one is doing and what its consequences will be.

I must say that, intellectually, I am attracted to the idea of promoting the protection of habitats; it appeals to me. But because I have not had an opportunity to examine the amendments in detail or to get any sort of advice from the experts on the environment with whom I discuss these matters, and as I am the representative of the shadow Minister, who himself has not had the opportunity to examine these amendments, it is unfair and unreasonable of Senator Coulter to come in and require us to divide on this kind of issue so that he can say, `These people did not support us on this major question of protecting habitats'. If the Democrats are to require us to divide on this matter, I find it a very unattractive political stunt, because it is seeking to create a view of our position which is simply false.

I am very concerned that in going through this legislation, if the Democrats are going to divide on all of the amendments, we face the prospect of something like 20 divisions, with the Democrats getting their numbers up in terms of the number of times the Government and coalition have voted together against the Democrats. If that is what this is, then I would be correct to say that it is a political stunt, because it is obviously one basic piece of legislation. If the Democrats are doing this to get their numbers so they can say, `It is wrong for the coalition to claim the Democrats support the Labor Party most of time', and to use this as an example of where they do not, when in fact it relates to one bit of legislation, then I must say I find it not an attractive intellectual exercise and one in which one could look for a level of intellectual dishonesty.

I am attracted to the proposition about promoting. I cannot support it because I have not had the opportunity of referring it even to the shadow Minister, let alone to our party room. The proper way to conduct an examination of this kind of legislation is to have proper consultation and proper discussion within the parties in this place so that we end up with legislation that is agreed. The process that has been undertaken is one whereby, for example, lots of bodies external to this Parliament were aware of the Democrats' proposals, at least in draft form, last Friday when they wrote to us—and presumably before last Friday because they had to take a view on them. We were not. I express my disappointment that, on the face of it, this sort of activity seems to add up to a situation where, for political purposes, the Democrats are seeking to force the Opposition to vote continually with the Government on matters that it simply has not had the opportunity of properly examining. To that extent I strongly regret what is happening at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) commented that this amendment casts far too wide a net. I believe that any land area contains the habitats of some species. The question we ask ourselves is whether any of those species are endangered. I therefore believe that any land use would leave open a charge of at least some species being vulnerable, as the amendment refers to `endangered and vulnerable species'. So I ask whether the Minister or Senator Coulter can tell me how much of Australia this would not tie up, because I believe that this clause would tie up all of Australia for any resource development whatsoever—and sea areas as well, for that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to Senator Baume's argument about numbers, I think he should speak to Senator Kemp, because it was Senator Kemp who raised that issue first and attempted to make something of numbers. He did so quite dishonestly because, as he would know, the Government very often does not call divisions when we vote with the Opposition. So the dishonesty really lies with the Opposition with respect to that.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the suggestion that we take out the word `ensure' and put in the word `promote', I am not sure how I could have put that to Senator Baume several days ago when it is an amendment that has only just been lost in this chamber. The acceptance of the word `promote' instead of `ensure' only 10 minutes or so ago immediately suggested to my mind that the second leg of my amendment might be acceptable if we were to change that word.

Coming to the more substantive point which the Minister has made, he is quite correct when he says that the word `habitat' and the notion of habitat protection is mentioned elsewhere in the Bill. I draw his attention specifically to clause 58(2), on page 26 of the Bill, under `interim conservation orders'. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of paragraph (1)(d)—
that is, ensuring that particular activities do not adversely affect a listed native species or listed ecological community, or habitat significant to the survival of a listed native species—

. . . activities affecting the habitat of a listed native species or a listed ecological community are relevant only to the extent that they adversely affect features of the habitat that are significant to the survival of the species or community.

It is an incredibly limiting clause. So while the Minister is correct in saying that `habitat' occurs in several places throughout the Bill, nonetheless the notion that a species cannot stand alone without the protection of its habitat is severely limited in this legislation. Senator Baume quite correctly drew attention to the example of a crustacean that lives in mangrove swamps and the question of the clearing of the mangroves, the mangroves themselves not being a threatened species. There are mangroves in many parts of Australia.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that none of the arguments put by either the Government or the Opposition really bear on the importance of bringing this forward—I stress it again—into the objects of the Act. The object of the Act should be to protect the habitats of the species and of the ecological communities which are endangered or vulnerable. That should be essentially the third leg of the protection of endangered and vulnerable species. Without that habitat protection, we simply cannot achieve the other objectives.

As far as what Senator Panizza was saying is concerned, I think it is a point that Senator Baume touched on earlier—that including such a clause would somehow lock up the whole of Australia. That is absolutely ridiculous. The Bill quite clearly says that it is the protection of habitats in relation to endangered and vulnerable species. So it is not all habitats; it is habitats in relation to endangered and vulnerable species. It is quite clearly qualified. I say to Senator Panizza through you, Mr Chairman, that a species which was vital in a particular habitat but which itself was not vulnerable or threatened nonetheless might be a key species in a particular habitat in which there was a threatened or vulnerable species. In that particular habitat, that species itself would need to be protected.

I think Senator Panizza really has not caught on to the interlinking relationship between threatened species in ecological communities and habitats. Again, I strongly put this notion of habitat protection. In view of the earlier non-acceptance of my first amendment, I am quite prepared to accept the word `promote', but I think it is important to get in this idea of habitat protection at the very beginning of the legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some great reservations about the proposition which Senator Coulter is putting today to the chamber, one of which relates to an animal called the tree-climbing kangaroo. Senator Coulter may be aware of the tree-climbing kangaroo. There was a time when certain people in the environmental movement said that the tree-climbing kangaroo could live only in eucalypt forests. They opposed the creation in North Queensland of pine plantations on the basis that the tree-climbing kangaroo could not find a home in the pine plantations, only in eucalypt forests. The fact that there were no eucalypt forests there, of course, because they had long disappeared through farming practices, was rather irrelevant. They said, `No, we can't have these pine plantations'.

PARA.TAB: It subsequently transpired that tree-climbing kangaroos live just as happily in pine plantations as in eucalypt forests—in fact, they eat the leaves from the pine trees. The problem is that some people perhaps will say, `Oh, you can't do this and this because we believe at this point in time you will have an adverse effect on them'. It subsequently transpired that the tree-climbing kangaroo lives quite happily in pine plantations.

Those same people now seek to use this provision to stop those who planted the pine plantations from actually harvesting the pine plantations on the basis that amongst the pine plantations live tree-climbing kangaroos which those same people some years ago said could never live there. The real effect of this amendment would be that the pine plantations would never be harvested, at a great cost to the State, because tree-climbing kangaroos are living in them.

That exposes one of the real weaknesses of this proposal. The weakness is that the amendment would basically restrict the ability to deal with certain habitats which may happen to contain vulnerable species. We should make it very clear for all those who are listening that this provision does not seek to protect all of the habitats of all vulnerable species, but it would restrict the ability to deal with an area in which the habitat of a vulnerable species occurs.

The perfect example of this is the pebble mound mouse, to which I referred in the second reading debate on this Bill. The pebble mound mouse was raised as an objection to mining at Marandoo. The value of the Marandoo iron ore mine is in the vicinity of $36 billion. The objection was raised to mining at Marandoo because the pebble mound mouse is found there. The pebble mound mouse was vulnerable in that one habitat, but it can be found in other places in Western Australia. I think the Labor Government in Western Australia made the right decision to go ahead with the mine. I think that is something on which Senator Collins and I may actually agree. It made the right decision. This amendment moved by Senator Coulter would prevent that sort of thing from taking place, and that would be unacceptable.

I thought the provision was dangerous enough when I first heard it discussed. When Senator Coulter got up a moment ago and actually elaborated on it, he gave me more jitters. It is obvious that the provision he envisages is much more restrictive even than the provision which I thought he envisaged when he proposed this amendment.

Acceptance of this amendment, even with the word `promote', at this point would be very dangerous and would really open up enormous scope for extremists in the environmental movement to impose their way simply on the basis that they found in a particular habitat a species which was vulnerable in that habitat. I do not think that is acceptable and a reasonable person would not think it is acceptable. I agree with Senator Baume that we in the coalition should not be supporting this amendment, particularly in the light of the way in which it was brought into this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee is wrong on both counts. Firstly, if he had read the legislation, he would see that the processes which this legislation envisages are quite properly protected by scientific committees, advice and everything else. We are really talking about the objects of the Act here, and the notion that somebody could propose the wholesale protection of an area where in fact there was no threatening process occurring or no threatened or vulnerable species or ecological communities is, of course, a nonsense.

PARA.TAB: The object of this would be to protect those habitats where there was a threatened or vulnerable species, recognising that the species cannot exist without its habitat. Senator O'Chee gave the example of the pebble mound mouse. If he looks at the schedules to this legislation, he will see that the pebble mound mouse is a listed species. It has already been recognised as a threatened and vulnerable species.

The argument in relation to Marandoo really comes down to quite a different argument. Senator O'Chee is not being honest with this Committee when he uses that example. There are vast resources of iron ore in the Pilbara region which, throughout the last several decades of his life, Mr Lang Hancock tried to open up for development and which, in fact, do not involve any threat to the pebble mound mouse whatsoever.

The argument is really quite a different argument. There is no reason why iron ore development should not go ahead, but it needs to be recognised that there is a particular area where the pebble mound mouse occurs which would be interfered with if that particular proposal were to proceed. It might simply be much better to exploit iron ore somewhere else so that the pebble mound mouse is not extensively interfered with.

The species is listed. It is in this piece of legislation, if Senator O'Chee cares to look at it. Consequently, under this legislation, it would be one of the factors to be taken into account with respect to this sort of development. That would be a consideration whether or not this amendment is in place. The example does not bear any weight.

With respect to the broader point he is making, that somehow this locks up areas more extensively simply because habitats are protected, they are habitats in which there are species or ecological communities which are threatened or vulnerable. The whole process is protected by the scientific review process and this will ensure that these vast areas are not locked up. Again, I argue most strongly for the inclusion of this notion of habitat protection in this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Either Senator Coulter is trying to skirt the issue or he did not understand what I was saying. One of the dangers of habitat protection is that this amendment could be used to lock up areas of habitat which are not natural—for example, plantations of timber. I would seek to hear from Senator Coulter whether he believes that this amendment could be used, for example, to lock up hardwood or softwood plantations which happen to be the habitat of a vulnerable species.

—If a vulnerable or threatened species or ecological community was driven to the point where its survival depended upon the protection of some piece of habitat which was not at that stage a natural habitat but which included introduced species, including pine plantations, of course that habitat would need to be protected. Also, the recovery plans envisaged in the rest of the legislation would clearly include the re-establishment of a far more natural habitat so that that condition would not obtain indefinitely into the future.

PARA.TAB: Is Senator O'Chee saying that if the last refuge of the tree-climbing kangaroo was in one pine plantation in Queensland, we should simply go ahead and tear down that pine plantation and ignore the plight of the tree-climbing kangaroo? It seems to me that that is what he is saying. Clearly, if the animal existed much more widely than that, it simply would not be on the list of threatened or vulnerable species or a threatened or vulnerable ecological community. He cannot drive his argument both ways. If it is threatened and vulnerable and that is the last habitat, that habitat should be protected, and one should make no bones about it whatsoever.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is that what Senator Coulter is saying is completely different from his amendment. Senator Coulter says, `If it is the last habitat', but the problem is that this amendment talks about the protection of habitats of endangered and vulnerable species. It says, `the protection of habitats', not `the protection of the last remaining habitat'. Obviously, there is a difference between the last habitat and one of a number of habitats. This is where Senator Coulter's amendment really falls apart.
—Ha, ha!

—I notice that one of Senator Coulter's colleagues is giggling like a schoolchild. The construction of this amendment talks about the protection of habitats. It is quite open to interpret this amendment as meaning the protection of one of a number of habitats of an endangered or vulnerable species. There is a great deal of difference between what Senator Coulter says and what his amendment actually would seek to do or would allow to be done. That is the first concern.

PARA.TAB: The second problem is that the amendment also talks about vulnerable ecological communities. Vulnerable ecological communities in themselves may not constitute a vulnerable species; they may be a community. Senator Coulter has said in this chamber that a community of animals, for example, may be vulnerable in that one area but as a species not endangered or vulnerable. Again, the net is sought to be cast far too widely. The dangers are that, in the case of a plantation, enormous sums of money may be invested in creating these plantations and these resources, and then the resources cannot be harvested because some time after the time at which the resources were put in and they are ready for harvesting a particular animal has moved into the area.

When one looks at the protection of vulnerable ecological communities, under this particular provision one could argue that a particular species—not an endangered species—which moves into a pine plantation is vulnerable because it is found in only one area, the artificial environment into which it migrated. This clause could be used to lock up those resources. That really means that there is no certainty for the future of the timber industry in this country because this would be yet another opportunity for the extremists in the environmental movement—people who do not reflect the mainstream concerns of those of us in the coalition—to seek to impose their views over the reasonable people in the Australian community who want to protect endangered species but who also want to protect them in a reasonable fashion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make two points. Firstly, we are talking about species and ecological communities that are endangered or vulnerable. A species that exists quite widely and in other habitats would not fall within that definition, so the fears expressed by Senator O'Chee are really unfounded. Secondly, Senator O'Chee fails to recognise that the legislation is built around proper scientific assessment processes. Unless he is arguing that the scientific committees and so on that will be advising the Minister will be composed of extremist environmentalists, there is more than adequate protection in the Bill.

PARA.TAB: More fundamentally, Senator O'Chee seems to be arguing that, provided we have one breeding pair of, say, the larger bilby in Australia, we are quite okay; that because we have one breeding pair of that species in a zoo somewhere, it is no longer endangered and vulnerable. Senator O'Chee does not seem to recognise that, once the number of interacting animals in a community drops below a certain level—and that number can be quite large and can range over quite a large area for some species—that species becomes very vulnerable. Some species require relatively large areas; some require smaller areas. Some require very large populations to maintain that level.

I point out to Senator O'Chee the plight of the gouldian finch. Two or three decades ago there were literally tens of millions of gouldian finches across the whole of northern Australia. Yet now, for reasons that are not at all clear, the numbers have dropped, and so the issue of whether the Mount Todd goldmine, which was mentioned in the second reading debate two days ago, would impact on the gouldian finch becomes a significant question. I use this opportunity to make the point that Zapopan has satisfied me that that goldmine will not make a significant impact on that threatened species. Nonetheless, it becomes an issue for proper consideration because that finch—a very important and very beautiful animal—has dropped in numbers absolutely catastrophically in the course of several decades.

In that case we need quite large numbers to be protected so that we have a community that will sustain itself indefinitely into the future and be able—and this is an important clause that occurs elsewhere in the legislation—to continue to evolve as a species in response to the inevitable changes that will occur in the environment in any case. Some of these changes will be human induced, some will occur quite naturally. Climates and weather patterns change irrespective of human intervention.

We need relatively large populations which can continue to evolve so that 10,000 years in the future they may be different in some significant way from the species we have today. We are not looking in this legislation, nor should we be, simply to protect museum-type specimens locked into 1992 and unable to evolve in response to changes to the environment which will inevitably occur. Therefore—and I come back to this point—the natural habitats in which animals and plants occur are an important element in their protection. They need to interact with their habitats. That evolutionary process will continue without the intervention of human beings.

We will not have to take away animals and store them in zoos and so on. I point out to Senator O'Chee that trying to retain these species under such highly artificial circumstances is very expensive. We will not be doing that. They will continue to evolve in their natural environments. They will still be there for future generations to enjoy. After all, one of the fundamental foundations on which the whole notion of ecologically sustainable development is based is the idea that future generations will have available for their enjoyment, pleasure and genetic information for scientific purposes at least the same range of species which we have available to us today.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite obvious that Senator Coulter is not going to be terribly reasonable about this. I do not wish to delay the Committee much longer on this amendment. However, I would just like to draw the attention of the Committee to one thing, and that is the way in which Senator Coulter likes to put up a straw man when he debates these points. I have been talking about particular communities and particular species, and the impact of some of these things on the timber industry. Senator Coulter, out of nowhere, suggested that I would believe it would be satisfactory to have one breeding couple of any species in a zoo. The incredible intellectual dishonesty of trying to raise a straw man case to argue against a viewpoint, even if one does not hold that viewpoint, is wholly unsatisfactory. Senator Coulter ought to do himself a better service politically and realise that one just cannot do that sort of thing.

PARA.TAB: One is trying to raise a reasonable argument from this side and elicit from Senator Coulter some indication of his response to it. But Senator Coulter then comes out with some over the top suggestion that I am saying, `Provided we have one breeding pair in a zoo'. I really do not know from where he got that in my speech. But to come out with something like that really—

TALK.START.PARA: —By implication.
—Senator Coulter interjects, `By implication'.
—It lies behind everything that you have been saying.

—Senator Coulter has used the word `lies'. Mr Chairman, I would seek to have that word withdrawn by Senator Coulter because it really is unparliamentary and unsatisfactory for such a word to be used in this place.

—Mr Chairman, I said, `By implication it lies behind everything that Senator O'Chee has said'. I did not say he was telling lies. It lies behind; it is the basis on which he is working. I think Senator O'Chee should wash his ears out. He misunderstood a word that I used the other day. He thought I had said `Nazi moron' when I had used the word `oxymoron'. Perhaps he has difficulty with his hearing.
—There is no problem with the word that was used.

—Mr Chairman, again Senator Coulter does not seek to be honest with the chamber. He says one thing from this part of the chamber and relies on the fact that you cannot hear it. He uses the oxymoron example again. We all know that an oxymoron is an intelligent Democrat.The problem that we have with Senator Coulter is that he is being unreasonable. He is really not seeking to debate the argument. He is trying to peddle some sort of nonsense.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter has tried to suggest that there was an implication in my argument which would allow him to extend all of these irrational nonsensical pieces of tripe about my suggesting that it would be satisfactory to have one breeding pair of any species in a zoo. This is not an implication but an inference that the honourable senator, in his fanaticism, has drawn from a speech that had absolutely nothing to do with it. If we ever needed a reason as to why this amendment ought not be accepted, it is the fact that Senator Coulter can draw such an inference from what is a perfectly reasonable comment—a comment which seeks his elucidation—and goes running off at a tangent. It is that irrationality which is a real risk when we come to this sort of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not disagree with anything that Senator Coulter said about the importance of habitat. As I have said before, and as Senator Coulter has acknowledged—and I want to refer to the clause in the Bill he quoted from—habitat is specifically mentioned in the legislation. In every one of those cases, a rigorous scientific assessment will have to be made. If an assessment determines that a particular habitat is essential to the survival of the species that is being considered for protection, the recovery orders that will be issued will contain that prescription in respect of the habitat.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to detain the Committee any longer than necessary by talking about individual examples, but it is a scientific fact, as Senator Coulter would have to acknowledge, that a species cannot exist without the features of its habitat that are essential for its survival. But, in every case, not each and every feature of that habitat is necessary. In some cases—and I am happy to talk about it in detail, if Senator Coulter wants to—the features of the habitat are not even relevant to that species. There are some parts of the habitat that the animal does not use for protection, food or anything else that affects its survival or daily life in any way at all. Subclause 58(2) on page 26, which Senator Coulter quoted from, is a sensible and reasonable acknowledgment of that. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . activities affecting the habitat of a listed native species or a listed ecological community are relevant only to the extent that they adversely affect features of the habitat that are significant to the survival of the species or community.

It incorporates the concept of community. So it can go beyond the single species to an ecological community but, scientifically, it does not need necessarily to include each and every feature of the particular habitat that the species lives in.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Coulter knows, that is a matter that the Government has, of necessity, put in the hands of the scientific community. The legislation provides for a rigorous scientific assessment of the species that are being considered. As Senator Coulter has acknowledged, it provides of necessity that that assessment, the orders that are made and the recovery plans that are then drawn up involve consideration of the habitat in which the species lives. But it is not scientifically correct to say that each and every aspect of a habitat has to be either necessary for the survival of the species or, in some cases, relevant to the life of a particular species in a habitat. That is simply a sensible acknowledgment of the situation.

I conclude by reiterating that the Government is not only well aware of the points that Senator Coulter correctly makes about the importance of habitat but also asserts that the legislation, which has been carefully negotiated and, as I think Senator Coulter would also acknowledge, controversially negotiated—because it is a controversial piece of legislation—quite properly takes habitat into consideration. We are perfectly prepared to accept the decisions of the scientific assessment that is made as to what parts of the habitat would be required to ensure the continued survival of the species or the ecological community that is being considered.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has just given the best explanation as to why this amendment should be accepted. It does lie through the legislation; `habitat' is mentioned in a number of places. I point out again that we are dealing with the objects of the Bill, and habitat protection is therefore appropriately brought right forward to the beginning of the Bill. We are talking about recovery, the protection of species and ecological communities that are endangered or vulnerable and the habitats in which they occur. It is therefore absolutely appropriate, as the Minister has just identified very clearly, to bring that right forward into the objects of the Bill.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 3.Clause 3, page 2, subparagraph (2)(b)(iii), lines 24 and 25, omit "and impact assessment conservation orders".
5.Clause 4, page 4, subclause (1), definition of "impact assessment conservation order", lines 30 and 31, omit the definition.
23.Clause 55, page 24, subclause (4), lines 37 to 40, omit the subclause.
34.Part 5, Division 3, pages 34 to 37, line 28 (page 34) to line 19 (page 37), omit the Division.
37.Clause 84, page 37, subclause (4), line 35, omit "impact assessment".
38.Clause 85, page 38, paragraph (c), line 6, omit the paragraph.
51.Clause 99, page 44, lines 22 and 23, omit all words after "contravenes", substitute "a conservation order".
57.Clause 103, page 45, paragraph (1)(c), lines 16 and 17, omit "or impact assessment conservation order".
Amendment No. 3 refers only briefly to the impact assessment conservation orders of part 5, which starts on page 24 and is the relevant part.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats will be seeking to remove this whole section which refers to impact assessment conservation orders. As the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) alluded to earlier, in the genesis of this legislation there was a great deal of controversy regarding the way in which other Ministers and other departments might become involved. The part to which clause 3 refers invokes the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act and, under the clauses dealing with that Act, the action Minister with respect to threatened species becomes not the Minister for conservation and environment but the Minister responsible for the proposal for development. We find that quite unacceptable.

In considering the social and economic implications of any action which arises from this legislation for the protection of threatened or vulnerable species or ecological communities, it is appropriate that other matters be taken into consideration and that processes be put in place for that to occur. Those processes are in place in the legislation. But to remove entirely from the purview of the Minister for environment the clauses dealing with the impact of assessment conservation orders and thereby removing the ability of that Minister to make the judgment seems to the Democrats to be going far too far.

This is a mark of the position to which the Government has come. It has moved substantially away from its concern for the environment and towards greater emphasis on what it sees—we think mistakenly—as the need to protect economic activity. As far as the Opposition is concerned, it fits very much with its, in our view, great over-emphasis on economic activity such as mining, forestry and various other activities.

We would like to see this legislation strengthened very considerably by bringing it back, with respect to these particular and recognisably very important objectives, to the protection of the unique flora and fauna that this country contains—flora and fauna which, in the main, as I said in my speech in relation to my own legislation, are not found elsewhere in the world, which have evolved in Australia over 40 million years, a long period, and over which the present generation of Australians are the custodians, not only for all future generations of Australians but for all future humankind from now until humankind ceases to exist on this planet, perhaps 500 million years hence.

We are the 1992 custodians of that unique flora and fauna. We have an enormous responsibility to protect it. Accordingly, the Democrats think that much greater emphasis must be given to the Minister in this respect. This legislation does come under the Minister for the environment, with the exception of these impact assessment conservation orders where that very important power is removed from the Minister and placed somewhere else where the emphasis may well be, and is very likely to be, something quite different from the protection of threatened or vulnerable species or ecological communities.

Accordingly, we would press this series of amendments. They are all interrelated. Amendment No. 57 would delete the whole section dealing with impact assessment conservation orders. We pick it up in amendment No. 3 only because this is the first reference which is made to that particular section. Amendments Nos 3, 5, 23, 34, 37, 38, 51 and 57 are interrelated. I most strongly stress that, if this legislation is to have any teeth at all, if it is to be firmly grounded, not in the protection of economic activity, but in the protection of endangered and vulnerable species, and endangered and vulnerable economic communities, then it must lie with the environment Department and the environment Minister to make those sorts of assessments, given the scientific advice that in this case she would have. It should not be farmed off to one of the pro-development Ministers, one of the pro-development departments, to make an assessment and judgment which they are really not competent to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be accepting amendment No. 3 and the consequential amendments that flow from it, which have the effect of abolishing the system of impact assessment conservation orders. So far as the Government is concerned, this system is essential to achieving regulation of development to the extent the Government considers is appropriate—that is, in tandem with the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 4.Clause 4, page 4, subclause (1), definition of "ecological community", after paragraph (a), insert the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(aa) interacts as either an identifiable functional unit or an identifiable spatial unit, or both; and".

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 4 to clause 4, page 4, deals with the definition of `ecological community'. We feel that the definition of `ecological community' which is included in the Bill requires some amplification and clarification and that the words we are choosing to insert in the legislation are very important. In clause 4 of the Bill, in the definition of `ecological community', after paragraph (a), which says `inhabits a particular area in nature', we propose to add:

PARA.TAB: "(aa) interacts as either an identifiable functional unit or an identifiable spatial unit, or both. . .

SPEECH.PARA: The definition in clause 4 then goes on to paragraph (b):

PARA.TAB: (b) meets the additional criteria specified in the regulations made for the purposes of this definition;

SPEECH.PARA: When I discussed this yesterday with Senator Baume he drew attention to the word `interacts' and expressed concern that `interacts' might refer to the community interacting with something outside itself. The words in the definition in clause 4 of `ecological community' are that it means `an integrated assemblage of native species'. `Interacts' is clarified in our amendment as either an identifiable functional unit or an identifiable spatial unit or both. Paragraph (a) still stands, `inhabits a particular area in nature', as does paragraph (b), `meets the additional criteria specified in the regulations made for the purposes of this definition'.

PARA.TAB: This is not a major change in the legislation. It is simply an attempt to make it clearer. The idea of an ecological community is certainly well ensconced in biological circles. But the words `ecological' and `ecology' have come to take on a somewhat different meaning out in the community, particularly perhaps in some of those more extreme groups to which some Opposition senators have referred. So it is important to tie the definition back to something closer than the sense in which biologists use the words `ecology' or `ecological'. Therefore, we feel that it is desirable to insert this improvement into the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing this amendment, firstly, on the grounds—which I think are self-evident from reading the existing definition—that it is totally unnecessary and, secondly, because in our view it is potentially ambiguous: `interacts as either an identifiable functional unit or an identifiable spatial unit, or both'. The current definition in the Bill of `ecological community' is very broad. It goes on to say in paragraph (b) that there will be `additional criteria specified in the regulations made for the purposes of this definition'. The current definition is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: "ecological community" means an integrating assemblage of native species that:

PARA.TAB: (a) inhabits a particular area in nature; and
(b) meets the additional criteria specified in the regulations made for the purposes of this definition;

SPEECH.PARA: So the Government will not be accepting the amendment because we believe that it is unnecessary and also because, if it is found at a later stage that a clearer definition or clarification can be provided, then we will do that, as specified in the Bill, by regulation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite prepared to accept what the Minister has said in relation to regulations. I hope that the definition is made clearer in the regulations because the definition in the Bill by itself is not sufficient. I think the Minister would recognise that. Much of the discussion that went into those earlier amendments was underlaid by recognition that that definition was inadequate in that both the Minister and members of the Opposition were talking about members of a particular area that were not essential to that particular species.

PARA.TAB: I would enjoin the Minister to ensure that the notion of interacting as a functional unit in that sense is got into the regulations, if that is the way the Government is going to proceed, because one can have within a particular area more than one ecology. There might be species in a particular area that does not in any significant sense interact in the sense of an ecology. So the notion of interaction and dependence, one upon the other, is an important notion to get into the idea of an ecological community. If the Minister is giving an undertaking that that notion of interaction and interdependence is to be built into the regulations, then I will be quite happy to accept that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to give such an undertaking. I am happy to leave that to the scientists. I can give Senator Coulter an undertaking—in fact, it has already been done—that his concerns about the clarification that was intended by his definition will certainly be taken into consideration when the regulations are being drawn up.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—The Committee will now proceed with amendments nos 6, 7, 10, 12, 13 and 18 regarding vulnerable ecological communities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 6.Clause 7, page 8, clause heading, line 22, after "species", add "and ecological communities".
7.Clause 7, page 8, after subclause (2), add the following subclause:
10.Clause 16, page 10, lines 9 to 11, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "16.(1) Part 1 of Schedule 2 contains a list of ecological communities that are endangered.

TAB.TAB: Part 2 of Schedule 2 contains a list of ecological communities that are vulnerable.

SPEECH.PARA: 12.Clause 21, page 11, clause heading, line 12, after "species", add "etc.".
13.Clause 21, page 11, lines 12 to 17, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Native species etc. that are vulnerable

PARA.TAB: "21.(1)The Minister must not delete:

SPEECH.PARA: (a)a native species from Part 2 of Schedule 1; or

TAB.TAB: (b)an ecological community from Part 2 of Schedule 2;

SPEECH.PARA: unless the Minister is satisfied that the species or community is no longer vulnerable.
