(a)a native species to Part 2 of Schedule 1; or
(b)an ecological community to Part 2 of Schedule 2;

SPEECH.PARA: unless the Minister is satisfied that the species or community is vulnerable.
18.Clause 35, page 17, Table, item 2, after "species", insert "or ecological community".

Clause 7 is headed, `Vulnerable species'. We wish to add the words `and ecological communities'. `Ecological community' is picked up in the definitions, and that is one of the things we have just been discussing. I suppose a lot of this argument relates to the argument we were having over habitat; that is, if species are to be protected, the ecological community of which those species form a part also needs to be looked at and protected. We cannot protect the species in isolation. It is important that the provisions which fall within each of these clauses be extended from vulnerable species to include ecological communities.

PARA.TAB: I also draw attention, as I indicated earlier, to the last line of clause 7(1) in the Bill where reference is made to `threatening its abundance, survival or evolutionary development'. I think that is a very important concept. I must praise the Government for ensuring that this concept is in the legislation. It bears very much on the idea of an ecological community.

If we seek to protect species in isolation, we will simply have species that are genetically locked out of that continuing evolutionary process. Therefore, we need to protect the environment and, specifically, the ecological community of which they form a part—that is, the other species with which they are interacting. It is that process which will most significantly affect their further evolutionary development and continue to allow those species to be properly adapted to the environments as those environments inevitably change. It is for those reasons that the notion of ecological communities needs to be written into that particular clause. Amendments 7, 10, 12, 13 and 18 are all related to that same point.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting these amendments. Again, of necessity with a Bill covering this sort of subject, it is very much a question of drawing the lines. There is no question that this will be a difficult matter to administer. The Government is not deterred from pressing ahead with this legislation. It is here in the chamber for that reason.

PARA.TAB: The effect of these amendments, as Senator Coulter has said, is to extend the coverage of the Bill to vulnerable ecological communities as well as endangered ones. It is a fact that the classification of ecological communities is far more controversial than the classification of species in the scientific community. For example, there would be broad agreement amongst scientists on the listing of endangered communities, but there would not be the same sort of consensus at all amongst scientists in respect of vulnerable communities.

It is a question of degree. As I said, it is more difficult to find consensus on the listing of communities than species, on which there is broad consensus. There would be consensus on endangered communities, but nowhere would there be the same degree of consensus in the scientific community on extending that definition to vulnerable communities. For that reason, the Government will not be supporting the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —One would have to agree to some extent with what the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Coulter) has just said about there being a certain degree of arbitrariness to where one actually puts species. From time to time, one even has a species that one thinks is extinct and suddenly it is rediscovered. There is a possum in North Queensland, just south of Cairns, which was thought to have been extinct but was discovered after quite some decades.

PARA.TAB: Nonetheless, I do not think the Minister's argument has substance. One of the principles which underlies the notion of ecologically sustainable development is the idea of erring on the side of caution—the so-called precautionary principle. If in doubt, one seeks to at least move so that one retains the option of taking stronger action if that becomes necessary. If in doubt, one does not continue to impact on that environment, on that vulnerable species, so that it moves inevitably from being vulnerable to being endangered.

In light of the precautionary principle, I think the Minister should really reconsider what he just said and recognise that if a species has got to the point of being regarded as vulnerable—recognising that that in itself is an arbitrary definition, but recognising that there is a sufficient body of scientists who consider that species or that ecological community is vulnerable—the precautionary principle should operate in line with ESD principles. I believe one should take that line rather than the alternative line of saying, `Because it is arbitrary we do not need to go so far', and possibly tip a species from being vulnerable to being endangered and possibly to becoming extinct. I stress to the Minister the precautionary principle to which this Government has assented under the ESD process.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is very conscious of the points Senator Coulter is making. We do not disagree with them. However, it is important to make the point that one of the fundamental strengths in maintaining the support of the Australian electorate, the people of Australia, for this sort of proposal will be—I am sure Senator Coulter will acknowledge this—consensus in the scientific community.

PARA.TAB: I make that point without any disrespect at all for the work done by the many dedicated environmental groups around the world for what has been a new acknowledgment—there is no question about it—and a growing acknowledgment of the importance of environmental protection by the community. It has always been my view, and I have expressed it before, that the shift in opinion in the electorate at large was not due to any work done by the environment groups, Greenpeace or any of those organisations. It was that substantial body of world scientific opinion that coalesced on matters such as protection of the ozone layer, greenhouse gases and global warming—and, in particular, the outstanding work done in Australia by the divisions of the CSIRO in this area—which led substantially to that shift in public support for environmental protection.

For that reason, I sound a cautionary note to Senator Coulter that I believe that the fundamental strength of this legislation will depend on broad consensus on what is required in this legislation by the scientific community. As Senator Coulter has acknowledged, it is much more difficult to get that consensus in respect of defining vulnerable ecological communities than it is to either define species—be they vulnerable or endangered—or endangered communities.

Particularly in the early years of the operation of this legislation it will be that scientific consensus which gives the action taken under this legislation the support that it needs in the community. I accept Senator Coulter's desire to take a precautionary step one step further, but I do think that there is some danger in taking that step and keeping broad public support for this sort of action, and the Government is not minded to do so at this stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the issue of broad community support, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, paid a quarter of a million dollars not so long back for a survey of public opinion on just this question of endangered species. Some 68 per cent of Australians said that this was a very important issue. The Australian public is well ahead of the Government in its thinking on this. I agree that it is necessary to have broad community support. I believe that broad community support is there.

PARA.TAB: While I would have to agree with the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) also in relation to the lack of consensus concerning vulnerable ecological communities in the scientific community, I do not think there is a great deal of lack of consensus in the scientific world in relation to the precautionary principle and the putting of things on the list, if in doubt, until one is quite sure that it is safe to de-list and to move to exploitation of a particular ecological community or vulnerable species. That precautionary principle is widely accepted.

I am personally quite disappointed that the Government has not proceeded a lot further with its ESD process. I see the Minister is nodding. We have set up the committees, expended a great deal of money and made a whole lot of recommendations and so on. These recommendations depend on this idea of inter-generational equity and the precautionary principle and are built right on the substantial base, but they have not been proceeded with further.

I simply make the point that I believe that the Government need have no fear of community support for this. One must not confuse the quite right scientific arbitrariness in which particular communities might be placed, the variability among scientists on that and the solid consensus among scientists of the need to invoke the precautionary principle and to proceed on that basis with protection until there is better evidence to proceed in another way.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder whether Senator Coulter would have any objection to taking amendment No. 8 together with the proposed Democrat package of amendments Nos 9, 11, 77 and 80. I am advised by the officers—this may be simply an error—that amendment No. 8 and amendment No. 78 should also go into that package because they all relate to the same matter. However, I am happy to deal with them separately if Senator Coulter wishes.
—That's all right.
—We will deal with amendments Nos 8, 9, 11, 77, 78 and 80 together. We did our own consolidation of Senator Coulter's amendments based on subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been checking those amendments again. They do not really relate to the same issue. There are somewhat significant differences between those amendments, so at this stage I would prefer to proceed with amendment No. 8.
—Fair enough.
—I move:

PARA.TAB: 8.After clause 13, page 9, add the following clauses:
"13A.(1) Except so far as the contrary intention appears, this Act applies to acts, omissions, matters and things outside Australia, whether or not in a foreign country.

TAB.TAB: Subject to subsection (3):

(a)to the extent that a provision of this Act has effect in and in relation to any waters or place beyond the outer limits of the Australian fishing zone, that provision applies only in relation to Australian citizens, Australian aircraft and Australian vessels and the members of the crew (including persons in charge) of Australian aircraft and Australian vessels; and

(b)to the extent that a provision of this Act has effect in and in relation to Australia or any waters other than waters referred to in paragraph (a), that provision applies in relation to all persons, aircraft and vessels, including foreign persons, foreign aircraft and foreign vessels.
This Act has effect subject to the obligations of Australia under international law, including obligations under any agreement between Australia and another country or countries.

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment refers to the operation and application of acts which occur outside Australia. The Government has indicated that it wants to make Australians who engage in, say, paedophilia in foreign countries, subject to the Australian law when they return. In other words, Australian nationals committing acts in a foreign country which are illegal in Australia could get caught. We are attempting to ensure that if an Australian goes to a place outside Australian jurisdiction and commits an act which is illegal according to this legislation, that act would still remain illegal within Australia when that person returns. We feel that that is consistent with what Senator Tate said the other day in relation to sex crimes in other countries.

PARA.TAB: It is particularly important here. One could imagine a situation in which a species was listed as endangered or vulnerable on one of the international lists and we recognised that that was the case, but if the particular foreign country to which an Australian citizen went did not recognise that list, and that Australian person then committed an act against one of those threatened species, that act would become illegal under this proposed amendment. For instance, if China were not protecting the giant panda but the giant panda was accepted everywhere else as a threatened species, and an Australian went to China and proceeded to shoot giant pandas, under this particular clause that person, on returning to Australia, would be liable to retribution under the law.

We feel that this amendment is consistent with current Government thinking. We think it is appropriate and we think it is a section which is not likely to be invoked very often. One hopes that Australians do not do these things when they go overseas, but no doubt some would. It is appropriate that those people simply should not engage in those sorts of activities.

The other sections to which the Minister referred pick up other external aspects of the legislation. This amendment relates specifically to Australian citizens, Australian aircraft, Australian vessels and members of the crew including persons in charge of Australian aircraft vessels, doing things in other countries which, under this legislation, would be illegal if they were committed in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting this amendment or, indeed, the consequent amendments that flow from it—amendments Nos 9, 11, 77, 78 and 80. Again, it takes the ambit of the Bill impracticably wide when, in fact, the Act is not yet in force and we have not started to establish the regime that we want to establish under it.

PARA.TAB: The reason I make that point is that the fundamental objective of this Bill is for Australia to first get its own house in order. We obviously want to see all countries around the world adopt similar legislation. However, to propose at this stage that we should be amending our legislation to make it an offence in Australia for an Australian citizen to do something overseas which would be an action negative to the well-being of an overseas endangered species is simply, at this point in the development of this kind of protection, taking it to the stage where it would be impossible to police; and it would divert resources unnecessarily away from the primary object of the current proposal, which is for this country to first get its own house in order.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will be supporting the Government in this matter. We recognise that there are problems, as Senator Coulter has quite rightly pointed out, in allowing Australian citizens to do overseas what is illegal in Australia. Our objection to Senator Coulter's proposed amendment is that a problem is created when an animal or bird or whatever it is that is endangered in Australia is not endangered overseas. It may not be that the laws of some other countries are lax in not classifying a certain species as endangered; it may well be that that species is in plentiful supply in those other countries. Migratory birds are a classic example. In Australia, there may be very few of a particular kind of migratory bird because its habitats have been wiped out, but there may be many of that species in New Zealand or some other place where those habitats have not been removed.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that, unless we are confident that the situation would not emerge where a species had been declared endangered in Australia but was plentiful somewhere else, we are at risk of imposing unreasonable burdens on Australians. It seems unreasonable to go down what, on the face of it, is otherwise a very reasonable track. I take Senator Coulter's point that one should not allow Australians to do overseas what is illegal in Australia, but there may be cases where it is not illegal overseas for very sound, rational reasons.

I would need to examine the implications of the sort of amendment that Senator Coulter has proposed before I would go along with it. I am also a little concerned that it probably does not achieve what it is seeking to achieve in terms of Australian citizens. I do not know whether the definition of `Australian citizen' would include Australian companies. If an Australian company wants to do something which is illegal in Australia but not illegal overseas, it does not seem to be captured by this amendment. I do not think it is a terribly well constructed amendment and I am not certain of its consequences. I do not believe that it necessarily will achieve its objectives, and I am not certain that in all instances its objectives should be achieved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not so long ago an Australian went—if I recall rightly—to northern Canada and engaged in shooting polar bears, which are a threatened species. When that person returned with `trophies', that person was very much pilloried by most Australians as having engaged in an activity that they find totally repugnant. Of course, no action could be taken against that person. It seems to me that there are instances, albeit rare, of Australians going overseas, committing acts which would not be acceptable here and then coming back and gaining by those acts with impunity in this country. I think it would be in furtherance of Australia's really quite high standing in relation to the environment—
—But wasn't what he was doing illegal in the foreign country?
—It was not illegal in that foreign country.
—He couldn't bring the trophy back if it was an endangered species because it would be an illegal act to bring it back into Australia.

—As the Minister would know, there are certain illegal imports in relation to threatened species. For instance, one could not go to Africa and shoot elephants and bring ivory back into this country. As I recall the particular instance, at the time I do not think it was illegal to bring that trophy back into Australia. So neither the trophy that was brought back, which I think was the skin, nor the act in the foreign country was illegal. One would hope that this provision would not ever be invoked.

PARA.TAB: The Government is concerned about activities of Australians in places such as the Philippines and Thailand in committing sexual acts with underage boys and girls. It regards that as unacceptable behaviour and, as I understand it, is seeking to invoke Australian law to make those sorts of acts illegal. It seems to me that the burden should also be placed on Australian citizens going overseas to not do things which in this country would be illegal. They should not escape the legal consequences of acts which we have rightly made illegal by law in this country simply by committing those acts in a foreign country. That is what we are seeking to catch in this amendment.

In relation to Senator Baume's concern as to whether the amendment extends to Australian companies, I would have thought that in the law generally `Australian citizens' is taken to extend to Australian companies. I would have thought they also would be caught by that. If Senator Baume is suggesting that we include Australian companies, then we would be very happy to include that also in the amendment. I see the Minister alternately nodding and shaking his head.

TALK.START.PARA: —Loose lips sink ships.

—I do not think we are talking about actually sinking any ships in this case, but if it were an Australian vessel and it engaged in activities which were threatening endangered or vulnerable species we believe it should be caught by this legislation, even though those things occur in international waters. I am rather pleased that the Minister used that expression, because perhaps it is in international waters that that offence is more likely to occur. For instance, the green sea turtle in Australia is recognised by most people as a threatened species, but it is still quite acceptable in Indonesia to take that species. As I understand it, most of the predation on that species is occurring in Indonesia. I would certainly not like to see Australians who are keen on turtle soup going to Indonesia and taking that species to escape the consequence of the Australian law. They should be prevented from doing that to the extent that this legislation is capable of achieving that objective.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: "(2) Division 1 provides for Schedules 1 to 3A to set out lists of native species, ecological communities, key threatening processes and non-native species.

We are now dealing with amendment No.9, which relates to clause 14(2) on page 9 of the Bill. We are seeking to omit subclause (2) and substitute a different subclause. We want to change the scheduling somewhat. I draw this particularly to Senator Michael Baume's attention. I am sure that he will agree to some change in the scheduling.

PARA.TAB: Part 2 of this Bill deals with the listing process. Clause 14(1) states:

SPEECH.PARA: This Part provides for listing the native species, ecological communities and threatening processes with which this Act is concerned.
Clause 14(2) states:
Division 1 provides for Schedules 1 to 3 to set out lists of native species, ecological communities and key threatening processes.
We seek to delete that subclause and put in its place:
Division 1 provides for schedules 1 to 3A to set out lists of native species, ecological communities, key threatening processes and non-native species.
This, in a sense, is a triggering amendment in relation to schedule 3A, which relates to the non-native species. This is a significant addition.

PARA.TAB: Amendment No. 11 deals with clause 17 on page 10. It refers to part 1 of schedule 3A, which contains a list of non-native species that are listed as being endangered and part 2, which contains a list of non-native species that are listed as being vulnerable. That again amends the scheduling process. Amendment No. 77 refers to clause 173 on page 71. This again refers to scheduling. In passing, I note that clause 173 also provides for international assistance, something that we were debating only a moment ago. With respect to amendment 77, clause 173.(1) reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to subsection (2), the Director may provide financial assistance to governments of, and organisations in, foreign countries for the purpose of assisting the recovery and conservation, in those countries, of non-native species included in lists established under agreements specified in Schedule 4.
Amendment No. 77 seeks to insert the new schedule 3A so that it reads, `Schedules 3A and 4'. The last amendment in this group, amendment No. 80, states:
After Schedule 3, at end of the following Schedule is inserted:
LISTED NON-NATIVE SPECIES
(Currently no entries)
(Currently no entries)

The earlier amendments, Nos 9, 11 and 77, refer to the scheduling process, particularly numbers in the schedules, whereas amendment No. 80 seeks specifically to insert schedule 3A, which includes non-native species that are endangered and non-native species that are vulnerable.

PARA.TAB: The point is quite simply that Australia may come to contain species which are non-native, but which are nonetheless endangered or vulnerable either globally or in the country of their natural habitat. I can think of quite a number of instances of this; for example, species in zoos may well be rare, endangered and vulnerable. This amendment provides that those species would be recognised as vulnerable or endangered, even though they are non-native. It will allow this legislation, through the scheduling process, to extend to those species so that Australia can take some action in relation to their protection.

It is true that a number of these species will be picked up by schedule 4, which relates to agreements between Australia and other countries. In situations where we have an international agreement with another country—and a number of those agreements are listed in schedule 4—certain species would be picked up. But other species would not be picked up by those bilateral agreements, and Australia should turn its mind to their protection. As these animals are more likely to be in zoos and similar situations, in the past their protection has, in the main, been handled pretty well. Those animals have been protected and looked after, recognising that they are rare and, in some cases, exist only in zoos.

It is appropriate that recognition be given to those non-native species that are endangered or vulnerable under this legislation. After all, this is, and will become, the umbrella under which threatened and endangered species and ecological communities will increasingly be protected. It is, therefore, appropriate that it be made as comprehensive as possible.

I draw the Committee's attention to our amendments, particularly amendment No. 80, which is, if you like, the key amendment of that series. The other amendments, Nos. 9, 11 and 77, refer only to the scheduling process and the need to change it if amendment No. 80 is accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be supporting these amendments. We do not support proposed new schedule 3A for non-native species, and this will be reflected in an action to be taken in respect of other Democrat amendments. We will certainly be opposing, as Senator Coulter correctly says, the major part of that list of amendments for that reason. In addition, we believe, for all of the reasons that we have given in respect of the previous Democrat amendment, that the proposals are unacceptably wide to the Government and impractical in their enforcement. For that reason, we will not support these Democrat amendments.

—The Opposition does not support these amendments either. It does seem that, under the Democrat amendments, Australia may well be prevented from wiping out rabbits and foxes. There is every prospect that that could happen under that proposed amendment, and yet that would be a desirable objective. In fact, it is even recommended in schedule 3 that they be regarded as animals that are causing massive danger. But if they, as non-native species, came down to a very low level of existence in Australia, they could be protected as endangered non-native species.

PARA.TAB: That could cause considerable distress among farming communities. Early on in the history of white settlement in Australia it was only a few rabbits that escaped that generated the rabbit disaster we now have. There is no way we could accept a situation that could see the elimination of rabbits and foxes in Australia frustrated by this kind of legislation. On top of that, there is the general problem of species being endangered in their country of origin but not being endangered in Australia because of either their feral activity or some other thing. We would be obliged to follow external processes, even though they were not endangered in Australia. On all grounds, we totally oppose the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Baume was drawing a very long bow—
—True; he acknowledged it.

—Yes. It is extremely difficult to imagine the rabbit, which was the example he used, becoming essentially extinct in every other country and so profligate and of such great fecundity in Australia that it was overrunning the country and causing so much damage. I do not think that situation is likely to develop. I cannot really imagine the circumstance in which that would occur—that we would have an animal here that is so prevalent it is causing damage and we need to wipe it out but is non-existent, or virtually so, anywhere else.

PARA.TAB: If that were the case, it would be appropriate for Australia to reduce the numbers here and to assist the reintroduction of that species back into the country of origin so that it could take its place in its original habitat. I think the rabbit originally came from South America and was taken to Europe in the seventeenth century or thereabouts; of course, it has overrun a number of countries. For argument's sake, if in South America the rabbit became an endangered species, it would be appropriate for Australia to provide assistance for the reintroduction of rabbits from Australia back into South America. Indeed, clause 173 of the legislation provides for just this sort of assistance. It reads, under `International assistance':

SPEECH.PARA: Subject to subsection (2), the Director may provide financial assistance to the governments of, and organisations in, foreign countries for the purpose of assisting the recovery and conservation, in those countries, of non-native species included in lists established under agreements specified in Schedule 4.

Of course, schedule 4 includes only those cases where there is a bilateral agreement with respect to species. The whole point about including schedule 3A is to make that process much broader. There are clearly recognisable species and ecological communities that would fall outside schedule 4 but should correctly be caught by the ability of the Director to provide financial assistance to the governments of or organisations in foreign countries. Those species would be non-native to Australia by definition but would not be caught under schedule 4. It seems to me that the Government has accepted the principle of this by putting in clause 173 but is tying it to a much narrower schedule—a schedule which does not comprehensively contain endangered species or endangered ecological communities—than is desirable.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, it is appropriate that we put in this other schedule that allows the operation of section 173, which the Government itself has put in, allowing this financial assistance to other governments or organisations in foreign countries to allow for the taking into account of comprehensively endangered species or vulnerable species, or endangered or vulnerable ecological communities or, for instance, species listed in the IUCN Red Data lists. It is simply not a new concept in this legislation. It is an extension of the concept the Government has actually built into the legislation, and it is an appropriate extension of that concept.

In my private member's Bill, which we debated several weeks ago, I also sought, quite appropriately in that legislation, to provide assistance to foreign countries. We need to recognise that there are many countries around the world that recognise and want to protect threatened species but, particularly in the Third World, are financially incapable of doing that. It is appropriate that we are capable of providing that sort of assistance. We as Democrats have said that part of our foreign aid program—which incidentally should be substantially increased—should be targeted towards the protection of species and environments in foreign countries, particularly Third World countries, so that they do not continually degrade their environments, which ultimately impacts very severely on their ability to sustain their human populations.

The amendment we have moved is not breaking new ground. It is doing something the Government has recognised as desirable. The Government has built it in by way of clause 173 and schedule 4 of the legislation. We are simply seeking to extend that notion to a more comprehensive listing process.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not breaking new ground; it is simply widely extending that ground. The current schedule 4, which Senator Coulter has correctly referred to, is deliberately aimed, as we can see from reading it, at extending protection to a number of other species, but in our region of the world, and I think that is the proper focus. Obviously Senator Coulter would be pleased that the Government has extended the ambit this far, and clearly it is something the Government itself strongly supports. But the primary focus, and I think sensibly, as I said earlier in debate, has to be to our own region in terms of that area of the world over which we can sensibly exercise some policing and some responsibility and actually get a result. Schedule 4, as Senator Coulter would have to acknowledge, has as its primary focus the region of the world in which we live.

—I understood that the Government was going to agree to a later amendment to extend schedule 4 to include a couple of other international agreements—I would have to agree with the Minister that China and the South Pacific region are also in our region—signed at Noumea on 24 December 1986. I would not expect, within the limited financial framework of the Government at this time, that with respect to either schedule 4 or an expanded schedule 3A, an enormous amount of assistance would flow in that direction. We can see from the amendment that no species are actually listed in that proposed schedule 3A at this stage. Nonetheless, it provides the opportunity to go down that road when and if an urgent problem emerges and when and if enough finance is available to address that problem.

PARA.TAB: It recognises that we face a global situation. The extinction of species is not going on just in Australia; it is going on globally at an absolutely alarming rate. As a still wealthy country, it is appropriate that we provide ourselves with a legislative backing so that we can do these things, but that we recognise that at the moment we may be quite limited in the extent to which we can do those things. It simply provides that opportunity.

That the amendments (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 14.After clause 24, page 12, insert the following clauses:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Interim listing of native species etc.

PARA.TAB: "24A.(1)A native species or ecological community recommended for listing by the Scientific Subcommittee in either Schedule 1 or 2 but not yet prescribed by the Minister is deemed to be on an Interim List.

TAB.TAB: A native species or ecological community on an interim list is subject only to the provisions under Division 2 of Part 6.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 24 deals with the Minister considering advice from the Scientific Subcommittee and sets out the terms under which the Minister adds or deletes an item from the listing. It is important that we establish the interim list proposed in the amendment. There is a period of up to 30 days between the time the Scientific Subcommittee provides advice on the listing to the Minister and the time that the Minister must make a decision.

PARA.TAB: The point of this amendment is to provide some protection during those 30 days for species recommended for listing by the Subcommittee. The protection relates only to subclause 24(2) which provides for the Minister to actually list the species. The reason for this quite simple. Under this legislation, the Scientific Committee or other members who become aware of the fact that a listing process is in the pipeline are not permitted to divulge information. Nonetheless, that information might well become available to others outside and unless there is some interim protection there could be a situation in which, during that 30 days, the species or ecological community is wiped out.

I recall a specific instance in South Australia where, under the native vegetation clearance regulations brought in under the planning Act, a rare species of plant in one region of Kangaroo Island was destroyed. In the process leading up to the protection of that particular area, the farmer concerned went in with a bulldozer and completely destroyed the area and the plants in that area. There have been other cases in South Australia where, while people did not impact specifically on endangered species of plants and animals, nonetheless, in anticipation of the introduction of regulations which prevented clearing of native vegetation, they went in and cleared native vegetation so that they would not be caught under those regulations.

In this particular case—recognising that we are dealing with endangered and vulnerable species and ecological communities and given that there is an interim period during which the Scientific Committee is providing advice and the Minister is still making a decision—it is important that there be, within that interim period, protection for those species and ecological communities so that no pre-emptive strike or vindictive action is taken against them. Therefore, this particular amendment proposes to address that issue.

I should point out that there will be another amendment to clause 24B. The two proposals are listed together in the amendments which I circulated. They deal with quite separate issues. This amendment No. 14 really deals only with proposed new subclauses 24A(1) and (2). Again, I strongly stress the importance of this interim listing process to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will call the amendment before the Chair amendment No. 14, and the part of your circulated amendment that commences with `Public may nominate' will be called amendment No. 14A.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman, that will make the process a lot more orderly and easier to proceed with. The Government will be opposing this amendment No. 14—that is, the insertion of the new clause 24A—but we will be supporting, with one minor amendment, the amendment that we are now calling No. 14A; that is, the proposed insertion of new clause 24B. But, as I said, we certainly oppose this amendment No. 14 now before the Chair.

PARA.TAB: The effect of that amendment, so far as the Government is concerned, would be to unacceptably fetter the Minister's discretion in this matter. There is no need for a prolonged debate about that. I just say to Senator Coulter that, in the circumstances that he referred to, there would be no difficulty whatever in the Minister acting if someone attempted to carry out such an unconscionable act. The Minister must respond within 30 days, but can, in fact, respond in 24 hours if the Minister wishes to. The effective law enforcement part of this provision takes effect from the time of gazettal. Mr Chairman, I will have to continue my remarks when the debate resumes.
Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a matter of considerable public importance. It relates to the Criminal Justice Commission in Queensland and the retirement last weekend of Sir Max Bingham. After three years as Chairman of the Criminal Justice Commission he—in the words of the Weekend Australian—fired `several parting shots' at Premier Wayne Goss. In doing so, he also attacked the Courier-Mail: he said that it was a `deplorable rag', `close to becoming an arm of government', and `a propaganda arm of the Government'. There may be some truth in this because Peter Beattie, a sitting Labor member of the State Parliament, when he delivered the Dennis Murphy memorial lecture on 14 November, said:

SPEECH.PARA: In all my 18 years of political involvement I have never seen the Courier-Mail so supportive of the political wing of the ALP.

In criticising the Premier, Mr Bingham also alluded to the fact that his departure closed the first chapter in the Fitzgerald report inspired rebuilding of justice administration in Queensland, and the Australian reported:
. . . these bombshell revelations will raise new questions about the Government's handling of the process and, indeed, Goss's own political style.
I believe that he was referring to the expunging of the Hansard record in State Parliament on 7 May 1992 when Mrs Joan Sheldon, in a question without notice, said:
Did Commissioner Newnham ever raise with the Premier the possibility of illegal donations being made to a Labor member of parliament or to the Labor Party?

Mr Goss replied, `No, he did not'. Then following this, on further questioning, he attempted to dissemble. This transcript has been incorporated in the Hansard of this chamber on 20 August by my colleague Senator Parer. I am pleased to note the presence in the chamber of my three colleagues Queensland Liberal Senators Parer, Macdonald and MacGibbon, because they support my remarks. I would refer particularly to the record of proceedings in the Queensland Parliament on 7 May which contained material relating to a transcript of a tape recording of conversations between Mr Angelo Vasta and Mr Santo Coco between 13 November 1989 and 16 November 1989. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the documents that I have previously shown to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins). They are: firstly, a letter from Mr W.L. Antill, Assistant Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, to Mr N.R. Newnham, then Commissioner of Queensland Police, regarding the transcript; secondly, the transcript itself; thirdly, a letter from Mr Newnham to the Hon. W.K. Goss, Premier of Queensland, on 14 February 1990; and, fourthly, a letter from Mr Newnham to Mr Warburton on 11 May 1992.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

MINISTER FOR POLICE AND EMERGENCY SERVICES

TALK.START.PARA: —In the Age newspaper of 8 October this year Mr Newnham was reported as saying that he would withdraw his application for reappointment as Police Commissioner if Mr Mackenroth was reappointed to the Cabinet. A perusal of those documents which have now been incorporated will reveal that in fact Mr Mackenroth was given $5,000 in cash—and a recording of that conversation between Vasta and Coco is in the documents incorporated.

PARA.TAB: Mr Mackenroth was appointed Minister for Housing and Local Government in September after the last State election and, following that, Mr Newnham did withdraw his application for reappointment as Commissioner of Police. If people read those documents they will understand why Mr Newnham is now vindicated on his stance. History will record that he followed on the long tradition of his previous history with the Victorian police department and, now that this matter has come to the public notice, it will vindicate his position.

The transcript shows that $5,000 in cash was given to Mr Mackenroth on 15 or 16 November 1989 and it could easily have been interpreted as a bribe. This was referred to by Sir Max Bingham in the interview in the Weekend Australian of 28-29 November 1992. Sir Max Bingham said that the Sunday Mail attempted to denigrate him when it reported a minor motoring infringement 14 months after it had occurred. In the Weekend Australian it was reported:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the story was given legs after Goss endorsed a call by his police minister, Mackenroth, for a full report `to satisfy everyone the law is applied equally'.

The staff at the Criminal Justice Commission believed that the story had been planted to discredit Sir Max Bingham because of the travel investigation. Of course, following that travel investigation Mr Mackenroth had to resign as Police Minister.

PARA.TAB: I could elaborate further on this material, but because of the time constraints I think it will be necessary to review the Hansard that I spoke about previously in this chamber. As a result of the various statements that have been made, both by Sir Max Bingham and Mr Noel Newnham, there are a series of questions that need to be asked. I challenge the media of Queensland to ask these questions. The first question is: why did Mr Goss mislead Parliament on 7 May 1992 when he said that Commissioner Newnham had not raised a donation with him? He then said that he had been approached in mid-1990 while Mr Mackenroth was overseas and we now know that Mackenroth was not overseas. The Age newspaper of Thursday, 8 October states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Newnham directly contradicted the Premier's version of events when he said he had told Mr Mackenroth that he was going to see Mr Goss.

The second question is: why did the Premier have his comments expunged from the Hansard of 7 May 1992 in Queensland? That has never occurred before and to my knowledge it has not occurred in any other State parliament in Australia. There are serious questions that must be asked about that transcript and the contents thereof.

PARA.TAB: The third question is: why did Mr Goss mislead the public when he claimed last December that the travel expenses inquiry had exonerated his Ministers? This has been repudiated by Sir Max Bingham who said he had only told Mr Goss that none would be charged with criminal offences. There is an obvious disparity between the two reports. The fourth question is: why did Vasta and Coco pay Mackenroth $5,000 in cash? Was this connected with Mackenroth's support of Vasta in Parliament in an attempt to have Vasta reinstated to the Supreme Court?

It is obviously beyond the scope of senators in this chamber to investigate these matters further. They go to the very heart of government in Queensland and the administration of justice. They go to the continuation of the problems that were revealed in the Fitzgerald inquiry, because it is evident that this material has been covered up and not investigated as it should have been.

I note from the Courier-Mail last Saturday that senior appointments have been made in Canberra. Mr Wallace Brown was appointed national affairs editor of Queensland Newspapers. Wallace Brown is known to us all. He is a very senior member of the Canberra press gallery and he has been the Courier-Mail's correspondent since 1961. He is well known and well respected by, I am sure, all in this chamber. He was a foundation member and President of the National Press Club.

Mr Peter Charlton, who is well known to Queenslanders, has been appointed the Courier-Mail's Canberra correspondent. He is the author of nine books, including War against Japan 1941-42, War against Japan 1942-45, and Pozieres 1916: Australians on the Somme. He is another very highly respected member of the media. I challenge both those gentlemen to do all within their power to highlight the material that has been presented today in the Senate chamber because I also note that the masthead on the editorial of the Courier-Mail which was present for many years was dropped in October this year when the page was redesigned. That masthead read: `Our liberty depends on the freedom of the press, and that cannot be limited without being lost (Thomas Jefferson)'.
Yesterday, Premier Goss gave a lecture at Griffith University on the Government and the consultative process. In his address he said:

SPEECH.PARA: Arguably, Queensland has the most open, most honest, most accountable, most consultative government in its history.

I find that unbelievable, given the evidence that I have presented this afternoon. There is a major disparity between the action of the Government, the attempt to cover up by the expunging of the Hansard record and the material that I have presented, together with the disavowal of Premier Goss's comments by the former Police Commissioner, Mr Noel Newnham, a highly respected man who has been denigrated in the press and hounded out of office in Queensland, and the public approval rating of the Premier and the attack made on him by another senior figure, Sir Max Bingham, QC, on his resignation last weekend. In addition to that, there needs to be further investigation of the $5,000 in cash that was given to Mr Mackenroth, who is now a member of the Cabinet in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: I believe that these matters cry out for investigation. I do not think that any further cover-up should occur. Now that the facts have been revealed, it is imperative that they be pursued. I know that I will be supported by my fellow Queensland senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put on the public record alongside the concerns of Senator Herron my concern at recent activities within the Queensland Parliament. I do that without any hesitation or apology because the Senate is primarily a States House and it is quite proper that these sorts of matters are raised within the Senate. Also, in the light of the evidence tabled by Senator Herron, we clearly have a Federal involvement in so far as we have advice that the Australian Federal Police was involved in this matter. Of course, the point at issue relates to the Queensland police force.

PARA.TAB: There is not much point in us, as legislators, even though we accept unreservedly the separation of powers, being negligent in our oversight of the police forces. There is a case for eternal vigilance. The Parliament must always be observant of the police forces to make sure that there are not undesirable or unlawful elements within the police forces themselves and to make sure that a police force does not involve itself in unlawful activities.

We all know the history of the immediate past few years when the Fitzgerald inquiry delved very deeply into the Queensland police force and laid on the public record all the shortcomings that were apparent at that time, but I have a view that the Queensland police force would be no worse than any other police force in Australia. There is a need for constant oversight of the police forces but I do not think the Queensland force was worse than that of any other State. When I look at the furore of the last couple of days over the appointment of a commissioner for Victoria, I have some concerns as to what might be going on in Victoria.

The relevance of all of this is that the present Queensland Government was elected, not once but twice, on a policy of a higher moral code than anyone else in the history of Australian parliamentary democracy. Now there are some very real questions that have to be asked; questions that go right to the probity of the Queensland Government and right to the probity of the Premier of Queensland.

Maybe there are some explanations for the inconsistencies that are now on the public record. The Queensland public are entitled to hear those. I should point out the seriousness of the charge that Senator Herron has laid against the Premier. It is on a matter on which the Premier has misled the Parliament, and consistently misled the Parliament. If he is wrong and has made a genuine mistake, the Parliament affords the opportunity for any member to appear before it and to apologise to the Parliament and say, `The facts were wrong as I presented them'. Certainly Mr Goss has had that opportunity on many occasions this year to have redressed the balance, if indeed the facts as he saw them were wrong, but he has not taken any steps at all to correct the record.

So in the circumstances, we really have to press these questions, because they cannot be swept under the carpet. If they are kept under the carpet, you will find that the carpet slowly unravels and takes Mr Goss and his Government with him.

Those questions are as Senator Herron said: why did Mr Goss mislead the Parliament on 7 May, when he said that the matter was raised with him by the Police Commissioner in mid-1990, when the Minister for Police was overseas? He also said it was done in a backhand way, a sneaky way. It was done furtively by the Police Commissioner going around the police Minister to the Premier himself. The proof is on the public record that the first approach from the Police Commissioner and the first meeting of the Police Commissioner with the Premier were indeed in February 1990, not June 1990. At that time the Minister for Police was not overseas. Moreover, the Minister was advised by the Police Commissioner that this matter was being taken to the Premier. There are three very important questions there that the Premier has to answer.

The second point is this extraordinary move of expunging something from the Hansard record. I am not aware of anyone in this Parliament having the authority to go to Hansard and have a record altered, let alone expunged. From my limited knowledge of history, I know that under the Curtin Government, in the darkest days of the Second World War in 1942, there was a secret meeting of the Federal Parliament and I would presume that, because it was a secret meeting, there was no Hansard record published of that. But the reasons for that were of great national importance. We were in the midst of a war, we were fighting for our lives, and I presume that the purpose of the secret parliamentary meeting was to acquaint the members of parliament with the military situation and the threats facing Australia at that time. But I can think of no other occasion where secrecy was invoked by altering a Hansard record. Certainly Mr Keating could not do it here, and he can do most things.

The excuse that Mr Goss gave was that the item raised in a question was sub judice. That is transparently false. Nothing in the questions that were raised by either Mrs Sheldon, the Leader of the Liberal Party, or Mr Borbidge, the Leader of the National Party, identified the matter which was the subject of the question with any court actions at that time, nor could they have been linked. Over and above everything else, the matter of sub judice has no standing in the parliament, any more than commercial in confidence has. It is a matter of convention that parliament exercises a responsible position and on the evidence, reading the Hansard from Queensland, I think that those members of parliament involved in the questioning did exercise a responsible point of view.
I am left with two questions. Firstly, why would Mr Goss do it, why would he have a record expunged from Hansard? Secondly, how could he do it? I do not know the answers to those questions.

We come to the other question: why did Mr Vasta and Mr Coco pay Mr Mackenroth $5,000, in cash, in used banknotes? Everyone has the right to support a political party, but for most people who are dealing with sums of money over $50, the normal response is to write a cheque, rather than make cash payments of thousands of dollars. In the transcript made by the Australian Federal Police, Mr Vasta and Mr Coco, when talking about the $5,000, say:

SPEECH.PARA: That is good insurance in case they get in.

I do not wish to quote the entire transcript, but clearly `they' refers to the Goss Labor Party and `get in' refers to the election. The intention, as was borne out in a subsequent trial by the Crown Prosecutor, clearly was that Mr Coco, in giving this $5,000 to Mr Mackenroth, wished to put Mr Mackenroth under an obligation. He knew at the time that these people had been charged with the serious offence of attempting to bribe Commonwealth Taxation officers. This claim was that it would be good insurance. The questions that surround the payment of that $5,000 need to be answered frankly by the members of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: As I said a few minutes ago, these questions go to the heart of the probity of the Queensland Government. They go to the heart of the probity of its leader, Mr Goss. That Government was elected because of its high moral stature, and unless those questions are answered, and answered unambiguously, the public in Queensland is entitled to think there is an accelerating decline in the standards of public morality in Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support my colleagues Senator Herron and Senator MacGibbon for raising these very important and serious issues in the Senate. I raised these issues before when the Queensland Government used the extraordinary measure of expunging Hansard records. The questions are now even more important because of the information which Senator Herron has incorporated in Hansard in the form of a Federal Police transcript of conversations between Mr Santo Coco and Mr Vasta. Mr Vasta, incidentally, was formerly Judge Vasta, and Mr Coco is a close relation of Mr Vasta.

PARA.TAB: The expunged record, which was subsequently incorporated by me in the Senate Hansard on 20 August 1992, contains a number of questions which must now be answered. When Mrs Sheldon asked Mr Goss on 7 May whether Commissioner Newnham ever raised with the Premier the possibility of the illegal donations, Mr Goss said no. Joan Sheldon then asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Is it a fact that Commissioner Newnham forwarded directly to you a copy of a Federal Police transcript—
which has now been incorporated in the Federal Hansard—
of a telephone conversation in which a $5,000 bribe was discussed by the former disgraced police Minister, the member for Chatsworth. . .

That is, Mr Mackenroth, who was required to resign because of his involvement in travel rorts, and who has now, following the win of the Goss Government at the last election, been reinstated. She continued:
Is it a fact that following this advice from Commissioner Newnham arrangements were made for the $5,000 to be listed as a legal donation to the Australian Labor Party.

What is hard to reconcile is that, in the transcript which Senator Herron has incorporated, Mr Coco—the person who gave Mr Mackenroth the $5,000 in cash—complained about the fact that he could not get a receipt.

PARA.TAB: Subsequently—and I will come to this further because we find that there are some inconsistencies in all that—Mr Goss in his response to those questions responded by saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . sometime in 1990, I think it was one or two days after the Minister for Police had gone overseas. . . I received a request from the Police Commissioner if he could see me in the Minister's absence.

As pointed out by Senator MacGibbon, it turned out that Mr Mackenroth was not overseas at the time. More importantly, the Minister was aware that the Commissioner for Police was going to see the Premier. Mr Goss went on further to say that he came behind the Minister's back. I have just pointed out that that is not correct. There is another inconsistency; another question that must be answered; another question that must be asked. Mr Goss said:

. . . the Commissioner came to see me to show me a transcript indicating a certain individual, had discussed in a phone conversation with another individual, not the then Minister at all, the making of a donation to that member's election campaign.

Mr Goss said, and I find this absolutely quaint—if ever I have seen anything like Caesar on Caesar—`it certainly warranted investigation by myself'. I emphasise, `by myself'. Here is a man who, in the years prior to getting into government in Queensland, was incredibly critical of the then government of the day for what turned out were relatively minor issues, but for which some ex-Ministers went to gaol. Mr Goss said:
I would expect such a donation to be declared. . . I would expect, particularly if the payment was in cash—
cash totalling $5,000—
. . . that, instead of what happened in the past where it is put into somebody's pocket, that the second test would be, that it be fully documented and accounted for in the normal accounting records.
He then went on to say:

I made inquiries and I found, I was able to confirm that in fact, there had been a declaration of the donation by the member in his declaration of pecuniary interests. . . had simply been passed on to the Electoral Executive Committee in the normal way that all donations are passed on, in various political organisations and in the Labor Party, and was fully receipted and accounted for. . .

This raises a number of additional questions. It was `fully receipted'. Who received the receipt? Was it Mr Mackenroth who received the receipt? Apparently, from the police transcript, it was not Mr Coco. Part of the transcript that is fairly important to Messrs Coco and Vasta is that they got the receipt, because it enabled them to be able to go back and collect at some later date. Now Mr Goss said it was receipted and I repeat the question: to whom was the receipt given? Mr Goss said he decided to discuss the matter with the Chairman of the Criminal Justice Commission, Sir Max Bingham. He said:
I laid the facts before him and Sir Max Bingham advised me that in his view, the member concerned had acted with complete propriety, and acknowledged to me.
And I remind you that Sir Max Bingham is a former Liberal member of parliament, and confirmed to me that it was quite a normal political donation that had been handled in a normal way. . .

This raises a number of other questions. What facts did Mr Goss lay before Sir Max Bingham? Did Sir Max, for instance, know about the Federal Police tape which clearly Mr Goss knew about? Another question that must be asked; another question that must be answered. What in fact did Mr Goss tell Sir Max Bingham—what facts did he lay before him? During the trial of Mr Coco, who was tried for seeking to bribe a taxation officer—that was the background of the trial—the question was raised by the Crown Prosecutor, Mr Weinberg, who told the trial of Mr Coco:
The material—that is the Mackenroth tape—
which none of us has seen until now—
discloses that between the 13th and 16th November 1989, there were several communications between Coco and Mackenroth by phone and in person.
Mr Justice De Jersey of the Queensland Supreme Court then asked:
What did you say? It shows an attempt to confer a bribe on Mr Mackenroth?
The Crown Prosecutor replied:
It shows a willingness to have the money which has been handed over treated as a bribe.

The Crown says it shows a willingness on the part of those two accused, who have handed over a sum of $5000 in cash, indeed a preference as far as Coco is concerned, to have the money retained as a bribe.

It is not our position to judge matters like this, but we do have a responsibility to air them when these sorts of things occur and when the implications become known. There is no doubt, from the transcript which Senator Herron has incorporated, that Coco and Vasta clearly intended the $5,000 to be a bribe; and there is absolutely no doubt whatsoever that Mr Mackenroth took the money.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, these are very serious matters. Over the last few years the matter of propriety in government has become—quite correctly, I would say—a very major issue, and something in which the general public has a very keen interest. Now that this information is known, simply to restore propriety of the elected representatives in Queensland it is important that these questions be asked and that they be answered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my Queensland colleagues in raising this matter of very serious public interest about some things that appear to be happening within the Government of Queensland and within certain elements of the Labor Party in Queensland. There is a smell coming from that area, and I think this should be raised in the public interest before it becomes a stench. Madam Acting Deputy President, you would be aware of allegations of wrongdoing in connection with the Labor Party and its shareholding in Jupiters Casino. Those sorts of things, as I understand, are currently under investigation.

PARA.TAB: But the matter that Senator Herron and my other Queensland colleagues raise today is also one that requires much further investigation by people concerned with good government in Queensland. I was concerned about some of the material that came out in the trial of Mr Santo Coco, and I want to quote some sections of it which are of particular concern to me. The Crown Prosecutor in that trial told the court:

SPEECH.PARA: The material—that is the Mackenroth tape—discloses that between the 13th and 16th November 1989, there were several communications between Coco and Mackenroth by phone and in person.
The trial judge, Mr Justice De Jersey, then asked:
What did you say? It shows an attempt to confer a bribe on Mr Mackenroth?
The Crown Prosecutor, Mr Weinberg, replied:
It shows a willingness to have the money which has been handed over treated as a bribe.

The Crown says it shows a willingness on the part of those two accused, who have handed over a sum of $5000 in cash, indeed a preference as far as Coco is concerned, to have that money retained as a bribe.

The evidence contained in the Mackenroth material, however, shows that Coco was serious about having Vasta restored to the bench, and that Vasta was serious about having his position reviewed by the ALP when it came into government.

The Mackenroth conversations occurred between 13 and 16th November 1989 at the very same time as these two accused are allegedly engaged in a conspiracy to defraud the Commonwealth by bribing the two tax officers to reverse sham transactions.

(This was) in order to be able to shout from the rooftops before the election that Vasta was wrongly found to have engaged in sham transactions and the professed aim being to have him restored to the bench.
This is the conspiracy the Crown alleges.
Coco was himself highly desirous of Mackenroth keeping the money without a receipt and treating it as a bribe.
They (Coco and Vasta) had an association which was far from innocent with Mr Mackenroth.

That causes me some concern. As honourable senators will recall, Mr Mackenroth, the Labor member for Chatsworth in the Queensland Parliament, resigned in disgrace over some travel rort allegations and left the Queensland Ministry. I might say that this followed what I suppose could be called, to put it mildly, an indiscretion by Mr Mackenroth when he used the government plane, after years of criticising the previous Government for using the Joh jet for political purposes, and flew to Port Macquarie to try to get the Labor member for Nundah to withdraw his resignation from the Queensland Parliament because the Government did not want a by-election there. Mr Mackenroth, after criticising the previous Government, saw no hypocrisy in then using the government plane for a purely political matter.

PARA.TAB: However, as a result of the travel rort allegations, Mr Mackenroth resigned in disgrace. Unfortunately, he has just recently been reinstated as the Minister for Housing and Local Government. I would have thought that was an unusual step for the Labor Party in Queensland. It did not reinstate other people who resigned at the same time. For example, Mr Ken McElligott, the Labor member for Thuringowa, which is up my way, also resigned over what I would have thought was a fairly innocuous set of allegations. He resigned, admitting some wrongdoing, but he expected to be put back on the Government benches after the election. He was not, but Mr Mackenroth was.

Now the rumour doing the rounds of the Queensland Parliament is that the current Deputy Premier, Mr Tom Burns, will announce his retirement in the not too distant future, and the further rumour is that Mr Mackenroth is favoured to take on the new Deputy Premier's role. That also causes me some concern. I join my colleagues in simply raising these matters and asking questions that really do need to be answered. Why, for example, did Mr Goss say that Newnham had gone behind Mackenroth's back to report these allegations when, in fact, Mr Newnham denies this? Why did Mr Goss say that Mackenroth was overseas at the time?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Please use the proper titles for members of parliament.

—Why did Mr Goss say that Mr Mackenroth was overseas at the time, when this was patently untrue? Those questions need answering. I might say that Mr Greg Roberts, a reporter for the Age, who I think has done some good investigative work, did report on this in the 8 October edition. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Goss told Parliament in May that Mr Newnham had `gone behind the back' of Mr Mackenroth in 1990 to give the Premier the Federal Police transcript concerning the minister.
In an extraordinary move, the Government later expunged the Premier's comments from Hansard. He continued:
Mr Newnham directly contradicted the Premier's version of events when he said he had told Mr Mackenroth that he was going to see Mr Goss.

So not only did he not go behind his back, not only was Mr Mackenroth not overseas, but, according to Mr Newnham, he told Mr Mackenroth that he was going to report this matter to the Premier. Mr Goss has denied that, in direct contravention of what Mr Newnham says, and the question has to be raised: why did Mr Goss deny that?

PARA.TAB: As well, we should demand an explanation of why the Premier had his comments expunged from the Queensland Hansard of 7 May. Why did Mr Goss mislead the public when he claimed last December that the travel expenses inquiry had exonerated his Ministers? This was repudiated by Sir Max Bingham, the head of the CJC, who said not that he had exonerated his Ministers but that he had only told Mr Goss that none of them would be charged with criminal offences—quite a different thing from saying that he exonerated his Ministers. Why did Vasta and Coco pay Mr Mackenroth $5,000 in cash? Was this connected with Mackenroth's support of Vasta in the Parliament and was it an attempt to have Vasta restored to the Supreme Court? Those are the sorts of questions that do, in fact, need to be answered.

Those of us from Queensland well remember how the Queensland media were very enthusiastic and energetic in the pursuit of what they saw as corruption in the previous Government. There was not a day went by when some investigative journalist or one of the current affairs TV shows did not have something on the air or in print about pursuing these allegations of corruption in the previous Government. The Queensland media certainly did take on a role then of pursuing those allegations to the result that is now part of history. I am quite confident that the Queensland media will be equally diligent, equally energetic and equally enthusiastic in pursuing the evidence which my colleague Senator Herron has tabled in this Parliament today.

TALK.START.PARA: —In July this year the Australian Democrats and the Government finally reached a deal in relation to the superannuation guarantee charge legislation which effectively meant that, like it or not, whether businesses could afford to pay or not, they were going to have imposed upon them a compulsory regime which would increase over time and which would effectively mean that lowest common denominator superannuation would replace the current largely voluntary system.

PARA.TAB: As part of that deal, the Australian Democrats made great play of the fact that it might be the case that the economy would be in such poor shape by the end of the year that it would be necessary to slow down the proposed rate of increase. Accordingly, an amendment was inserted into the legislation to enable the disallowance of the increase from 4 to 5 per cent for companies with payrolls in excess of $1m so that it did not take effect from 1 January 1993 but was effectively delayed until 1 July 1993.

Since that time, of course, no-one in his right mind would argue that the economy has gone other than south: we have only to look at the most devastating economic results that have been announced in the last few days in terms of current account deficit and the blow-out in foreign debt and all those economic indicators which make it abundantly clear that Australia is in diabolical trouble. Of course, those employers who have not already gone to the wall are struggling to make ends meet. Private net investment is, of course, down and continuing to go down.

If there is one thing that ought to be obvious to all, it is that business has even less capacity to pay that increase now than it had then. Yet what we have had in the last few days is some indication from the Australian Democrats that now they take a different view. As recently as 28 October, Senator Kernot was saying to the media, `We cannot afford it, it had to be disallowed', and she was going to urge her colleagues to support her. One does not even know whether it went to the Democrats party room and whether they resolved accordingly five weeks ago, but now we are faced with this extraordinary performance whereby Senator Kernot is currently prepared to put jobs at risk for the sake of playing some political games.

I find it regrettable in the extreme that Senator Kernot can now seek to justify this volte-face by linking it to a decision that has recently been taken by the coalition in respect of the deductions of personal contributions to superannuation, because there is a very significant difference. The fact is that, with regard to the decision in relation to personal contributions, all we have said is this: the Government has the capacity to restore to individuals the right to make tax deductible contributions. They have had that right for years. Indeed, 1.3 million people in the last financial year took advantage of that opportunity and made those deductions. Yet on 30 June, on less than 24 hours notice, the Government announced that henceforth that entitlement would cease. That was an unforgivable decision. We do not for one moment condone it and we never have, and we have made our displeasure very clear.

What we have said, in recent days particularly, is that those people will have a clear choice at the next election. They know that this Government does not propose to allow people to top up. It takes the view that employers ought to bear the burden and that employees ought to forget about super and leave it to the bosses to make the payments, as they will be required to do by statute—the usual jackboot approach. In contrast, under us—immediately after the next election—they will have access to generous tax concessional arrangements. So we are not depriving people of anything that the Government has not already taken away from them; we will be restoring tax concessions after the election.

In relation to the increase in the SGC, we have a very different position. It does not have to go to 5 per cent; it certainly does not have to go to 5 per cent from 1 January. Indeed, on all the available evidence, it is clear that the country cannot afford it. But if it does go there, by virtue of the regulation not being disallowed, then we are stuck with accepting the level that is in place at the time of the next election. That, of course, would mean a totally artificial disparity between those employed by companies with payrolls of less than $1m, who would only get 3 per cent, and those above that, who would get 5 per cent.

That is a quite unnecessary and meaningless distinction. It simply aggravates the position and is one that we would have no ability to reverse. Quite clearly it is necessary to take the very action which Senator Kernot has been advocating for months and which would reflect the views of, I suspect, every organisation and interest group in the country except the ACTU, which has always believed in the divine right to double dip and which does not have any problem about seeing the rate go up, irrespective of whether or not business has the capacity to pay.

Senator Kernot has been visited in recent days by a whole range of business organisations, pleading with her to uphold her previous solemn promises. Yet we still have this dithering going on. I think the tragedy is this: there is rank sophistry, hypocrisy and double-speak in any suggestion that it is necessary to increase the SGC to compensate those people who might temporarily be denied access to tax concessions. That is what Senator Kernot said on 2CN this morning.

That is a preposterous and misleading suggestion because quite clearly, if there is a Labor government after the next election, that level will automatically increase from 1 July next year. Those people are not going to be denied their increase. Of course, a coalition government would be giving them back those tax concessions. People do not need compensation in any sense, other than what might be available to them if the Government and the Democrats were able to get together and restore, at least temporarily until the election, the ability to make tax concessional contributions.

Therefore, I find it extraordinary that Senator Kernot should be saying that she believes that our earlier decision this week was for what she said was the basest political reason, isolating the Democrats. The fact is that they deserve to be marginalised and sidelined, for no better reason than the fact that they have something like 1,000 members around Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't exaggerate.

—I am sorry, I take it back. They would claim, I suspect, up to 1,000. They have got about 5 per cent of the popular vote. In Victoria they are truly a mickey mouse outfit. They have effectively been halved and they command no respect in the electorate.

PARA.TAB: What is very significant in explaining why Senator Kernot is so furious is that she is undoubtedly posturing in the run-up not just to the next election but to the next leadership contest in the Australian Democrats, which takes place by plebiscite after the election. All those people, up to 1,000 of them, have the opportunity to register their view of the current performance of the leadership. Unfortunately for Senator Kernot, who comes from Queensland—where I suspect the party membership is not in double figures—the leader, the deputy leader and I think the national president are all from South Australia, so she has got to go over their heads to the people.

What we have been seeing in recent days is an incredible performance from someone who quite rightly recognises that she has been denied the opportunity to screw yet another deal out of the Government at the last minute, claim all the kudos, and then put that forward as her credentials for the leadership challenge. It would seem very clear that hell hath no fury like a Democrat leadership pretender scorned, and that in what she is currently in the process of doing to get Senator Coulter's job she is prepared to put up to 10,000 jobs at risk. That, I think, is the great tragedy of the Democrats' position on this issue, because quite clearly this increase will have job consequences. If employers bear the full burden, we know from Treasury that up to 10,000 jobs could go, it could add to employer costs by something like $700m, and could affect something like 25,000 firms and 40 per cent of all wage and salary earners. It has very significant job implications.

The other issue that Senator Kernot quite speciously seeks to link to this one is in relation to people having the ability to make tax concessions. That may temporarily affect those individuals who would otherwise have preferred to continue making significant contributions but who might now have to pay a bit more or breach their contracts, but it certainly is not putting jobs at risk; and that is what is so deplorable about the current game that is being played by the Australian Democrats. I therefore urge them to reconsider, to put the national interest first, to stop protecting the Government and start protecting jobs. I urge them to accept that this issue is one on which they have made their position clear time and again. The circumstances have changed only to the extent that they have made even more compelling the case that they have sought to make over recent months, and there can be no justification at all for putting jobs at risk in the way that Senator Kernot is proposing to do, simply to try to manufacture a bit more publicity at the last moment.

It might have worked in July. She might have had a compliant Government then.
