I suspect that if we had sought to block the removal of tax concessions in due course we would have had the Government again being prepared to make last minute concessions. Indeed, I have had very good information that the Government was not only expecting to have to horse-trade with the Australian Democrats, but was prepared to look at things such as phasing out and removing the more odious retrospective effects of this proposal, so that rather than being backdated to 1 July it would have taken effect from when the legislation came into force.

Of course, that has been denied. If the Democrats and the Government now do a deal, it will be transparently obvious that it was not forced by weight of numbers in this chamber but was simply some sort of crude political exercise. Also, of course, Senator Kernot has lost her leverage, and one can understand her fury in that regard. But that in no way excuses her from her obligation to protect the jobs that the Democrats claim are important, which Treasury makes clear are very important, and which I would hope this Government still recognises are important. Therefore, the opportunity is still there. In the days leading up to next Tuesday, when this matter will be finally debated, I hope that all those people with an interest in protecting jobs in this community will make their view known to Senator Kernot in no uncertain terms: that they are not prepared to see jobs put at risk simply for the sake of leadership games that might be played after the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to pay tribute to a great Tasmanian. Roelf Vos died as he had lived, at peace with his God and surrounded by the love and concern of his children, grandchildren and friends. Mr Vos arrived here in 1951 as a Dutch migrant with his wife Miep and the first three of his six children. He brought little with him but his faith, his hardworking attitude and a bright optimism which was easily caught by all who came into contact with him.

PARA.TAB: He was a true Australian. He brought little, from the material point of view, to his adopted country, but left so much that this speech could not even start to list his accomplishments. In fact, Roelf Vos commenced work as a labourer during the day and then at a cannery at night in a small town, Ulverstone, approximately 100 kilometres north-west of Launceston. From this he was able to put together enough capital to open his first shop. From there he built up, over the next two decades, Tasmania's largest supermarket chain, the Roelf Vos stores.

At one stage there were over 16 stores throughout the north of the State. A trip to Vos's for the groceries became the norm for many a Tasmanian family. In 1982 the supermarket chain was purchased by Woolworths, while the freehold of the stores was maintained by the Vos family. Woolworths at the time noted that this particular supermarket chain was so efficient that, as part of the purchase deal, it requested the continuance of the present management team and its full staff.

Woolworths recognised the respect for the Roelf Vos name within the community and promptly changed the name of its own stores to this unusual Dutch name. This was but an indication of the influence of Roelf Vos's values, beliefs and ethics throughout his supermarkets. He symbolised the best of the so-called Protestant work ethic.

After selling out to Woolworths, he then went on to develop one of Tasmania's most beautiful tourist and housing complexes known as Grindelwald just outside Launceston in the Tamar Valley. Within this complex beautiful chalet style homes have been built on the Swiss model. Over the years a new five-star hotel, tourist resort and convention centre equipped with golf courses, lakes, tennis courts and other facilities were added. In fact, in the last 12 months a new complex especially for the over-50s has been built. This was an example of his vision, drive and determination.

However, his business dealings were not his overriding passion, because he led a purposeful life. He was a businessman who respected and loved his God and lived and respected those values epitomised by his faith in the Christ of the Gospels. He loved his family and his church. He was a businessman who worked six days a week and had respect for the now often scorned day of worship, the seventh. Sunday was a day which he spent with his family, his church family and his friends.

His values, his ethics and his beliefs were lived. They were based on his christianity, which determined and ruled his life. He was not a pious, self-righteous man, but his manner was infectious, loving, joyful and optimistic. When Christ, whom Roelf Vos loved, walked this earth, he quickly drew crowds around him. Roelf Vos was determined to reflect his God. He was a gregarious person. People were important to him. He never took on airs. Every individual was given his full attention, whether it was a chance meeting such as on one of his daily walks or in his daily contact with the business world or those who worked with him. Every person was especially important to him. A noted doctor, Dr John Morris, Chairman of the Clifford Craig Medical Research Foundation, noted:

SPEECH.PARA: He was a marvellous person to work with and behind it all was his devout belief in his maker—it was a very motivating force in his life.
On the other hand, the Mayor of Launceston, Alderman Graeme Beams, noted that `he was always prepared to have a go and not be deterred by minor setbacks'.

PARA.TAB: The late Mr Vos is survived by his wife of 46 years, Miep, and by sons and daughters. To all of them I would like to pay a special tribute and express our grief on behalf of Tasmanians in this Parliament. Tasmania has indeed lost a man of quality who, on his death, has not merely come to the end of his existence but makes a new beginning. His trust in the Lord Jesus Christ, who took away the finality of the grave, is now vindicated. Indeed, he is alive in heaven with the God whom he served. I thank the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for quite appropriately putting on the public record today his views on a great Tasmanian. We extend our condolences in this incident.

PARA.TAB: I will not really comment on what Senator Alston said today, although I did get a sense of deja vu, having woken up to his golden words on AM this morning. I had a bit of a lie-over and actually heard most of what he said on AM, but he has come in here and put it on the record. He did make some allusions to the leadership aspirations and contests in the Democrats. I am still waiting for the figures of the last ballot. I have asked for them in this chamber on a couple of occasions. For a party that is committed to openness et cetera, I do expect Senator Coulter at some stage to provide us with the figures in the last leadership ballot between him and the other Democrats. I think Senator Alston has probably put his finger on why they have never been published, that it would reveal the smallness of their membership.

We heard from four Queensland senators today. I almost thought I had drifted off into the Queensland Parliament. They raised questions that I cannot address and cannot answer simply because I have no knowledge of them. I think you can be pretty much assured, though, that in the Queensland Parliament, where they really should be debated, they will be addressed and debated in the near future in response to what was raised here.

I do have one comment to make, however, on Senator Herron's attack on the Courier-Mail as being pro-Labor. I am not a regular reader of the Courier-Mail, so I cannot particularly comment on that, although some of my colleagues have led me to believe that the opposite has been the case over the years. I have one comment for Senator Herron to go away and think about. No newspaper in this country could be as politically biased, as malignant, as thuggish in its attitude as the Melbourne Herald-Sun has been in the last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —The West Australian is a good second.

—No, I am a regular reader of the West Australian and it simply is not in the same ballpark. We are not talking now about editorials directed against Labor. I do not care if the Herald-Sun every day for the next 50 years writes editorials about the Labor Party. I am talking about an integrated campaign, from journalists through to cartoonists, through the whole construction of the paper, meant and designed to rip into every aspect of the Labor Party. It would not matter if the Kennett Government made the grossest of mistakes—they would barely be reported in the Herald-Sun. But I do have some hope for the future. I notice that the editor who has destroyed this once great newspaper, as the Melbourne Sun was, has been redeployed to Fox Studios in Cali-fornia—and where better could he exercise his talent for fantasy and untruths but in Fox Studios. I do not know the new editor. I wish him well. I do not even ask for balance from the newspaper, I just ask for a go occasionally in the newspaper on behalf of the Labor Party.

PARA.TAB: So I will just say to Senator Herron that he should go and read the Melbourne Herald-Sun. He will find himself terribly refreshed in terms of newspaper bias. It has been the worst form of political bias in newspapers in this country in the last 30 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Prime Minister. I ask: does the Prime Minister not realise that the Kennett Government in Victoria was overwhelmingly elected to correct the disastrous economic mismanagement of 10 years of Labor government, which saw it inherit an unemployment rate of 11.8 per cent, a debt of over $30 billion, a Budget deficit blow-out to $2.2 billion, and the loss of its State Bank and Pyramid Building Society? Why will the Minister and his Government not accept the decision of the people of Victoria and, rather, face up to the Government's responsibilities of addressing the national economic mess the Government has caused—a record $200 billion foreign debt, a massive current account deficit and a million Australians unemployed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Question Time is gradually being turned into sloganeering by Senator Hill. We have had all the economic figures this week and we have debated them in the Senate. The Opposition has been a bit reluctant to debate them. As I said yesterday, Opposition senators come in here all pumped up, as if they have their hands full of hand grenades; they turn out to be over-ripe watermelons, thrown by people with limp wrists. We have looked at the balance of payments figures. We have dealt with that issue in the Senate this week. We have looked at the question of Australia's national debt. I notice that Mr Beers, of Standard and Poors, said this morning:

ANSWER.PARA: I think it is very important for people to bear in mind that the debt burden in relation to the country's exports earnings, which is an important indicator that we look at, has been relatively stable over the last couple of years.
The debt has moved from 39 per cent to 42 per cent of GDP. Is that something that concerns you?
Well, no, because we look at the medium term.

That is what he said about it. It is no good Senator Hill coming in here and trying to rebury the Kirner Government in Melbourne. There has been an election and, as he pointed out, the Liberal Party won it. Mr Kennett went into the election in Victoria saying that nobody would be worse off as a result of the election of his Government. Every household in Victoria is going to be a hundred bucks worse off before Christmas. Irrespective of whether one is a pensioner or a multimillionaire, one is going to be a hundred bucks worse off. Every wage earner in Victoria is going to be worse off as a result of the Victorian Government's industrial relations policies, and Senator Hill has the hide to come in here and try to repump up the results of the Victorian election. If ever there was misrepresentation by a party seeking election, it occurred in Victoria. It will come back to haunt the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I think the Minister missed the question. The question was: why will the Federal Government not butt out of Victoria's affairs? Why will it not respect the decision of the Victorian electors and, rather, do something about the economic mess it has created? When are we going to see the Government's employment policies?

—That was not the question I was originally asked. After nine years in opposition and 27 years of failed government, when the coalition did nothing about the restructuring of this economy, it is time the coalition learnt that the climate of industrial relations in this country and wages policy are very important to the Australian economy. When Opposition senators learn that, they will be able to ask these questions with a greater degree of credibility. They talk about butting into Victoria's situation. Nearly half the people in Victoria are under Federal awards already. Is that butting into Victoria's situation?
—What is wrong with democracy? What is wrong with a State government making a State decision about State matters?
—I understand that Opposition senators are very protective of their friend Jeff Kennett. They try to pull people's legs every time they talk about Fightback.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and relates to disturbing incidents that have taken place in Cambodia over the last 24 hours. I ask: can the Minister provide further details of the incidents, reported in today's media, involving UN personnel in Cambodia, including the holding of six United Nations military personnel by the Khmer Rouge and the subsequent firing on a UN helicopter carrying UN officials going to seek the release of the six, with the wounding of one of the officials in the helicopter? Further, is the Minister able to provide the Senate with his assessment of the implications of these incidents for the future implementation of the peace process in Cambodia?

—The facts about the incidents over the last two days are as follows: on 1 December the Khmer Rouge captured and detained six UNTAC military observers, three British, two Filipino and one New Zealander, at a KR checkpoint on a river 20 kilometres from Kompong Thom. UNTAC has been in contact with the observers, who say that they have not been harmed. UNTAC has been negotiating with the KR and is confident that the military observers will be released shortly. There have been some reports about alleged conditionality of that release, but the Khmer Rouge headquarters in Phnom Penh says that there will be no such conditions. UNTAC headquarters understands that the local Khmer Rouge commander believed that the military observers were spying for the CPAF, that is, the Hun Sen armed forces based in Phnom Penh. The Khmer Rouge office in Phnom Penh, however, maintains that it is not Khmer Rouge policy to confront UN troops. That is the basis of the negotiated release that is now occurring.

PARA.TAB: On 2 December—yesterday—a UN helicopter with a party on its way to Kompong Thom to negotiate this release was fired upon. A French lieutenant-colonel was wounded in the upper thigh. That flight returned to Phnom Penh. Again, it is the case that also yesterday in Siem Reap province two Tunisian civilian police were seriously injured when the UN vehicle they were in drove over an anti-tank mine. Two hours later in the same location three Indonesian civilian police were injured in the same circumstances when their vehicle ran over another mine.

The Australian Government is concerned by these various acts against UN personnel in Cambodia. Peacekeeping by its very nature does involve some risks, and certainly neither I nor anyone else in the Government has ever sought to disguise the risks that are inherent in the exercise for UNTAC personnel, including members of the Australian contingent. We are, of course, conducting an ongoing assessment of the security situation in Cambodia, with special implications for the safety of Australian personnel. We will continue to do that. Every effort is being made to minimise the risks to our personnel, in line with the responsibilities of their functions, of course.

The detention of UN personnel is the first incident of its kind. According to all the information we have been able to glean, it appears likely that the detention was a local decision rather than reflecting some new strategy by the KR leadership, in which case the implications for the overall settlement are limited. However, we are continuing to assess the situation further.

The attack on the UN helicopter is one of over 20 which have now occurred since the UN arrived and which were specifically condemned in a UN Security Council resolution a couple of days ago. Such incidents certainly make the implementation of a settlement more difficult and more dangerous, but it is everyone's judgment, I believe, at this stage, that they have not threatened the settlement. Similarly, injuries to UN personnel through landmines have occurred previously. They are of grave concern and illustrate the need for extreme care in movement around Cambodia. Despite all these incidents, the implementation of the settlement does continue in the way I described a couple of days ago, with results that still give us all grounds for very considerable optimism that we will be able to proceed to elections in April-May.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question, Mr President. I refer to the Minister's remarks relating to the safety of Australian personnel in Cambodia. Is he able to provide the Senate with an assessment of the implications for the safety of ADF personnel currently serving as part of the UN peacekeeping mission?

—I am really unable to add further to what I said in that respect. The ADF personnel are essentially scattered around the country in individual locations performing their communications role. They are constantly on the move and, as a result, liable to problems with landmines, particularly if new ones are being laid, but we have no particular current evidence of that. All we can say, as I have already said, is that we are continuing to try to assess the implications for the safety of our personnel, indeed UN personnel generally, and the current assessment is as I have described it.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. I ask the Minister: if the Government's industrial relations system is so good, why is it that after 10 years of Labor government Australia has the worst recession in 50 years, a record million unemployed, falling real wages, falling investment, lower productivity, a record $200 billion debt and a collapsing dollar?
—I referred earlier to people throwing over-ripe watermelons. Senator Parer's question indicates that he is one.

—I take a point of order, Mr President. I refer you to standing order 194, which says that a senator shall not digress from the subject. The question was a very simple one about the state of the economy after 10 lousy Labor years, and I request you to draw his attention to that matter.
—I am sure Senator Button is going to answer the question.

—The short answer to the question is that, like every other country in the OECD, this economy has been through a recession. With recession there is inevitably rising unemployment and there is inevitably falling investment, but there is not inevitably falling productivity. In fact, the honourable senator is wrong about that. The trend productivity rates in this country are considerably better than they were when we came out of the last recession. These things are the concomitant of a recession.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill, a while ago, did not seem to understand that industrial relations and wages policy are very important in the context of an economy like Australia's. We cannot isolate Victoria. We live in an international economy now, not the sort of silly domestic economy that the coalition operated for so many years. It is quite extraordinary for Senator Parer, in contradistinction to his leader, to come in here and suggest that the industrial relations system has failed because we have a recession. It is a ludicrous question. I know that it gives the honourable senator the opportunity to reiterate all the mindless slogans of the Opposition, but that is all it does.

The industrial relations system in this country has been through an extraordinary change. That is reflected in the huge increase in manufactured exports from this country, and it is reflected in the fact that last Monday's national stoppage, as it was called, was the first time we had had such a thing for years and years. When the Opposition parties were in government we had one of those about every month. The stoppage stood out last Monday. What caused it all? It was the abuse by the Kennett Government in Victoria of its election mandate.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a supplementary question, Mr President, I ask the Minister: is he saying that he has had no responsibility whatsoever for the recession, and is this why the Government has absolutely no policies to address the million unemployed, the falling real wages, the falling investment, the record $200 billion debt and the lower productivity?
—How do you help that by mugging Australians?

—These people think they help themselves, not Australians, by mugging the Australian economy. That is what they think; they think that by talking down the Australian economy they will help themselves. That, of course, is not true. I do not know where Senator Parer has been for the last three years. If he says that we accept no responsibility for the recession, I say that we have never done that. I do not know what he has been doing; he must have been dozing away over there. I see his head nodding; I suppose it will fall off or he will go to sleep. I do not know what he is doing there. We have never said what Senator Parer asks about, and it is a misrepresentation, in a supplementary question, to suggest that we have.

—My question is directed to Senator Collins, the Minister for Transport and Communications. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the implications for the future of ethnic broadcasting in Australia of the Federal Government's decision to establish a national SBS radio network?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased indeed to advise the Senate that the Government will establish a national SBS radio network to meet the increasing needs of ethnic communities around Australia. It will provide ethnic communities in Adelaide, Perth, Brisbane, Darwin, Hobart and Canberra with their first full SBS radio service. The new service will also give Sydney and Melbourne a second SBS radio service to complement 2EA and 3EA.
—All the unemployed can watch it.

—I know that the Opposition is opposed to this kind of thing. I know that it wants to cut $6m out of the budget of SBS. That is in Fightback. Sydney, Canberra and Hobart will come on line from July 1994, and broadcasting will begin in Melbourne, Adelaide, Perth, Brisbane and Darwin from December next year. Those lead times are required for the community consultation necessary for programming and for the provision of the infrastructure itself.

PARA.TAB: SBS will develop programming schedules in consultation with ethnic communities prior to taking decisions on program content, format and schedules. This decision is a clear demonstration of the Federal Government's ethnic broadcasting strategy, its ongoing commitment to SBS in particular, and community broadcasting in general. It stands, as I said in response to that helpful interjection from Senator Parer a few moments ago, in stark contrast to the Opposition's policy contained in the Fightback document to cut $6m out of the funding for SBS.

I must say that I am very curious about that Fightback commitment to cut $6m from the SBS budget when Senator Alston, who represents this particular portfolio in this chamber, said in this chamber on 11 November last year in respect of SBS:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . we regard SBS as a lean and efficient organisation, providing consistently high quality programs . . .

In fact, Senator Alston said that SBS gave Australia `good value for money'. Perhaps Senator Alston could explain to those people who listen to SBS broadcasts—and there are very many of them—how the coalition on the one hand can have a member of its front bench who represents this portfolio say in the Senate that SBS is good value for money and provides a good service for Australia and, on the other hand, in stark contrast to the Government's position on this, can propose in Fightback to cut the budget of SBS by $6m a year.

PARA.TAB: It is even more astonishing to see a press statement from the shadow Minister, Warwick Smith, giving support to the establishment of the second network that the Government has determined on when the Opposition is going to not just cut SBS's current budget, which is very small, but amputate it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—I thank the Minister for his answer, but as a supplementary question I ask him whether he can provide the Senate with any additional information regarding the present and anticipated audience reach of SBS television and radio services and their importance to Australians of non-English speaking backgrounds.
—Turn your tie down, Jim.

—I think he must have won it in a raffle, Senator Alston. Research on the audience reach of SBS television, conducted during 1991 and released earlier this year, clearly shows that SBS TV made significant gains in all the capital cities in which it broadcasts. The research shows that SBS television increased its audience reach by more than 60 per cent over the previous year. It is estimated that SBS television is now watched by between 3.1 million and 3.3 million Australians each week—including me, I am pleased to say. It provides what we all seek in here—quality broadcasting.

PARA.TAB: Ironically, as I have said, given what the coalition plans for the service, the 1991 success story for SBS was the high rating series Civil War with new audiences reached approximately seven times. The importance of SBS television was perhaps best summed up in a recent article in the Weekend Australian magazine which I commend to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and follows Senator Lees's question yesterday on the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. Is the Minister aware that the President of the TCF Council, Alan Trumble, recently told the independent tariffs inquiry chaired by my colleague Senator Sid Spindler that Chinese textile workers were being paid $20 for a 6-day, 48-hour working week? Given this fact, and also that TCF imports rose 8 per cent in October, is it not becoming blindingly obvious that the reduction of tariffs and the abolition of quotas will expose the Australian TCF industry to competition it cannot hope to match? When will the Government acknowledge that to deliver lower consumer prices by destroying jobs and inflating our debt is totally self-defeating, given that Australians will be forced to pay the price in other ways?

—If Senator Coulter picks up a microcosm of the Australian economy and tries to translate it into a story about employment and so on, I suppose it is an interesting exercise intellectually. However, I am quite well aware of Mr Trumble's view of the world. He does not in that view of the world represent the more aggressive, independent and growing sectors of the textile industry.

PARA.TAB: It is probably quite true that Chinese workers are paid $20 for a 48-hour week. We do not for a moment want to translate that situation here. We have been trying to get the TCF industries to concentrate on the higher value added export sectors of the industries which they can do well. As I said yesterday, while import penetration has risen a bit recently, it is still very low by world standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bit!

—I said that import penetration in these industries—I have to explain everything twice for Senator Crichton-Browne—has risen a bit recently. It is still low by world standards. In the future, these industries have to export more. Their export performance has been abysmal in the past.
—Thanks to you.

—During the 27 years the coalition was in government it exported nothing. It gave them the highest levels of protection in the world. The fact is that their export performance has not been good. As regards restructuring these industries, we want to push them into greater exports. Inevitably, there will be higher levels of imports in the lower value added end of the market. If we go around the world trying to compete with every low labour cost country in particular industries, we will have very real problems.

PARA.TAB: We do not share the coalition's view which is picked up from the `blast from the past' industrialists who are used to high levels of protection and who seek to have those high levels of protection restored. That will not happen under this Government. We will also not go to the absurd levels of the Opposition, which apparently believes in zero tariffs for everything and a level playing field in the international marketplace. That is, of course, quite absurd.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I have two fairly obvious questions. Even at the high end of the market, how long does the Minister estimate it will take before the Chinese make that high cost end of the market and are still paying people $20 a week? Therefore, how long will our industries be able to survive?

—It is a simplistic question to which there is a complex answer. China is already making good quality clothing in some factories. That is because it has had very high levels of investment from Japan, Taiwan and places like that. The question is about producing things here in Australia, which we do well because we have the raw materials or some indigenous design features that we can contribute to clothing. It is also about relationships with the retail sector. We have put a lot of money into improving relationships with the retail sector which now find it more beneficial with `just in time' technology to deal with local manufacturers more than ever in the past. We are pushing that process along.

PARA.TAB: There are lots of costs involved in importing from China. It is not just the price of the goods; it is the price of warehousing, transhipment and the possibilities of shipments not arriving—things like that. These are all factors which this industry has to take into account. When we started on this process, we were five years behind Europe and America in these processes and we are not now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the Government intend to provide greater choice, flexibility and a fair safety net for Australian workers? Is the Minister aware that both he and the Prime Minister have been accused by Premier Kennett of thuggery and criticised by Mr Howard for this policy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first question is yes, and I table the press release of the Prime Minister and myself yesterday announcing the proposed changes. There are in fact two proposals. One is to provide that the existing Industrial Relations Commission Act be amended and that an existing right be expanded so that Victorians have the freedom of choice to choose a fairly determined independent award or a Kennett individual work contract. They have that freedom of choice, and it will be for Victorians to decide whether they wish to access that choice. The constitutional principle is well established.

PARA.TAB: The second proposal is to prescribe a fair safety net on the foundation of a number of conditions. One is to provide that minimum wages can be prescribed by the Industrial Relations Commission in Australia and be a universal fair minimum; another is to provide that equal pay be an enshrined principle; and another is to provide that people cannot be unfairly dealt with at the point of termination of employment.

These are significant and important changes, they add to labour market flexibility, and I and the Government believe that they are valued by all Australians. It is true that we have been attacked for this and that Mr Kennett has called us thugs. The important thing to remember is that Mr Kennett himself promised to move the Victorian industrial relations system to the Commonwealth on the basis that the Commonwealth Government was that of the coalition. He has no objection, therefore, about moving the Victorian industrial relations system to the Commonwealth. However, he wants to continue the reign of the Kennett contract rather than have a fairly determined basic award.

That is where we differ and, if that is where we differ, we are quite prepared to allow Australians to judge us on that. Mr Howard has done something quite extraordinary. He, too, has attacked us for this. On page 6, Jobsback states:

ANSWER.PARA: A future Coalition government will seek complementary legislative action from state and territory governments to achieve the objectives of this policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have ruled with monotonous regularity on this point. Senator Cook knows it and is defying your ruling that he is not to debate Opposition policy, however good it might be.

—Mr President, on the point of order: on this occasion the Opposition has attacked Government policy. It is absolutely appropriate for Senator Cook to be able to elucidate the Opposition's policy to prove—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the coalition had advocated something similar, Senator Cook would have been entitled to refer to it to lessen the credibility of those criticisms.

—Mr President, on the point of order: the question that Senator Cook purports to be addressing is whether he is aware that Mr Kennett has accused Senator Cook and the Prime Minister of thuggery. It has nothing to do with Senator Cook suddenly announcing that something Mr Howard said is quite extraordinary and, therefore, presumably interesting. It is not in any way an answer to the question. It is utterly irrelevant and he ought to be ruled out of order.

—On the point of order, Mr President: if Mr Howard has attacked me, as he has, for the policies I have announced, it is entirely relevant for me to quote from his policy, which shows that he proposes to do exactly the same thing. It may well be very uncomfortable, but Mr Howard has said that he will shift, that he will interfere with State jurisdictions too.

—I rise on the point of order, Mr President. If the Minister is concerned about anything Mr Howard said, he should make a personal explanation at the end of Question Time, not in the middle of Question Time.

—Order! Senator Cook was asked a question on industrial relations that related to Victoria. There was also a reference to a press release, I think, put out by Mr Howard. I ask Senator Cook to answer the question he was asked.
—Mr President, I seek your ruling. The question the Minister was asked was simply: is he aware that Mr Kennett has accused him and the Prime Minister of thuggery?

—On the point of order, Mr President: the question has been rephrased to suit the point of order. The question, as I comprehended it—I believe that the Hansard record will show that this is true—was whether I and the Prime Minister had been accused of thuggery by Mr Kennett and whether the coalition had criticised the measures of the Government. If that is not a precise wording, it is close to my recollection of what was asked. Surely that entitles me to say what Mr Howard's position is, since he is the critic of the Government on this matter.
—Order! I call Senator Cook.
—Jobsback says:

ANSWER.PARA: A future Coalition government will seek complementary legislative action . . . It will, if necessary, use whatever constitutional power is available to it, excluding the external affairs power, to ensure that the benefits of this policy are as widely available as possible to Australians.
Every head of constitutional power the Opposition can use, save the power of external affairs, which enables us to encode fair international labour standards as laid down by the United Nations ILO—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. The results of the Australian Private Hospitals Association audit of the role of private hospitals in Australia's health system, which was released today, shows that a Labor government would have to provide an extra 17,065 public hospital beds per day and another $5.5m per day to achieve Mr Keating's policy directive of getting people to drop their private health insurance because `they don't need it'. Where does the Minister plan to find an extra five million bed days and $2 billion per year when there are already 100,000 Australians who cannot get access to treatment in public hospitals? Also, on what date will the Government's health policy dealing with these matters be released? If the Minister cannot give us a date when the Government's other policies will be released, can he give us a date when its health policy will be released?
—There is no policy of the Federal Government to require people to drop private health insurance.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Ha, ha!

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections from my left. I call Senator Tate.
—Does my time start again, Mr President?
—Yes, Senator Tate; I have called you.

—There is no policy of the Federal Government to require the dropping of private health insurance. We recognise the role of private health insurance, which provides about 10 per cent of the funding for the provision of health and medical services in the Australian community. To put an emphasis on private health insurance as the way in which the funding requirements of the Australian health system into the future will be sustained and supported is quite wrong and ideologically driven.

PARA.TAB: Medicare is supported by seven out of 10 Australians because they know from their experience that it provides a good foundation, without the fear that accompanies the old systems the Opposition harks back to, and the United States system, which it seems to prefer, where private health insurance plays such a major role. Seven out of 10 Australians support Medicare. We support strengthening it by providing $1.6 billion over the next six years in order to strengthen the public health system.

We believe that the public hospital system is the place where Australians are entitled to expect to receive adequate and proper treatment for their medical ailments or those conditions which require surgery, whether it be a chronic illness or the result of some traumatic accident, either on the road or in industry. In these ways we believe that under our Medicare strengthening program, which is not simply confined to strengthening the public hospital system but has many other elements also, the State Ministers for health ought to sit down in good faith around the table with the Federal Minister for Health, Mr Brian Howe, and sign the Medicare agreement that is presently being negotiated.

That is where our policy is, as Senator Knowles well knows. It is wrapped up in the new Medicare agreement, which is well known to all her Liberal colleagues in the State ministries in Australia. I believe that they will sign the agreement because they are full of fear of the alternative the Opposition is offering.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister representing the Treasurer aware of claims that increasing the minimum level of superannuation contributions required by the superannuation guarantee charge from 4 per cent to 5 per cent for employers with national payrolls of $1m or more from 1 January would jeopardise 10,000 jobs and would cost employers $700m? Are these claims correct? Can the Minister explain why the Government believes that it is inappropriate to defer the planned increase in the minimum level of superannuation provided by large employers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Burns was kind enough to give me some notice of this question.
—He is trying to help out the unions, is he?

—Senator Alston, who interjects, is trying to prevent an additional one per cent of superannuation being provided to employees of large employers from 1 January. Senator Alston recently gave an address to the Monash University School of Banking and Finance industry conference. At that conference he claimed:

ANSWER.PARA: The increase from 4 per cent to 5 per cent, due to take effect from 1 January 1993, has been estimated by the Treasury to jeopardise up to 10,000 jobs over the next two years.

Senator Alston spoke with a pimple on his tongue when he told the finance conference that. He knows full well that the Treasury has done no such thing. The Treasury was well aware of the mischief Senator Alston was attempting in Estimates committees with his question, because Treasury did his calculations for him. It said:
The assumption specified in the question is not regarded as realistic.

I have news for Senator Alston. That is Treasury language for `This issue is a load of rubbish'. His suggestions are a load of rubbish. Senator Alston made other claims in his speech about Treasury estimates that are also wrong, but with the time limit imposed I will not deal with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is convenient.

—I thank Senator Kemp for that convenience. Earlier this year the Government said that if the SGC could not be increased without causing inflationary outcomes, the Government would reconsider the scheduled timing of increases in the prescribed minimum standards of superannuation. That is, what we would do in January of next year would depend on the inflation outcome. There is no need to undertake such a reconsideration now. We have the lowest inflation rate in the OECD—it is below the rate of our trading partners—and inflation in 1992-93 is forecast to continue to be lower than the rate of other countries. In so far as the 5 per cent is concerned, with low wage outcomes and low inflation outcomes, the Government is committed to the extension of that extra one per cent in January next year.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support. On 5 June this year he announced an inquiry into the CAA and TAAATS contract. In his press release at the time he forecast that the inquiry would report in six weeks. As it is now 3 December—two days short of exactly six months from the setting up of the inquiry—can the Minister tell the Senate whether he has received the report or when he expects to receive it? Can he give the Senate an assurance that he will table the report before the end of this session?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The facts in that question, as I recall them, are correct. The reason for the delay is that the Senate will recall that at the time the overwhelming concern was that the report be a fair and independent one and have the necessary scope to conclude its inquiry properly. The six weeks we foreshadowed then was an estimate of what we anticipated would be about the time it would take. As it turns out, the report has taken longer than that. The delay has been necessary because the evidence that has come forward has required further and additional inquiry. That should strengthen the report when it is delivered.

PARA.TAB: It is my understanding that the report will be available to me this week—tomorrow—or some time very early next week, maybe a little later, because there are some questions of finalisation. As to the question of whether it is my intention to table the report, I can say to the Senate that I regard it as highly important that the report, when it is completed and available, be tabled as soon as possible, and certainly before the Senate rises for the Christmas adjournment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 72, I ask a question of Senator Alston relating to his notice of motion for the disallowance of the SGC increase. I ask Senator Alston why this matter is urgent, given his recent backflip on the tax deductibility of superannuation? He said that the Government's superannuation policy should not be opposed in the interests of stark policy contrast between the Government and the Opposition. He said that if people do not like the Government's policy they should vote the Government out. Irrespective of what the Democrats decide to do, I ask Senator Alston: surely under the same logic he should allow the SGC increase; or is it one rule for his mates and another rule for the one million Australians who have been disadvantaged in terms of adequate retirement income by his hypocritical decision?

—I appreciate the opportunity to try to sort out the contorted logic of the Democrats. Unfortunately, Senator Kernot's current exercise is all about putting herself forward as the leadership pretender after the next election. That is what it is all about. The tragedy of that is that she is prepared to put up to 10,000 jobs at risk for the sake of getting Senator Coulter's job.

PARA.TAB: The logic of the argument is simply this: if the personal deductions are not allowed to go ahead, they can be restored immediately after the next election, whereas if the 4 per cent is allowed to go to 5 per cent that cannot be restored. Senator Kernot was saying as recently as five weeks ago that Australia could not afford it, that the economy has gone from bad to worse. That is the very reason she was given that opportunity back in July to disallow it—and she is now disregarding her own logic.

If you want a lesson in logic, you should go back to what you said and you will realise that once that has gone through it is irreversible. There is nothing we can do about it. We are stuck with whatever level is in place. If this mob opposite gets back into office, the rate goes to 5 per cent within six months; if we get there, people immediately get the benefit of generous tax concessions. So there is absolutely no logic at all in claiming that somehow there is a difference between the two.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston, address the Chair.

—Thank you, Mr President. I have to say that I thought Senator Kernot was more in need of education on this issue than you. Certainly, when it comes to logic, I do not think we will be able to do justice to her lack of that in the short period available.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Kernot is really going to knock off Senator Coulter in the near future, she will have to do a lot better, not just in terms of logic but in responding to the needs of the 10,000 Australians who want to see businesses stay in the game, who do not want employers' capacity jeopardised by an unnecessary and needless increase, and one that Senator Kernot recognised was totally unnecessary as recently as five weeks ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I point out to Senator Alston that I do happen to be the superannuation spokesperson. Is Senator Alston confirming that he will use these one million Australians so that he can make some sort of cheap political point before the next election? Those opposite will not be there because they have to bail out of their policies now. Let me bring you back to the logic, Senator Alston.
—Order! Senator Kernot, ask the supplementary question.

—Senator Alston, if you are now letting Government superannuation legislation go through, why should you not let the SGC increase go through and let the people of Australia decide that your position is indefensible?
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Where is the supplementary question?
—Order! Senator Kernot, address the Chair in future, too.

—Doing the best I can with what was clearly more a statement than a question, let me say this: if the Democrats are sincerely interested in people having the benefit of tax concessions prior to the next election, it is a very simple proposition to go to the Government and urge it to do it. What infuriates you is that you were hoping to be able to pull off another coup—
—Face the Chair.

—Sorry, Mr President. Senator Kernot was hoping to be able to persuade the Government to give her a bit of a deal on retrospectivity and phasing-in. Senator Kernot has never given us the details on this phasing-in; that is what she was hoping for. If she is fair dinkum, if she wants people to get those concessions, she should go to the Government and ask it and stand up and argue for them. If she does not want people to go out of business altogether, the way she will do that is by blocking the increase from 4 per cent to 5 per cent, as her logic was compelling her to do as recently as five weeks ago and which she now seems to have forgotten entirely in your obsession to get rid of her current Leader.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Will the Minister reconfirm the commitment he gave last evening to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs to be available with departmental and AQIS officers for further questioning on the Prime Minister's pig interests before the Committee reports to the Senate? Will the Minister instruct his Labor Party colleagues on the Committee to honour his commitment and seek to extend the Committee's reporting date if necessary, or is there to be another Government engineered cover up of this scandalous matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries and Energy portfolio came before the Senate Committee last night at 9 o'clock. I understand the Committee sat until 1 o'clock and dealt with all the questions senators had. I left the Committee at 10 o'clock, and I make absolutely no apology for doing so. I have other responsibilities and I intended to—and do—attend to those.

PARA.TAB: I said before I left that I would endeavour to make myself available, and I will endeavour to make myself available. Senator Tambling asked me whether I will instruct my parliamentary colleagues. I have to inform him that the Labor Party is a democratic party. We are not in a position of instructing one another. This may be foreign to the Liberal Party. The Liberal Party may not be familiar with this, and the dictatorial approach of Dr Hewson in threatening the preselections of Liberals who oppose his GST is more typical of Senator Tambling's bunch. We function as a vibrant democracy. I believe that the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Burns, indicated that he too would endeavour to be available, and that should meet the needs of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does the Minister not understand that there is widespread community concern about how the Prime Minister turned $430,000 tenfold into $4.3m as a result of this pig investment? When the Minister walked out of the Standing Committee meeting last evening, did he have any arrangements with Labor members on the Committee with regard to future meetings or the availability of any agreement to frustrate and override future scrutiny? Senator Burns and Senator Sherry stacked the meeting last night and took a decision not to reconsider this issue, in defiance of the Minister's commitment. Is the Minister going to renegotiate with the Committee in order to have the matter reconsidered properly or is he going to cover it up?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are several imputations in that question which are offensive to the dignity of the Senate. But I will

ANSWER.PARA: not rely on that because it will be a condemnation of the asker and not of the people who have to answer. I do not believe there is widespread community concern. Members of the coalition have committed themselves to a smear campaign which is not true and they know it. They are looking for some dignified exit. That dignified exit is to continue to ask the same question with one synonym substituted for another synonym.

PARA.TAB: Last night we saw the same attempt at juvenile cross-examination of officers. We saw ground canvassed that has been canvassed a million times before. This matter has been properly and fully answered. I think members of the Opposition should just fold their tents and melt quietly into the night. They have lost this one. Just give it up; do not make an issue of it. If they do this, people will respect them. But if they try to win something out of what they have lost, they will appear to be what they really are—just foolish.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister confirm the accuracy of reports in the Italian language press that a revised agreement on social security has been concluded between Australia and Italy? If so, in what way have the terms of that agreement been changed?
—Make a statement.

—I do not know what the concern of the Opposition is. Senator Zakharov has asked a very sincere question that directly affects quite a number of people of Italian background living both in Australia and in Italy.

PARA.TAB: Senator Zakharov referred to articles in the Italian press in the last few days or so in respect of the social security agreement between Australia and Italy. The current state of play is that negotiations are being conducted by officials in relation to the revision of the current social security agreement. The negotiations attempt to build on an agreement which has been in operation for some four years and is due for review. As I said, it is a very important agreement for some 40,000 people living in both Australia and Italy.

In terms of the state of negotiations, the negotiators have been looking at options for revision. Those options have been reviewed and developed by officials in negotiations over the last two months. As part of that process, an Italian delegation has been in Australia over the last couple of weeks. I believe that prior to their departure from Australia they spoke to the Italian language press. That press did give details of negotiations. However, reports do not make it clear that the respective governments are still to consider the proposals for a revised agreement.

There is keenness on both sides to finalise the review quickly. There is also keenness to address two major issues—namely, the ambit of the coverage of the agreement as well as the administration. In order to expedite proceedings, the Australian Minister for Social Security will be visiting Rome later this month to discuss ways in which both governments might finalise the review without delay.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is it a fact that there has been an interim tax ruling pursuant to the superannuation guarantee Act so as to include in the calculation of the levy, upon the termination of employment, components of holiday pay, long service leave and some sick leave?
—I am not aware of any such ruling. I would probably be one of the last people to be aware of that. But I will get an answer for the honourable senator as soon as possible.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am surprised at the Minister's answer. The Minister knew a great deal about the superannuation guarantee Act a short time ago when he answered a question from Senator Burns. When the Minister answers the question, will he also tell me whether in fact there has been such a ruling and, if so, how much additional revenue will be raised as a result of it?
—Let me make it clear: I think I understand the principles; I do not make a habit of reading tax rulings every time they come out.
—Broad-brush.
—I have painted the broad-bush man into a corner and I am going to keep doing so. If there are financial implications, I will get that information for the honourable senator.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 October headed `Caesarean rates too high—doctor'. The article points out that not only are the rates of caesarean section increasing but they are much higher for women with private insurance. I ask whether the Minister agrees with Dr Douglas Reid, the State Chairman of the National Association of Specialist Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, who said:

QUESTION.PARA: Because they (the patients) are paying extra money they expect extra service.

Is there any clinical evidence for why privately insured women should have a 50 per cent higher rate of caesarean section? Does the Minister agree with Dr Reid that the co-payment paid by the patient puts pressure on the obstetrician to treat such cases? Is the Government concerned that health insurance status rather than clinical need is determining treatment for patients?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article in the Sydney Morning Herald. It was drawn to my attention yesterday. Might I say that Senator Bolkus has just informed me that a member of his staff, Liz Jakubowski, gave birth to a baby yesterday by caesarean section at Woden Valley Hospital. I would like to send a greeting to Lucy and to her mother.

PARA.TAB: A study has been undertaken by Dr Paul Lancaster, the Director of the National Perinatal Statistics Unit of the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare. In it he has revealed that privately insured women have a 50 per cent higher rate of caesareans than non-insured women. He says that there is no physiological explanation for this. Senator Herron continually says in this chamber that these matters ought to be determined by clinical need alone. I think that is a very important principle. It is of paramount importance to keep this principle before obstetricians who are performing these medical procedures and interventions.

I believe that there is a matter of great concern here. In so far as there appears to be some correlation between a higher incidence of caesarean delivery of babies in the case of women who are privately insured, quite clearly that is a matter for concern by the associations and groups concerned, particularly professional peer groups such as the one represented by Dr Reid, the New South Wales State Chairman of the National Association of Specialists, Obstetricians and Gynaecologists.
Dr Reid did say that we have to look at questions such as foetal distress and so on as the possible reasons. The article states:

The higher caesarean rate of insured patients could be explained by the higher fees they paid, he said. The co-payment (what the patient pays), which could amount to $600 over the rebated amount, put extra pressure on the obstetrician, Dr Reid said.

ANSWER.PARA: If that is an accurate report of what Dr Reid said, it indicates a cause for great concern. I would certainly hope that the professional peer groups of doctors performing such operations and interventions would sit around the table and discuss this matter and this correlation. I think it does need discussion. Clinical reasons alone should determine the undertaking of this sort of operation. Doctors should be fortified in resisting the temptation, which appears to exist, to undertake this sort of operation perhaps for an extra co-payment of $600.

PARA.TAB: I would hope that the correlation does not signify any such yielding to temptation. As I say, I hope that peer group pressure amongst obstetricians and gynaecologists would help to bring those figures back to a more universally accepted rate for the delivery of children in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister elaborate on the last part of my question? To what extent is the Government concerned that health insurance status rather than clinical need is determining treatment for patients? Is there any way in which the Government would want to argue that private health insurance in this case seems to be a risk?

—I certainly believe that some sort of correlation has been revealed between private health insurance and the higher rate of delivery by caesarean section of babies to privately insured women. That is a matter for concern. I have expressed the Government's concern. I believe that this is a matter which is best dealt with by the gynaecologists and obstetricians to ensure that there is a proper clinical reason for that procedure being undertaken.

PARA.TAB: I am only going on the reported comments of Dr Reid. I believe that he is right in suggesting that there are proper clinical reasons. He also says that there is a risk of temptation in relation to the fees that might be available. I believe that that is a matter which needs to be looked at. That is why the Government is concerned about this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Has France yet agreed to the inclusion of agricultural products in the current GATT negotiations? If a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round is reached, when will reforms commence? What will be the benefits of those reforms to the Australian sugar industry?

—In answer to the first question, France agreed back in September 1986 to the inclusion of agriculture in the negotiations. If Senator Boswell is asking whether France has agreed to the inclusion of the agreed results from the Blair House meeting in the United States on 20 November, the answer is that it has not. The current indications are that France is not going to make a separate decision about that or seek to veto that part of the total agreement; it is going to wait until the Round, as a whole, is finally brought to conclusion with all the other heads of negotiation and respond to that.

PARA.TAB: The most recent indication that that will be the French position was a statement by President Mitterrand at a dinner for the King of Belgium on 30 November to the effect that France would only take a position on the Round as a whole and not just on the agricultural component. If that is right, it clearly involves some hope that there will be a repositioning of France so that it is in a position to claim that it is doing better out of the negotiations in the other areas as a whole than it is just in agriculture, and will not pursue it to the point of attempted veto.

Whether or not France can veto it is an open question. The negotiations have been conducted by the Commission on behalf of the EC as a whole, and any purported veto by France would have to rely on procedures that have not really been fully tested: the so-called Luxembourg compromise. We remain generally reasonably optimistic that things are on track for conclusion.

The commencement of the reforms depends, first of all, on the conclusion of the basic heads of agreement for the Round as a whole and then the agreement to the commitments by the particular countries to meet their obligations under those agreements, which has to be concluded by 1 March to meet the US fast-track deadline. Hopefully, it will not take as long as that, but it may. Thereafter, there is a signature and ratification process which could conceivably take us into 1994, but everyone hopes it will be earlier than that that the whole package will come into force. Certainly, some commitments in agriculture will be implemented in line with marketing or fiscal years and will commence at the start of the relevant year—1994—anyway.

As to the impact on the Australian sugar industry, that will benefit, like other agricultural industries, from the reductions in border protection, overall domestic support and export subsidies. Those cuts will benefit all our industries—sugar will be no exception—through the reduction of protectionism and distortions in the international market.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—For the information of honourable senators, I table a letter that I have sent to Brian Johns, Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Authority, following his appointment to that position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by Senator Alston to a question without notice asked by Senator Kernot this day relating to superannuation.

SPEECH.PARA: Despite Senator Alston's hysterical attacks, the Australian Democrats have not yet taken a decision on the superannuation guarantee charge. Unlike the Opposition, we are not locked in to protecting the vested interests of some of our constituents. We wait and examine the merits of the argument. One million Australians are relying on me to expose the hypocrisy of Senator Alston's back flip on the abolition of tax deductibility on personal superannuation policies. They were relying on that deductibility to top up their award superannuation in order to have an adequate retirement income and avoid joining the age pension queue.

PARA.TAB: Senator Alston is taking this decision about the superannuation guarantee charge in isolation from other factors. The key point that he needs to remember is that the decision, whatever it is, will directly impact on other aspects of employment conditions, namely, wage increases. Senator Alston is claiming that the effects of the SGC can be determined separately. He has deliberately misrepresented the Treasury's answer on job losses, just as he and Dr Hewson did back in June when they talked about 100,000 jobs being lost. That has not happened, and he knows it. No-one swallows his misrepresentations on this matter any more.

Senator Alston asked Treasury to do a calculation based on his usual assumption that the increase represents an additional cost to employers. He then said that Treasury acknowledges that 10,000 jobs are at risk. `Garbage in, garbage out', they said last time; `Garbage in, garbage out', it is again this time. That assumption is totally false, and he knows it.

My amendment to the Industrial Relations Act guaranteed that the Industrial Relations Commission would take the superannuation guarantee increase into account. It was my amendment, as the superannuation spokesperson—funny, that! Treasury further stated that, in addition, even in circumstances where wage increases are determined through more centralised arrangements, it is reasonable to assume that total labour costs, including wages and superannuation, will be a guiding consideration. Accordingly, the cost of the SGC is likely to be offset largely, if not fully, by lower growth in other forms of remuneration, especially wages. It may well be that the rejection of this increase in the SGC amount would lead to an increase in total labour costs in an across the board wage claim—costs in excess of that which would otherwise occur under an SGC increase. If that were the case, the action proposed by Senator Alston would create the problem that he has identified, not fix it.

The Democrats are working through these issues with all the parties concerned. When we have made a decision which we think is in the best interests of the country, we will make that decision public. The fact remains that one million Australians will now have a less than adequate retirement income because of the hypocritical back flip that Senator Alston has done on the abolition of tax deductibility on personal superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The tragedy of Senator Kernot's position is that she seeks to claim all the credit when she is only one of seven or eight Australian Democrats, all of whom presumably have a vote and all of whom should be entitled to regard it as a team game. More importantly, Senator Kernot seems hell-bent on blaming the coalition for the removal and phase-down of tax concessions on superannuation contributions. She seems to forget that it is a Government Bill which will remove these concessions, and it is our policy to reinstate concessions after the election.

PARA.TAB: We have not heard anything from Senator Kernot in recent days about urging the Government to reinstate these concessions at least pro tem until the next election. She tells us all this nebulous nonsense about phasing out. She ought to know that the current generation of the work force will get nothing adequate to compensate it for the removal of tax concessions. Any phasing-out would need to take place over a 40-year period. If she is not prepared to spell it out, it is a quite clear that it is a transparent gimmick.

Senator Kernot says that she is assiduously consulting with interest groups. I challenge her to nominate any interest group that is telling her that somehow she ought to let this go from 4 to 5 per cent. They are all of one voice. They all know that, when Senator Kernot sought that amendment in July this year, she did it on the basis that she wanted to reserve the right to knock this off if the economy could not afford it.

That is why a matter of only a few weeks ago Senator Kernot was urging her colleagues and saying that we could not afford it, that it had to go. I challenge her to say whether her colleagues had a party meeting and agreed to knock it off. I suspect that they have already taken that decision.

This morning on the Matthew Abraham show we had a cheap regurgitation of the usual nonsense. The Democrats choose to ignore that Treasury has said—I have said this ad nauseam, but lack of logic seems to extend to lack of capacity to appreciate the facts—that up to 10,000 jobs would be lost if employers were to bear the full burden. Senator Kernot has to know that the Treasurer conceded that there would be job losses; he said they would be negligible. It has been conceded that there would be job losses, but they could not be quantified. Do not somehow pretend that jobs are not at risk. How can this nonsense go on? Treasury has said that up to 10,000 jobs will be lost if employers bear the full burden. It is only a matter of degree—jobs will be lost; there can be no argument about that—yet Senator Kernot's justification seems to be little more than an attempt to retaliate because we have deprived her of another moment of potential glory.

Senator Kernot thought she would be able to pull off a big coup, but we have pulled the rug out on her instead. Hell hath no fury like a Democrat leadership-pretender scorned. It is quite clear that Senator Kernot is not interested in the jobs of 10,000 Australians. She is interested in one job only. That is why the game plan is all too transparent. She is furious that we are giving Australians a real choice—that if they do want tax concessions they can vote for them at the next election. If the Democrats move with the Government, there will not be any. The Democrats will not be able to do their usual grubby little deal because we will not give them the leverage to do it. In other words, their 500 party members around Australia and their 5 per cent of the popular vote will get by them about what they are worth—and that is about five minutes taking note of an answer and not changing legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time has expired.

—There are two central issues in this debate which Senator Alston failed to address in his speech. Those opposite are probably not aware of the gross cynicism which Senator Alston has been engaged in and which, when he says hell hath no fury, will incur the fury of the superannuation industry towards the Opposition and, in particular, Senator Alston. Based on the feedback from the superannuation industry that I have had in the last week towards the back flip by the Opposition, hell certainly hath no fury.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators will find out, if they are not finding out already, exactly what everyone in the superannuation industry thinks about an Opposition that pretends to be suited for government and says that it supports the tax deductibility of superannuation, yet has done a back flip in policy and said that it will in fact vote for the Government's implementation of the ending of tax deductibility and, if it gets back into office, a year or two down the track will reverse exactly what it voted for. The great problem with this approach is that not only is it totally cynical and unprincipled but also it affects many people out in the industry. There are some one million people who are affected by this policy—one million people who will make decisions based on Senator Alston's announcement to end their personal superannuation. It is not exactly easy to reinstate one's policy once one has ended it.

If the Opposition is elected, there will be a lot of angry voters out there who will have to go back and reinstate their personal superannuation policies at very great cost. I am sure Opposition senators will find out what their colleagues who hold personal superannuation think about the Opposition's back flip.

This Government has made clear what it thinks of the tax deductibility of superannuation. We will introduce a rebate. The public at large knows our policy and respects the position. Many people do not agree with it, but they certainly do not respect the Opposition's new position. In fact, I said to Senator Alston the other day that the position of the Opposition is so cynical it reminds me of a group of revolutionary leaders who said to their people, who were being massacred by the leadership of the country, `Let them be massacred because it helps increase the wrath against the ruling class'. It is so cynical in its approach. That is the sort of attitude that Senator Alston has to this issue.

The Opposition believes in a failed, discredited policy. It believes that people will save for their retirement based on tax incentives. It is a failed policy. It is a policy that has been rejected everywhere in the world. The Select Committee on Superannuation surveyed 23 countries. Of those 23 countries, every country except New Zealand has compulsory levels of superannuation of 9 to 13 per cent. It is compulsory because it is the only way people will save; they will not save for their retirement based on tax incentives. It is a failed policy. What those opposite have done is very cynical, as they will find out when the voters reject them at the election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you be addressing the same debate?
—Yes.
—I call Senator Coulter.
—Very briefly, Mr President—
—Why is Senator Kernot going around the gallery telling them she is after your job?
—When the Prime Minister—
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Alston has just made an offensive assertion about my motives in this issue. I ask him to withdraw it.
—Do you deny it?
—I do.

—Order! I am in the position here where the Clerk and I were discussing what time the debate ended. I did not hear the remark. Senator Alston, if you made an unparliamentary remark, you should withdraw it.
—I did not, Mr President.
—Senator Kernot has the right to make a personal explanation later.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have called Senator Coulter after Senator Kernot. There are many more members of the Liberal and National parties wanting to speak on this. Because the Democrats sided with the Government to restrict this debating time to half an hour, I wonder what your ruling is that gives the Democrats two opportunities in this debate when there are only seven of them and 34 Liberal-National Party senators and we will not have the opportunity to enter this debate.

—Order! That is one of the reasons why I was checking the time. I called Senator Kernot, a Democrat; I called a member of the Government; I have called the Leader of the Democrats now; and I will call at least two Opposition senators.

—As I recall, Mr President, you also asked whether I would be addressing the same point and there were two shaking heads over there. They should all be shaking their heads in shame actually. The simple point I make is that when the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) did his back flip on the GST, having decided that the GST was a vile tax which would visit all sorts of terrible things on the Australian public, he said, `Nonetheless, if the coalition is voted into government, we will support it'. We described that as a grubby act by the Prime Minister. Clearly, the Opposition thought it was very clever. We have just heard from Senator Alston his motivation in this whole thing. He said that we were concerned that he had brought off a clever coup. He does not give a damn about the million people out there who will be severely disadvantaged. All he wants to do is bring off a clever coup—and he said as much. I want to get absolutely clearly on the record that that is his motivation and he does not care one little bit, one jot, about the effects he is having on people out there in the community.

—I wish to make two brief comments. First, I draw attention to the astonishing contribution from Senator Sherry. We had four minutes of undiluted spleen attacking the Opposition for voting with the Government. On and on the abuse came pouring out of Senator Sherry because the coalition is voting with the Government.

PARA.TAB: In the 92 years of this Senate, I would defy anyone to go through Hansard and pick out either a member of the government or opposition viciously attacking the other side for choosing to vote with them. We agree with Senator Sherry that it is a bad policy. But it is the Government's policy, the Government decided to bung it through and the Government will have to cop the flak. While Senator Sherry was speaking about cynicism and all that sort of stuff, I reflected upon Mr Keating's comments that the Labor Party would support the GST when it came to the Senate. At the next Labor Party room meeting will Senator Sherry vent similar spleen on the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)? I doubt it, to be quite frank.

My second point concerns Senator Kernot's comments. If the lift in the superannuation levy has no effect on unemployment, why not double it? Why not treble it? The answer is that it does, and Senator Kernot knows that. Once again, when the Democrats are put to the test, they do not care about jobs.

We have had Senator Spindler and Senator Coulter in this chamber today worrying about jobs in particular industries, while at the very same time the Democrats are proposing to add an additional tax to that industry. Senator Kernot spoke about people showing a degree of hypocrisy. She should look closely at herself.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Crowley this day relating to private health insurance.
