SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, you will recall that in relation to caesarian sections Senator Crowley wished to draw some tenuous correlation between private insurance and co-payment. Somehow or another she tried to get Senator Tate to condemn that as a circumstance.

PARA.TAB: It was quite obvious from both the question by Senator Crowley and the answer by Senator Tate that neither has the faintest idea of anything about caesarian section rates, the significance thereof and the correlation with private insurance. For example, there is a much higher rate of private insurance among young married women than there is in their cohort group of single women because they wish to have their babies under the best possible circumstances—that is, in a private hospital with an obstetrician of choice, which is our policy. There is also a correlation between the fact that with the later marriage age of young women there is a greater risk of pregnancy in females over the age of 30 having their first child, so that there is a higher caesarian rate among young women now than there was perhaps 10 or 15 years ago.

The other point that should be made is that patient request comes into this aspect. That patient request is totally unavailable under the Medicare system because women go into public hospitals, are treated by registrars in training, and are not controlled by consultant obstetricians as occurs in the private system. The consultant obstetrician is called in if an emergency occurs.

This Government has also promoted home birthing and a higher rate for midwives. During the Estimates hearings I asked for this to be monitored because the effect of the higher caesarian rate in recent years has been a consequent decrease in the number of damaged babies. The incidence of spasticity among children is lower, which correlates with the higher increase of caesarian sections. Caesarian sections are done to save the baby from damage when prolonged labour occurs. It is just cheap politics to try to draw some tenuous correlation between co-payment and the insurance rate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't forget the doctor who raised it.

—The doctor who raised it has not practised for 20 years, and that is the point. She has not been around and she really does not understand what she is talking about to draw that out. I suggest that she should get back out there in the real world, find out what is occurring in medicine today and not hark back to when she graduated and practised in some women's health centre, whenever it was in ancient history.

—This is an issue in which I take a great deal of interest and concern as a registered midwife and someone who has received many caesarian section babies following their delivery. I can say that the caesarian section rate—the intervention rate in pregnancies—in privately insured women is much greater than in those who are not privately insured.

PARA.TAB: I would also suggest that caesarian sections are done for social reasons. I have yet to have my thoughts and knowledge dispelled by anybody. This is an issue that has been raging for many years. One has only to look at particular figures for procedures in this area to know that it is very dependent upon which particular doctors are doing those procedures to know that there is a greater rate of intervention in certain areas, with certain people and certain rates of private health insurance cover.

It is an issue that deserves to be looked at very closely. I greatly resent the assertion that those who have their children in large teaching public hospitals do not receive the best medical care available for those women and their children. I find that aspersion most offensive. As someone who has worked all of her time in public teaching hospitals as far as obstetrics is concerned, I am certainly aware that the standard of health care provided for those women and children is nothing short of the best available.

Part of the hippocratic oath that both doctors and nurses take is to provide the best service possible for one's patient, not to harm that patient in any way and to follow procedures totally irrespective of health insurance cover. The standard of obstetric care in the public teaching hospitals in this country is internationally recognised as of the highest standard.

I reject any of these allegations and aspersions. It is appalling to try to frighten these women who are unable to afford private health insurance. That applies particularly to what happened under the previous coalition government where several million women could not afford private health insurance but were forced out of private health insurance and not given adequate health cover. Under the Labor Government, these women are able to have health cover to provide care for them and their babies when they need it, as required on medical grounds. That is the way that it should be.

It is alarming that there is a high incidence of caesarian section—intervention—in obstetrics in those who have private health insurance. Anyone who says otherwise is either not looking at the facts or has not practised in the field.

TALK.START.PARA: —I stand to support exactly what Senator Herron said. I found Senator Crowley's proposition obscene—that certain doctors are conducting themselves in a very improper, unprofessional way and performing caesarian sections that are not required. I speak with some modest experience. My four children have all been born by way of caesarian sections. As a result of my wife having a placenta previa, if she had not had the caesarian section, she would have died and we would have lost the baby. On the second occasion, a caesarian section was required to save both her life and the life of the baby. Subsequently, there was no question of her giving birth in any other way.

PARA.TAB: The bottom line is that she happened to have a specialist obstetrician of the type that Senator Herron referred to and she happened to have been a private patient. If she had had neither, I would have been mighty anxious for her health.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day relating unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: About a fortnight ago the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) stood up in the House of Representatives and talked about the majesty of the democratic process. What has happened to respect for democracy in Victoria at the moment on the part of this Government? Victorians overwhelmingly elected the Kennett Government to do something about the disastrous state of the Victorian economy, and what has Mr Keating done? He has done everything possible to thwart Mr Kennett in addressing those major difficulties. He did it firstly by, in effect, endorsing the mass strike action in Victoria, which only added to unemployment and created further economic difficulty in that State, and then, when that became politically difficult, he sought to resort to the legislative process and do it by means of legislation. As I said, the electors of Victoria voted overwhelmingly for a coalition government to give Victoria another chance—to do something about the situation I mentioned in my question to Senator Button; that is, an unemployment rate of 11.8 per cent, a debt of over $30 billion, a Budget blow-out of some $2.2 billion, the loss of the State Bank of Victoria and the loss of the Pyramid Building Society.

PARA.TAB: Mr Kennett and the Victorian State Government, as elected, should be given the opportunity to have a go. But this Government will not let them have a go. This is all because they fear that Mr Kennett threatens the vested interests of Labor's union leadership mates. That is what it is all about. It is about provisions to abolish compulsory unionism—provisions that will give workers a real choice for the first time. These are the provisions that this Government cannot cope with; these are the provisions that it is terrified will be implemented after the next election. So it now seeks to thwart that program by legislative means.

The tragedy is that, while this Government seeks to interfere in the Victorian democratic process, it is not facing up to its own responsibility in relation to its economic mess—a tragedy in this country whereby we have a million Australians out of work and disastrous economic figures coming in practically every day. Earlier this week the current account blew out again. The growth figures are down to a level where they will not even sustain the current rate of employment.

That is what this Government should be facing up to. That is what I asked this Government about. I asked what it will do about a foreign debt for this country that is now, for the first time, over $200 billion gross. Senator Button was asked this question every day this week and on no day was he prepared to give us an answer. We have said to Senator Button and the Government, `When will you produce policies to address this major crisis facing Australia?'. And he will not answer that. The only logical thing that follows from that is that this Labor Government is planning to go to the people on the basis of its record. It offers no change of policy direction. Its record, as I said, is an economic disaster—a million Australians out of work, debt up to the highest levels ever—

TALK.START.PARA: —And he smirks about it.

—Yes, he smirks about it. This Government will not face up to its responsibilities. If ever these statistics called for a change of direction, they do today. This Government offers no change of direction. Even Senator Button said on the cyclical recovery that we will not get back to the previous levels of employment. It is not good enough.

—I want to make the point that the same problem is happening in Tasmania today. We are having a so-called day of action—inaction, in fact. A general strike has been brought on in Tasmania by the trade union movement at a time when we have 30 per cent of our young people out of work and an unemployment rate of 12.2 per cent. In Tasmania the same thing has happened as has happened in Victoria. We have a Liberal government elected by the people, and we have the trade unions trying to take over the role of opposition—and to do so in a bludgeoning way.

PARA.TAB: The greatest joke, if one can call it a joke, is that our teachers are on strike today—the first time in history that our schools have been shut by the action of trade unionists—four days after they were granted salary increases of between $4,000 and $7,000 a year. Is that not absolute lunacy? It just shows the state that this country is in.

We on this side of the chamber have been criticised for our Fightback policies, but I tell you what: when one looks at the Fightback policies and sees just what the abolition of payroll tax would do in the State of Tasmania, one finds that it would create 3,700 jobs—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion relating to the appearance of officers at the hearings of Estimates Committee B on Friday, 4 December 1992.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate requires that officers of the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance appear at the hearings of Estimates Committee B on Friday, 4 December 1992 for the committee's consideration of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1992 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate will recall that it recently debated Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) to the end of the second reading stage, at which point it was agreed a couple of days ago that the Appropriations that are the subject of those Bills be referred to Estimates Committee B. Honourable senators will recall that it was the coalition's proposal that the appropriations be referred to a range of Estimates committees—those committees being the ones corresponding to the departments for the respective appropriations in those Bills; that is, Estimates Committees B, C, E and F.

PARA.TAB: The coalition was frustrated in its attempt to have those four Senate committees meet because the Democrats and the Government did a deal on the matter. In the end it was agreed, by the Government and the Democrats, that only one Estimates committee would consider these appropriations, that that would be Estimates Committee B, and that officers of the other four departments—that is, the Departments of Employment, Education and Training, Transport and Communications, the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories and Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs—would come and appear at the hearings of that Committee which would meet tomorrow. Honourable senators may recall that we wanted those Estimates committees to meet today, but, again, the Government and the Democrats did a deal to refuse that and instead Estimates Committee B is meeting tomorrow.

We then had a meeting of Estimates Committee B, of which I am a member. At that meeting it was agreed that we would call officers of those four departments before Estimates Committee B and also officers of the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance. After all, it was the Government and the Democrats who chose Estimates Committee B as the vehicle for the consideration of the Appropriations. Whilst one might have argued that that was somewhat unusual, it was logical in the sense that these are Appropriations Bills, and Appropriation Bills are brought to the Parliament by the Minister for Finance. So that is appropriate. It is also appropriate in relation to Estimates Committee B because the Appropriations relate to a reordering of the Government's spending priorities. That, therefore, is a matter of importance in relation to the consideration of economic policy. I will come back to that in a moment.

So the meeting of Estimates Committee B to plan tomorrow's hearing agreed that officers of the six departments—Treasury, Finance, Transport and Communications, Employment, Education and Training, Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories—would appear. We worked on that basis until yesterday afternoon, when I was advised by Senator McMullan that the Government had decreed that no officers of the Department of the Treasury or the Department of Finance would be allowed to appear before Estimates Committee B, which is the Treasury and Finance estimates committee, because there were no specific appropriations for those two departments contained in Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4).

I objected very strongly to Senator McMullan about that. He stuck to his guns. I then consulted, in due and proper process, with the Australian Democrats. I put that matter to them late yesterday and said that I hoped they would consider at their party meeting this morning the impropriety of what Senator McMullan was proposing and that they would join me in supporting the motion I have moved, whereby the Senate would require the officers of those departments to appear before Estimates Committee B. We need a resolution of the Senate because the Estimates committees do not have power to call witnesses.

I welcomed the call from the Democrat Whip this morning at 9.45 a.m. She came to see me in the chamber and said that the Democrats had had their usual party meeting that morning and that they would be supporting the motion I have just moved. I thanked her for that, because it was the sensible and proper thing for the Democrats to have done. Three hours later, at 12.45 a.m., I was rung again by the Democrat Whip, who said—in a very apologetic tone, I must acknowledge—that sorry, but that arrangement was no longer on; the Democrats had now had another meeting and they had decided that they would not be supporting the motion I have now moved.

I asked the Democrat Whip what the reason was for that absolute reversal and complete breaking of an undertaking that they had given me for the coalition this morning. She said, `There was not a full complement of Democrats at our party meeting this morning. We thought it was okay; that party meeting agreed. But then, when we had a second meeting for the morning, there were more Democrats there and the decision went the other way'. I said to the Whip, `You may not tell me how many members there were at each meeting, but was the Leader of the Democrats, Senator Coulter, at both meetings?' `Yes', said the Whip, `the Leader of the Democrats was at both meetings'.

Two things might have happened. It is certainly one or other, but I would assume that it is both. The first scenario is that at the first meeting of the Democrats this morning, with the Leader of the Democrats present, they took a very sensible decision to support this motion—a right and proper decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the next meeting he got rolled.

—Yes. The Leader of the Democrats again got rolled because a couple of others turned up and the numbers changed. It reinforces the fracas that took place during Question Time and after Question Time today between Senator Kernot and Senator Alston. It is obvious that Senator Coulter's leadership is at great peril within the Democrats. He cannot support his own numbers. For a leader of a party to get rolled on an issue like this I find absolutely incredible. I do not wish to offer any gratuitous advice to Senator Coulter but, if I were offering gratuitous advice, I would say, `Resign, before you get rolled as leader'. I find it absolutely disgraceful that in a set of parliamentary processes where we have to work on the understandings that we give each other as parties, no-one can any longer—if they ever were able to; today is confirmation par excellence—trust, take any account of, or place any weight on undertakings given to us by the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: I do not know whether the Government finds the same problem as we do. I rather fancy not, because the second and only other reason that I can surmise for this change in the Democrats' view today is that between half past nine this morning and half past twelve today the Democrats were nobbled again by the Government. I want to know, and I will ask Senator Coulter through you, Mr Acting Deputy President: what sleazy deal have the Democrats done this time with the Government to cause them to roll over again and again to meet the Government's wishes? I repeat: I think it is an absolute disgrace.

It is a very serious matter indeed because these Appropriations involve a significant reallocation of the Government's spending priorities. We have only just finished in this chamber going through a very lengthy, tortuous and detailed consideration of the Government's Budget Bills in the form of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2). We went through a very lengthy and exhaustive Estimates process to reach satisfaction on those Bills before they were passed. Before the ink has dried on those Bills, we now have two new Appropriation Bills introduced into the Senate which significantly change some of the Government's major programs.

The One Nation statement in February this year was the basis on which the Government said it was going to really get this economy going, and look what has happened since. It has gone more and more into the mire, with another 100,000 people or so unemployed since that One Nation statement that was going to solve our economic problems. One of the major programs of the One Nation statement was in the area of infrastructure reform. Within that component of infrastructure reform, rail expenditure and so-called rail reform was going to be a key part.

In Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2), which we have just passed, something like $280m was allocated for rail infrastructure spending this financial year. Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) reallocate that expenditure, decimate it, cut it down by $150m—from $280m to something like $130m. They defer $100m of that into the never never of next year and say, `Well, we might be lucky and have the remaining $50m, which is totally unaccounted for at this stage, a couple of years down the track'. That is a major change in the Government's capital spending infrastructure reform proposal.

The Government talks about micro-economic reform being a critical element of its program, although the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) then tells us that the reform program is pretty well over; it cannot do much more. Senator Button has said the same. Nevertheless, in the same breath they have a One Nation statement and a Budget statement spending all this money—which the Parliament approved; we were asked to approve it and we considered it in Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No 2). We are now told, `No, we really cannot spend that money. We can only spend $130m of it. Let's shove the rest off to next year and in the meantime we will spend that $150m on a whole lot of other things, including a range of mickey mouse expenditure programs this year'.

That is a very important change in the Government's economic policy. It is, therefore, essential that, if the Appropriation Bills are to be properly considered by an Estimates committee, there must be economic policy officials present to answer questions and to participate in the Estimates committee consideration. The Government has decreed that that cannot happen.

The Department of Finance officials are also very important because it is the Department of Finance that produces and prepares the Appropriation Bills. It is the Minister for Finance who brings these Bills to the Parliament. Yet the Democrats and the Government say that officials from that responsible Minister's Department will not be permitted to have any questions put to them by this Senate.There are very important issues which should be put to the Department of Finance in relation to these Appropriation Bills. Apparently, we will be denied, because of this turnaround by the Democrats, the opportunity to have that happen.

I will conclude on this note because I do not want too lengthy a debate on this matter, although there has to be a debate on it as it is a very important matter. This is not a small, technical matter. I believe that, for the Senate to be not permitted to undertake its proper process of examination of the appropriations, as appears will be the case, is a very serious issue for the whole relationship between the Executive and the Parliament, and for the rights and responsibilities of this Parliament to exercise its proper role of efficient and effective scrutiny of government expenditure, government programs and the Government's overall policy thrust.

I say this because I do not know whether it is too late for the Democrats to change their view yet again on this matter. I do urge them to reconsider their action. If they do not, they are being made a party to an arrangement at the Government's behest that will lead to a major denigration of the responsibilities and proper processes of this Parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —The one thing on which I agree with Senator Short is that this is a serious question. It is a matter worthy of serious consideration. I think it is a great pity that Senator Short undertook to debate this in the way he did, but that is a matter for him and for his judgment, and he has to live with it. I do not think he did the subject any credit at all. For example, at no stage did he refer to the text of the resolution, to the Standing Orders of the Senate, to the terms of the debate about the motion that was carried, or to Odgers, to indicate how such a matter would normally be pursued.

PARA.TAB: It is no secret that the Government and I were not happy about the original motion to refer Appropriation Bills (No. 3) and (No. 4) to the Estimates Committee. That is no secret; I made it very clear on behalf of the Government, as did Senator Ray and Senator Button subsequently. But we accepted the decision of the Senate; it was within its powers, it was properly made, and we came to an agreement about the terms of the motion.

We accept that decision, and we will cooperate in full with that decision. We will cooperate to the letter of the decision, and in the spirit of the way in which Estimates committees, in the ordinary course of events, conduct their review of the appropriations. We will cooperate, with some significant inconvenience, because that is the resolution of the Senate. The officers of every department for which there is an appropriation will be present to answer all questions about every element of the programs to go before the Committee and, for so long as it takes, we will be there ready to deal with it, although under some protest, perhaps.

But let us look at the text of the motion, first of all, to see whether it is appropriate to add gratuitously, if I may use that word, two departments to which the legislation which we are referring to this Committee does not refer; that is, Treasury and Finance. The Bills are being referred to an Estimates committee, so first of all we know we are dealing with the Standing Orders of the Parliament as they relate to Estimates committees—not to any other aspect of the Standing Orders, not to any wish list, but to those Standing Orders. To make that more clear, part 2 of the motion says:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee should consider the proposed expenditure contained in the Bills in the same manner as the committee considered the particulars of proposed expenditure referred on 20 August.
That reiterates what we are dealing with. It is the orthodox procedure of Estimates committees pursuant to the Standing Orders and precedents of this Senate. That is an important issue.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short, in moving the motion, said that these should be dealt with through the normal Estimates process of considering these appropriations; that it will be in accordance with the normal, proper processes of the Senate. That is what Senator Short said in moving the motion. That sets the context. Let us look at what the Standing Orders say about the way in which an Estimates committee should deal with these matters. I refer to standing order 26, subclauses (12) and (13), which relate to Estimates committees:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) When a Committee considers the estimates, the Chairman shall, without motion, call on items of expenditure in the order decided upon and declare the proposed expenditure open for examination.
(13) The Committees may ask for explanations from Ministers of State in the Senate, or officers, relating to the items of proposed expenditure.

That is what the Standing Orders of the Senate say about the way in which Estimates committees should deal with the items we have before us. What does this legislation that we have referred to that Committee deal with? It deals with appropriations, items of expenditure, for five departments—the Department of Administrative Services, the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the Department of Transport and Communications.

PARA.TAB: The proper role for the Chairman will be to go through those departments in the agreed order and to say that the items of expenditure are open for examination. There is nothing about a general review of what might be the context in which this took place. When we deal with such appropriations in the normal Estimates process, that does not take place. The Chairman does not say, `We are dealing with the Department of Administrative Services, but would anybody like to ask a question about the background economic circumstances?'. That is not what the Standing Orders say, or what the precedents of the Parliament say; nor is it implied by the debate in this chamber on this motion; nor is it implied by the wording of the motion.

The motion quite clearly says that we want these items of expenditure relating to these five departments referred to a Senate Estimates committee for consideration in accordance with the normal processes of the Senate. The normal processes of the Senate are clear: items of expenditure shall be called on item by item. In this instance it will be department by department, as it always is—exactly in accordance with normal procedures. Odgers at page 648 makes that clear. In making a point about the capacity of people to ask questions of officers, which is an important power of an Estimates committee, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: An important feature of the Estimates Committees as agreed upon by the Senate is that the committees may ask for explanations from Ministers of State in the Senate, or departmental officers, relating to the items of proposed expenditure.

It is quite clear. It is not a committee of inquiry, a legislative or general purpose committee, or a select committee having some special brief to review the economic situation in Australia: it is an Estimates committee. The brief, the origins, the Standing Orders, the precedents and the resolutions of this chamber make it absolutely clear that the Estimates committees have an important and proper function to discharge, that is, to review the expenditure. But it is not and never has been their brief to review issues about which there are no items of expenditure.

PARA.TAB: It is similar to a circumstance arising in supplementary appropriations; where there are no appropriations for a department, there would be no Estimates committee scrutiny. That is the normal course of events. Where there is a running cost appropriation, we allow wide-ranging review in Supplementary Estimates. I have some views about whether that is appropriate, but it is the tradition and we would apply that.

That is not the case we are dealing with here. There are five departments for which there are items of expenditure and the only thing which the Standing Orders allows is for those items of expenditure to be reviewed department by department. A Minister—or in this instance, in accordance with our Standing Orders, a Parliamentary Secretary, I regret to say—and the officers from the departments, one by one, will come in the order determined by the Committee to deal with those items of expenditure for so long as the Opposition wishes and in whatever manner it wishes in accordance with the Standing Orders.

The Opposition found out that suddenly it could not have the witch-hunt it wanted because the Standing Orders do not allow it, the resolution of the Parliament does not allow it and the precedents as reflected in Odgers do not allow it. In fact, the whole tenor of the Opposition's resolution does not suggest that that is what should take place, nor the manner in which the Opposition debated it. The Government did not like the resolution, but we will comply with it. Those opposite did not like the resolution, so they are trying to change it.

The fact of the matter is that the normal Estimates committee process has been decided upon and the normal Estimates committee process should proceed. If we are going to review this by committee—I wish we were not, but I accept it may save time when we come back to the Committee of the Whole; it is not the way I would have done it, but we may do that—let us do it in accordance with the Standing Orders. We cannot just pull out of the air something that we would like to do. There is a proper process and we will comply with it, not only the letter, but also the spirit. That is what is called for. That is what we are doing. It is exactly in accordance with the Standing Orders and exactly in accordance with the procedures. It is exactly in accordance with the resolution of this Senate. We will comply with it.

The Opposition does not like it, so it wants to change the terms of reference. It is quite clear that what we are proposing to do is entirely proper and entirely in accordance with the traditions, precedents and Standing Orders of the Senate. That is why we are opposing the Opposition's motion on this occasion and why we will oppose a similar motion on every other occasion when the Opposition might move one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot believe what is occurring in the Senate today. Senator McMullan and Senator Coulter were both here when we debated this on Tuesday. I will read what occurred. Senator Short began by saying that these Bills represent a reallocation of considerable amounts of money which had earlier been appropriated in Appropriation Bills (No. 1) and (No. 2). Senator Short went on to state that the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) made the announcement that formed the basis of Appropriation Bills (No. 3) and (No. 4) that were before the Senate. The Senate had passed Appropriation Bills (No. 1) and (No. 2) and the Estimates committees had gone through their normal processes.

PARA.TAB: The legislation had been passed, but the Government wanted to change the allocation of the money and so it changed it around and brought it up in different allocations. The Senate Estimates committees had already scrutinised that money for the purposes for which it was originally allocated. The Government wanted that changed. Senator Short was justified in saying, `Fine. If you are going to change the money around for different expenditure, then the Estimates committees should be able to look at it'. Under our amendment three different Estimates committees were to be involved, Estimates committees C, E and F.
Then the Government decided to move an amendment. This was not our amendment; it was the Government's amendment. Senator Ray moved the following amendment:
That these Bills be referred to Estimates Committee B for consideration and report by 8 December 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: Why Estimates Committee B? Can Senator Coulter answer that question? Can Senator McMullan answer that question? It was an amendment from his Government. It was not the Opposition's amendment; it was the Government's. Senator Ray went on to say:
. . . `That Estimates Committee B only consider proposed expenditure contained in the Bills in the same manner' and then it flows on into Senator Short's motion.

We were very happy to meet on Thursday and Senator Coulter changed it to Friday in his amendment. We agreed with Senator Coulter's amendment. After Senator Button made a promise that we would also—not instead of, but also—be able to call Estimates committees C, E and F, Senator Coulter decided to agree with the Government. That meant that Estimates committees B, C, E and F would be involved. I am sure that Senator Coulter will not deny this: it was the decision of the Senate that Estimates Committee B would sit, and Senator Coulter only agreed with the Government as long as Estimates Committees C, E and F could sit as well.

PARA.TAB: Argument ensued because Senator Button said that we could have members, as well as the officers, of Estimates committees C, E and F. Not only could we have the officers and the membership of Estimates Committee B, but also the Opposition could call its membership of Estimates committees C, E and F as well. I asked about numbers and voting powers; he would not allow that and Senator Coulter joined him in that regard. At no stage in the Senate in this agreement was it ever said that the officers of Estimates Committee B could not be called. There was no indication at all that the Government would not allow these officers to attend. Why did the Government choose Estimates Committee B, if it will not allow the officers to be called? Why did Senator Coulter agree to Estimates Committee B, if no officers are to be called?

Following that decision in the Senate, a private meeting of Estimates Committee B members was called. Senator Burns and Senator Devereux were there and the decision of that Estimates Committee was that the officers of Estimates committees B, C, E and F be called. Under what power do the Government and the Democrats now override the decision of Estimates Committee B? Madam Acting Deputy President, can you seek the power under which they could possibly override the decision of the private meeting of Estimates Committee B that its officers should be called?

I am not sure whether Senator Coulter will change his mind. The position in this Senate on Tuesday was that he agreed with the Government that Estimates Committee B be called, and he agreed only on the condition that we could also call Estimates committees C, E and F. I cannot begin to understand why the Democrats would go back on their word and the decision made in the Senate. Let us leave out the fact that they agreed with us that that was the decision they had reached; that they rang Senator Short this morning to say that they would go along with that because that was the decision they made; and that, a bit later in the day, they rang and changed their minds.

The decision of this Senate can only be overruled under certain circumstances; we have to go through those procedures before a decision of this Senate can be overruled. Madam Acting Deputy President, I am interested to find out what procedures we must go through to have a decision of the Senate overruled and a decision of Estimates Committee B overruled also, because in essence that is exactly what is occurring in the Senate at the moment. I am very concerned that the decisions of the Senate are being fiddled with, the Government and the Democrats having got together and decided that a decision, rightfully taken in this place on Tuesday, is going to be altered.

TALK.START.PARA: —It must be extremely difficult for the Opposition to understand the way the Democrats work. It is certainly impossible to understand the way the Opposition's mind works. At the same time, it is also clear that it must be very given to conspiracy, status seeking and climbing up the greasy pole because it seems to be very concerned about leadership and everything else.

PARA.TAB: I inform the Opposition, if it did not know it beforehand, that the Democrats have a very open democratic system. That is why we call ourselves the Democrats. After the next election, there will automatically be a vote of all members of the Party to decide who will be the leader. All the Democrat senators willingly participate in that process. We are not here to seek status and to climb up that greasy pole; we are here to address as well as we can the substantive business of government.

It is interesting that Senator Short, having said that he would not speak for very long, spoke for 10 minutes before he got onto the substantive issue and spent all of that 10 minutes denigrating the Democrats. In the course of his remarks, he said that he had negotiated with the Democrats in relation to our position on this motion. He understood that a certain position had been reached but that when we changed our minds that was some sort of a deal which we had struck with the Government. How devious and distorted are the minds of Opposition members when they can say things like that: on the one hand, if we negotiate with them, they are negotiations; on the other hand, if we enter into negotiations with the Government and we are persuaded otherwise, somehow that is a deal. It is not anything different from the processes by which we deal with the Opposition. We look at every issue on its merits, and that is precisely what we did in this case.

When we had our meeting earlier this morning not all the Democrat senators were present. It is fair to say that in the mind of every single Democrat senator there were merits on both sides of this argument. Nobody felt particularly strongly about whether this motion should or should not be supported. It would be fair to say—I think this should be put on the record—that on balance and on the merits of the case we were persuaded at that earlier meeting that the Government had the best side of the argument; but, knowing full well that the Opposition would distort our position whatever we did, we were somewhat persuaded by the politics of it—and we needed to take into consideration the fact that the Opposition would quite wilfully distort the position if we chose a different course.

When we met later in the morning and considered the matter again we decided that we should, in all honesty, decide the issue on its merits and we should not be persuaded by the sorts of distortion which we know full well the Opposition will engage in—it will go its hardest anyway, so we might just as well look at the merits of the case.

The merits of the case have already been pointed out. We certainly, as a matter of principle, do not want to frustrate the proper inquiry which surrounds the introduction of legislation under the rubric of the Appropriation Bills, whether they be No. 1, No. 2, No. 3 or No. 4. When we were debating this issue the other day we were persuaded that the offer by the Government to put these matters before Estimates Committee B, with the provision of officers who were relevant to the consideration, was an adequate way of discharging that responsibility. We are still persuaded to that point of view.

Having looked specifically at the sorts of officers required, in light of what is actually in Appropriation Bills No. 3 and No. 4 and given that questions in Estimates are essentially asked of Ministers and Ministers can seek advice from all sorts of other sources, we still think that the offer being made by the Government in this respect is quite adequate to discharge the appropriate function of the Estimates Committee to look at this reallocation of money and to then bring that consideration back when Appropriation Bills No. 3 and No. 4 are considered in the chamber. Accordingly, we are not persuaded that Senator Short's motion should be supported.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Short's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Motion (by Senator Collins)—by leave—agreed to:

That Senator Hill and Senator Teague be discharged from attendance on Estimates Committees B for the consideration of Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1992-93 and Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1992-93 and that Senator Chapman and Senator Tierney, having been duly nominated in accordance with standing order 26, be appointed members of the Committee for that purpose.
