DEBATE.TITLE: ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION BILL 1992ENDANGERED SPECIES PROTECTION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Order! The Committee is considering amendment No. 14 of the Australian Democrats moved by Senator Coulter.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee determined just before the break that this amendment would now be in two parts. I indicated to the Committee that the Government will not be supporting what is now amendment No. 14—that is, the insertion of the proposed new clause 24A. As I said, the Government believes that this is a totally unwelcome restraint on the Minister's discretion and that, indeed, procedures are available—if the Minister were in fact of a mind to accept the recommendation—to the Minister to allow the Minister to move very swiftly if the kind of action pointed out by Senator Coulter were to occur.

PARA.TAB: I foreshadow that the Government will be supporting at least the thrust of what is now Democrat amendment No. 14A, which provides for the insertion of new clause 24B, with the slight amendment of removing the reference to schedule 3A and returning that to the original schedule 3. As I said earlier in debate on another clause, the Government does not support the addition of another schedule listing non-native species which the Democrats are proposing. But we have no disagreement with the thrust of the Democrats' amendment.
If the Democrats were of a mind to accept that as a drafting amendment, the Government would not be moving any amendment at all. That is a matter for Senator Coulter to indicate to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment relating to proposed new clause 24A sums up basically one of the greatest risks which can possibly exist for those who are trying to create jobs in Australia, despite the earnest endeavours of the Australian Democrats. This amendment seeks to create the same sort of status for people putting things on interim lists and thus giving them a false status. That in fact has been one of the major problems with existing heritage legislation.

PARA.TAB: It is a nonsense to create an interim list which has a false appearance of status. Unfortunately, it is one which the media in Australia has tended to go along with. Far too often I have seen in the media the statement that such and such is on an interim list—as if that gives it a status of significance meriting the cancellation or deferment of projects aimed at creating jobs in Australia—when in fact it finally ends up not being listed. I am overjoyed to see that the Government is not going along with it.

In order to underline my objection, one could look at the United States experience. The Endangered Species Act of 1973 in the United States allows for public listing of species and critical habitats. The provisions in that legislation, while more detailed than those proposed by the Democrats' amendments, are essentially the same. Both allow members of the public to nominate species or communities in habitats for addition to the list. The US legislation differs in that it also allows members of the public to petition for delisting, and that is a matter I want to raise with the Minister when we talk about the Democrats' proposed new clause 24B, because it is a one-eyed, one-sided move which I find totally intolerable.

In the United States only those species which have, if you like, a constituency are likely to be listed. An example here are charismatic species—that is, those of tourist value or those which are symbols of some constituency, such as the northern spotted owl for those who oppose logging on the west coast. They receive attention to the detriment of other species which may be more critical to an ecosystem or which are in greater danger of extinction. But they are not popular; they are not the go ones; they are not the whacko-you-beaut ones that are likely to attract media attention.

I am talking about the United States experience. Listing of species on the basis of petitions may lead to conflict with the protection of another species or an ecosystem. The Florida Everglades is the site of one such conflict. Lack of water has threatened the Everglades ecosystem. In order to increase the flow of water into the Everglades national park, the National Parks Service plans to release water from nearby impoundments. However, the plan is threatened by a proposal to list the endangered small kite which populates the waters.

Another point is that the listing system is easily politicised and can be used to prevent trade and commerce. There are many examples, and the following two graphically illustrate this point. The American alligator was placed on the endangered species list in response to public calls to stem trade in its hide. This is despite the fact that it was never endangered and that the State of Florida regards it as a nuisance. I might say that there are some States in Australia which regard the eastern grey kangaroo as a menace and a nuisance. But I cannot imagine the Australian Democrats taking that view.

In 1990 the Fisheries and Wildlife Service gave notice that it intended to downlist the bald eagle from endangered to threatened. Green groups protested vehemently but later admitted that part of their concern was that, given the charismatic nature of the bald eagle, downlisting would affect their fund raising efforts.

Public listing procedures have proved impracticable. The number of requests for listing can never be met. It is only the most politically forceful groups that succeed in having their demands met. In a scholarly analysis of the Act, Doremus, who is sympathetic to the Act generally, writes as follows of the listing experience:

It is simply impractical for all species to be protected under the ESA. The FWS has nowhere enough money to produce the required scientific justification for listing all species which currently meet the criteria for endangered and threatened status, much less to devise and implement recovery plans for these species.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to conclude by saying that it is of widespread concern that there should be such an interim list created. I understand the rationale and the need to protect from unscrupulous developers species and communities that are about to be listed. I take Senator Coulter's point that there have been instances where people have rushed in with bulldozers when something is on an interim list. As the Minister quite properly said, we do not have to have an interim list to have something like that flagged. There is no need. If there is a risk, if there is a danger of someone exploiting a situation before a final determination is made, it is up to the Minister to hurry and to take appropriate action to ensure that that does not happen.

PARA.TAB: I must say that the burden of benefit clearly dictates that we should not have an interim list because of the capacity of such a list to be used vexatiously by heavy pressure group activity to trigger legislation. I would much rather that we retain the atmospheric of cool, rational determination by a scientific body, not by, if you like, a government by pressure group. I find that this is simply not an acceptable proposition. I join with the Government in saying that we will oppose it with some vigour.

The Australian Democrats will inevitably call for another division. At times they have forced the coalition to vote with the Government. This is a silly ploy. We will vote against this amendment. I suggest to the Democrats and the Government that they seriously consider our proposal to resolve this matter. We will be seeking by way of amendment to replace clause 24A which is presently before the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would have to agree with at least part of what Senator Baume was saying. It is certainly true that the obvious and attractive species often get protection. They do so for a wide variety of reasons.

PARA.TAB: One of my trenchant criticisms of this legislation and the Government's whole approach to this matter is that the amount of funding which the Government is putting into biological survey is totally inadequate. If I did not say it in my speech on this Bill, I certainly pointed out in the speech which I made on my legislation on this matter that a well-known and world renowned Australian biologist said to me a few months ago that at the rate we were carrying out biological survey in this country we will have to wait until the year 3000 before we know what is here.

It may be that there are bacteria, worms, beetles or all sorts of other things in the soil which do not attract a great deal of attention but which may be quite critical to particular ecologies and habitats. They may be critical to the survival of other species. Until we know about those things, we really will not be able to carry out a proper listing. The listing in the legislation is very much predicated on the obvious mammals and plants and so on. There probably is already built into this legislation and into the listing associated with it a very considerable defect because of that. To that extent, I would agree with Senator Baume that a lot of species may well miss out under this legislation because they are not obvious and they are not attractive. These species may not attract the support of conservation groups and those who love furry little animals or go around hugging trees.

The conclusion that one must draw from that defect is that a great deal more money needs to be put into the biological survey. I might add that a great deal of employment can be generated in this respect. A proper study of the full complement of flora and fauna, bacteria and various other living creatures on this continent would require quite a large effort involving a lot of people—not only biologists but surveyors, photographers, truck drivers and support team members.

We have all heard stories of groups going to remote parts of Australia and, within a very short time, discovering species that we never knew existed. A recent expedition to Cape York came back after about only a week with about seven new species of plants and three or four new species of lizards. To that extent I would have to agree with Senator Baume that that criticism is founded.

As to the rest of his criticism, I just ask him to read clause 24(1). It is quite clear that the interim listing is only a 30-day listing; it is only an interim period. This does go through the scientific committee process. It is not a list which would be made up by conservation groups, however extreme Senator Baume thinks those groups might be. Quite simply, what has been proposed here is a mechanism to ensure that those organisms that have passed through that process for inclusion, pending a declaration by the Minister, go onto an interim list and attract some sort of protection for the reasons that I have already outlined.

I do not think Senator Baume's concerns have substance. He should look very carefully at the wording of clause 24. We are talking about a very short term interim list. It is simply to gain protection in that very short period before a definitive decision is made as to whether the animal, plant, bacteria, beetle, or whatever it is, goes on to one of the lists or that the proposal is rejected.

I turn to the suggestion of the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins. It is true that the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, can act very promptly; she does not have to wait for the full period before she acts—or he acts, if we have a male Minister for environment later on. However, the action will be taken by the Minister after the event. The advantage of the interim list is that the organism would be listed on that interim list and would immediately gain protection. To use Senator Baume's example, if somebody went in and bulldozed a lot of mangroves and that was an important habitat for a particular species, having learnt that the action was taken, the Minister might immediately list the species. Taking action after the event is not good enough. The action needs to be taken in a preventive way before the event.

The whole point of this amendment is that, as soon as that interim list is presented, that species gets protection for 30 days, which is a limited period. After the Scientific Subcommittee has made a determination, the Minister makes a final determination and the whole matter is resolved. There is no danger at all that this will become some sort of permanent list which conservation groups can blow right out. It is simply the proper expression of the precautionary principle that, if there is sufficient evidence for somebody to consider that a prime facie case has been made out so that a creature might be put on an interim list within that very short time, then that will be resolved. The fears being raised by Senator Baume really have no substance at all.

As the Minister pointed out, the other amendments are unrelated. We might just pick up on that so we can deal with the whole of amendment No. 14. The actual wording to which the Minister has agreed is somewhat different. The alternative wording for amendment No. 14A, which I think the Government has assented to and which I agree is fully within the spirit of what we are proposing, not only changes the actual schedule, but also says `members of the public may, in writing, nominate an item for inclusion in a list'. That is the wording I have.

TALK.START.PARA: —No.
—I have been handed a separate sheet, which I thought was the—

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Would it not be better to finish amendment No. 14 before we start to deal with amendment No. 14A?

TALK.START.PARA: —It was just that the other speakers had addressed both issues. I am very happy with that.
—Thank you. I think that would be better.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment we are now dealing with has been renumbered 14A. It refers to the rights of individuals outside the formal process to nominate an item to be listed—and, as the amendment is listed 1 to 3A but we have already rejected the 3A schedule, that should be reworded—in schedules 1 to 3. I draw the Committee's attention to that modification.

PARA.TAB: The principle here is that individuals, particularly in conservation groups, or somebody who lives in a particular area and has made observations over a long period will often become aware of the plight of a particular species of plant or animal. It is absolutely appropriate that those people who share a wider experience than the Scientific Subcommittee or the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories should be able to nominate an item to receive listing. Lest anybody be concerned that that would automatically put an animal or plant on the list, the whole process, of course, is still protected by the proper assessment of that animal or plant. The amendment goes on to say:
A nomination must be made to the Director and must include any information prescribed by regulation.
The Director must forward all nominations to the Scientific Subcommittee.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, it would then be for the Scientific Subcommittee to make the appropriate assessment. At the end of that process, the particular item would or would not be listed. With that slight modification, I understand—and I think the Minister has already given an indication—that the Government will be supporting this amendment. The Democrats are very pleased with its support because—and this is for another reason—as the Minister pointed out earlier, unless this legislation achieves wide consensual support from the community, it simply will not work. This, of course, is one way of involving the Committee more widely in the process of looking after Australia's unique flora and fauna. I formally move:
14A.After clause 24, page 12, insert the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Public may nominate native species etc.

PARA.TAB: "24B.(1)Any person may nominate an item to be listed in Schedules 1 to 3.

TAB.TAB: A nomination must be made to the Director and must include any information prescribed by regulation.
The Director must forward all nominations to the Scientific Subcommittee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter has indicated the change to this amendment, as he correctly says, being the removal of the large A so that it now reads `Schedules 1 to 3'. As a result of a previous Democrats' amendment being lost, that schedule now will not be in the Bill. With that change the Government supports the Democrats' amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition strongly opposes the amendment and is appalled by the Government's support for it. This is a quite disgraceful amendment in that it presents once again a one-sided view and provides one side of the debate with a vehicle.

PARA.TAB: What about those people who are concerned that something that has been listed, in their view, should be delisted? In other words, the issue here is the status of the species, not necessarily listing it. If it is unlisted and people are seeking for it to be listed, a change of its status to being listed is a matter quite properly that people should have an interest in and on which they should have the capacity to make requests. If it is listed, why do we not have the same capacity for people to make requests for it to be removed from the list? This is an example of legislation aimed at appealing to a pressure group, not legislation aimed at making a proper set of laws.

I cannot understand why the Government is going along with this. Apart from the fact that I have concerns about the way this one-eyed deal is being done in the first place—it is not even-handed; it is not fair—I have other concerns which relate to the actual wording. As a result, I will move an amendment which would replace the Democrats' amended present clause 24A with the following amendment. Instead of `Public may nominate native species etc.', the heading would be, `Director to refer status requests to Scientific Subcommittee'. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.After clause 24, page 12, insert the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Director to refer status requests to Scientific Subcommittee

PARA.TAB: "24A.(1) A person may request the Director to refer to the Scientific Subcommittee for consideration the status of a species or ecological community.
(2) Where a person makes a request for a referral in accordance with subsection (1), the Director must make the referral to the Scientific Subcommittee.

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, here we are ensuring that the public does have access to the process. Our opposition to the Democrats' proposal is not by way of refusing the public access to the situation; it is providing them with access but in a proper, rational and coherent way which is even-handed.

PARA.TAB: The reason we have chosen the words `A person may request the Director' and words such as `the Director must then pass on', is that we remove from the nomenclature this false and misused word `nominate', because that gives a false status to the request. It is no more than a request that the Scientific Subcommittee, in fact, consider this matter. By doing it in this way, we are making it clear that the status of the request is not something that, for example, prompts the media to get excited because `this item has been nominated'. This is simply a request and should have no more status than that.

We are concerned, then, on two scores. We have seen many instances, as I have said, where nominated matters have been given an excessive status. But we also believe that it is proper, if you like, for these requests to be filtered through the Director who must make the referral to the Scientific Subcommittee.

I am intrigued that the Government will accept the Democrats' amendment, because it is not my impression that all the Cabinet Ministers who sweated and slaved around the table to come up with some view on this legislation would be likely to agree with the Democrats' amendment. I would not put anything on the Minister himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are as solid as the Rock of Gibraltar.

—In that case, I suggest that there must be even more tunnels in the Rock of Gibraltar than the apes presently enjoy, because these Ministers have been totally undermined. Ministers who agreed in heated and lengthy debates in the Cabinet room—and that is public knowledge—with the final draft of this legislation that came into this chamber have not had the opportunity to discuss the amendment now being put by the Australian Democrats. Some of them are in blissful ignorance of the fact that the decision they came to is now being undermined by the unilateral action of Minister Kelly. I do not think this is an acceptable way for us to deal with legislation of this kind.

PARA.TAB: The clause is fairly dopey. Minister Collins may be amused by the fact—if I could get his attention for a minute; I understand that he has some problems on this matter—that there is no requirement in this amendment for the Scientific Subcommittee to consider a request, which may be why he is cleverly agreeing to it. The Minister was, very sensibly, silent because loose lips sink ships. This amendment is a total nonsense. There is no requirement for the Scientific Subcommittee to examine any such proposal. All we have in this half-baked amendment, which is wrong in what it seeks to do and wrong in the way it tries to do it, is a requirement that the Director must forward all nominations to the Scientific Subcommittee. Apart from anything else, it is a bad amendment: it does the wrong thing, it does it badly and I know for a fact that it does not reflect the views of those people who sat in the Cabinet room and decided on the draft that came into this place and not the legislation as amended. As the Minister has indicated, he will accept the amendment from the Australian Democrats.

To resolve this problem for the Government, I propose a simple solution. I propose that further consideration of this clause be deferred to a later hour this day to allow the Government to establish exactly what it is that Cabinet agreed to so that there will not be the sort of half-baked legislation that would emerge if the Government agreed on the spot now to accept this rather silly amendment. On the other hand, I stress that I believe it is important for the public to have some kind of access. That is why I have moved this amendment, which I believe would have the support of those Cabinet Ministers who have been undermined by Mrs Kelly's acceptance of the Democrats' amendment. I urge the Government, when we get back to discussing this amendment—if it agrees to my suggestion that further discussion be deferred—in the best interests of good government and unity within the Government's own Cabinet, to support my amendment. I believe it is rational and fits more with the spirit of the draft legislation than what Mrs Kelly is presenting to us through the Minister at the table today.

Let us face the fact that Mrs Kelly was comprehensively rolled in Cabinet on her original draft. This seems to me to be some way of trying almost to go back, to restore something that was eliminated from her original draft. I do not know whether those Ministers who enthusiastically removed this sort of thing from the original draft would be overjoyed to see something like this restored just by an agreement with the Minister. I move:
That further consideration of proposed amendments to section 24 be deferred and made an order of the day for a later hour.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to put the motion without debate but, before I do so, could I just indicate to honourable senators that before Senator Baume moved for deferment I had a procedural difficulty in that we had an amendment from Senator Coulter, and then virtually an amendment to that amendment. It would have been far better procedurally for Senator Baume's proposition to be put first and then the amendment from Senator Coulter. Therefore, I put the question moved by Senator Baume.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 15.Clause 31, page 14, paragraph (2)(d), lines 38 and 39, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(d)identify and specify the actions needed to protect the habitats that are critical to the survival of the species or community;".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment proposes to omit the paragraph and to substitute a different paragraph. The reason for this change is quite simple and I hope Senator Baume can agree with our amendment on this occasion. We are referring in clause 31 to the content of recovery plans; that is, those plans which would be put in place to ensure, if I may use the word, the recovery of endangered species and ecological communities. Under clause 31, in relation to the content of the recovery plans, paragraph (2)(d) states that the recovery plan must identify the habitats that are crucial to the survival of the species or community.

PARA.TAB: It is quite insufficient simply to identify the habitats that are critical to the survival of the species or the community. The recovery plan surely must include the identification of the habitats which are critical, but also it should specify the actions needed to protect those habitats. This really is the essence of the amendment. We are removing the words that simply identify the habitats and replacing them with words which say that we should identify and specify the actions needed to protect the habitats that are critical to the survival of a species or community.

I have discussed this matter with Senator Baume and last night he seemed to think that was a fairly reasonable thing to do. I hope he is still of that view and has not changed his mind in the interim or done a deal with the Government. I hope also that the Government is of a view that that is a perfectly reasonable thing to be put in this provision and that recovery plans should both identify and specify the actions which are needed to protect the habitats that are critical to the survival of species and communities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not minded to support the amendment, purely because it is totally unnecessary if we read the clause in the Bill. We agree with all of the sentiments that Senator Coulter has just expressed. If we did not, why else would this legislation be before the Parliament in terms of specifying the content of a recovery plan? It is just repetitious. What Senator Coulter wants to do in proposed new paragraph (d) is to insert the words `specify the actions needed' as well as identifying the habitats. Subclause 31(1) already says that in a very precise way under the heading `Content of recovery plans'. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The recovery plan must provide for the research and management actions—
that is precisely what a recovery plan is, what we have to do—
necessary to stop the decline of, and support the recovery of, the species or community so that its chances of long-term survival in nature are maximised.
All Senator Coulter's amendment does is repeat in paragraph (d) what is already specifically stated in subclause 31(1).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —If there were substance to what the Minister has said, one would wonder why subclause 31(2) is put in there at all, if subclause 31(1) is so comprehensive. Subclause 31(2) begins `In particular'. It is drawing special attention to those essential elements, I guess. It is really underscoring the essential elements in the recovery plan and then it specifies certain things. I would have to concede to the Minister that under paragraph 31(2)(c) it says:

SPEECH.PARA: specify the actions needed to satisfy the criteria;

So it is certainly true that those words are there. The need to protect habitats is referred to in paragraph 31(2)(d). It says `identify the habitats that are critical' and, of course, specify the actions needed to protect the habitats. That is something that is not specifically drawn out in the other paragraphs.

PARA.TAB: Because the Government clearly thought it was necessary to be more specific in this area, it has included subclause 31(2). We feel that it is appropriate to be quite specific in relation to specifying the actions needed to look after those habitats. It is underscoring; the Minister is absolutely right. But the Government started the process of underscoring. We are just saying that if it is going to underscore things, this one is worth underscoring

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —We do not want to get bogged down on this because it is not an earth shattering issue and it is already provided for. Senator Coulter has really turned the argument on its head in what I think is an extraordinary way. The principal purpose of the recovery plan is action. The other element of it—the detail—is spelt out in subclause (2). Senator Coulter asked: why go on with subclause (2) if we have said it all in subclause (1)? I think that that is not a particularly sustainable argument.

PARA.TAB: Fundamentally, the major purpose of the recovery plan, by definition almost, is the action that is required to ensure that the species is not extinct. That is why it is in subclause 31(1). Subclause 31(1) is there to emphasise that the primarily important role of the recovery plan is the action. Honourable senators should read subclause 31(1). The entire subclause specifies that the action is of prime importance. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The recovery plan must provide for the research and management actions necessary to stop the decline of . . .

It then goes on to list a number of other very important matters that are—and I would agree with this emphasis—less important than actually taking action to stop the decline. It is not a question of lumping this in paragraph (d) to re-emphasise its importance. It is in subclause 31(1). The entire subclause 31(1) specifies that the primary purpose of the recovery plan is to take action to stop the extinction of the species.

PARA.TAB: The other matters that are listed under that subclause are subsidiary to that primary role. It is not something we want to get bogged down with because, frankly, we will not die in a ditch if it is carried. But it is just repetitious to put it in paragraph (d) when its primary role is emphasised in subclause 31(1).

TALK.START.PARA: —I totally agree that it is repetitious and a waste of our time to fight about it. It is not our position to oppose the need to specify actions, and I am concerned that our position may be misinterpreted, either accidentally or deliberately, if we oppose this. I am constrained to the view that we should support it. I believe it is repetitious, unnecessary and I agree with everything the Minister said, but we will support it.
—On the principle that one should never use one word when 50 will do the same job, the Government will not be opposing the Democrat amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 16.Clause 34, page 16, paragraph (b), line 20, after "endangered", insert "or vulnerable".
This is a very simple addition. Clause 34 states:
(a) the actions specified under paragraph 31(2)(c) in a recovery plan, or under paragraph 33(2)(c) in a threat abatement plan, include the eradication of a non-native species; and
(b) the species is endangered in a country in which its native habitat occurs.

This means that some care needs to be taken and is the issue to which Senator Baume referred earlier. For instance, we would not want completely to eradicate rabbits in Australia, if rabbits in South America were already extinct or severely endangered. This simply draws our attention to the need to be aware of the global status of endangered species. The amendment we are proposing is to paragraph 34(b), so that it would read: `the species is endangered or vulnerable in a country in which its native habitat occurs'. I understand the Government will agree to the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats are indeed on a roll; they will get two in a row.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 17.Clause 35, page 17, Table, item 1, omit "5", substitute "4".
19.Clause 35, page 17, Table, item 2, omit "10", substitute "6".
20.Clause 35, page 17, Table, item 3, omit "6", substitute "4".

These amendments refer to the table which occurs on page 17, and to the timing of various aspects of recovery plans. Our concern here is that the timing of the recovery plans is overly long and overly generous. It should look to bringing into play more powerful forces which would ensure that, in relation to No. 1 in the table, `Recovery plan for a species or ecological community that is endangered', it allows five years if the listing day is the day this Act commenced and, if the listing day is a later day, it allows three years.

PARA.TAB: We are suggesting that in the first instance, if the listing day is the day this Act commenced—and remember that the Minister is giving herself nine months before this Act need come into effect—the recovery plan for a species or ecological community that is endangered will have the number of years reduced from five years to four years.

In relation to the recovery plan for a species, we would like to add `or ecological community that is vulnerable'. In the first instance, if the listing day is the day this Act commenced, the Government is allowing itself 10 years. We believe that that is far too generous and that that period should be reduced to six years. In relation to type of plan No. 3, `threat abatement plan for a key threatening process', again the Government has allowed itself six years—and we believe that to be an appropriate time—and there would be four years for the implementation and effective application of those recovery and abatement processes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not support these amendments of the Australian Democrats. The time frames that are already in the Bill were carefully and painstakingly negotiated and consulted on. We believe that they are without question realistic time frames. We do not support the Democrat amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 21.Clause 36, page 17, paragraph (2)(e), line 12, omit the paragraph.
22.Clause 44, page 21, paragraph (2)(e), line 20, omit the paragraph.
These amendments relate to subclause 36(2) and subclause 44(2). The two subclauses are identical. Subclause 36(1) states:
The Advisory Committee is to advise the Minister on . . . plans—
Subclause 44(1) states:
The Advisory Committee is to advise the Minister on. . . assistance—
In both instances, the Advisory Committee is to advise the Minister on various matters. Subclause 36(2) states:
In giving advice on the preparation of a draft recovery plan, the Advisory Committee must take into account the following matters:
The paragraph which we find offensive is paragraph (e), which states:
. . . any other value to humanity of the species or community;
Similarly, in relation to advice on assistance, subclause 44(2) states:
In giving advice on preparation of a draft recovery plan, the Advisory Committee must take into account the following matters:
Again, we object to paragraph (e), which states:
. . . any other value to humanity of the species or community;

The concern here is several-fold. As the Minister stressed very strongly a moment ago, this Bill deals with endangered species of plants and animals or ecological systems which are under threat. The committee which is to consider the listing of various categories of animals, plants and ecological communities is a scientific committee which is to advise the Minister on these matters. Yet it is that committee which, under these clauses, is being asked to take into account any other value to humanity of the species or community.

PARA.TAB: Surely the appropriate way in which these sorts of decisions should be made is that the purely scientific advice on the need to look after the particular species or ecological community, unalloyed or undiluted with considerations of other value to humanity of the species or the community, should go to the Minister. Those other considerations should be made somewhere else. They should not be made within the confines of this Advisory Committee, whose proper function is to advise the Minister on the endangered species or ecological communities.

To give another example, it is rather like the National Health and Medical Research Council considering the toxicity of pesticides and then taking into account, in my view quite incorrectly, the economic concerns of whether one should continue to use those pesticides in agriculture. In that case, the National Health and Medical Research Council, being a medical committee, should advise purely and simply on the medical aspects of the use of pesticides. The decision as to whether those things outweigh the economic considerations and the agricultural needs should be made somewhere else; they should not be made by a medical committee.

By analogy, this Advisory Committee, which is advising the Minister, should not be taking into account these other value systems. I suppose at the lowest level the argument would be that it is not competent or qualified to do so. It is no more competent than anybody else. In any case, that sort of consideration should not lie with it; it should lie somewhere else.

The Advisory Committee is an advisory committee only. It advises the Minister. The Minister then takes some action as a result of that advice. It is well within the ability of the Minister to take advice from other sources on these other matters. The Bill refers to other considerations in other parts. So that is how this matter should be handled; not by the Advisory Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that when honourable senators wish to move more than one amendment at once I have to ask whether leave is granted. I will short-circuit the whole process for the remainder of the amendments and ask whether leave is granted for the remaining amendments to be moved together according to the way that they are listed on the schedule. There being no objection, we will proceed in that manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have now been given a clue to an amendment of the Australian Democrats that I have found very puzzling. Senator Coulter may be able to confirm or disabuse me of the assumption that I am making.
—I didn't use the word `disabuse'.

—No, the word was `offensive'. Senator Coulter said that he found this an offensive clause. I now understand why. What puzzled me is the phrase `other value to humanity'. The inference is that all the other criteria are on this list only because of their value to humanity, which is what Senator Coulter said. I take his point. It is again a question of emphasis; it is not something that one would die in a ditch over. But the inference is clearly that the clause could be read that way. It is not the way that I read it.

PARA.TAB: The reason I was surprised at the Democrats' amendment is this: we certainly—and I strongly assert this—wish to retain the value to humanity of the species or community as a criteria. Whether Senator Coulter agrees or disagrees with the amendment that I am about to suggest to him—and this is straight off the top of the old bonk—will soon indicate to me whether this is the problem.

I agree with Senator Coulter's perception, from his point of view, that it has the effect of downgrading perhaps the purely environmental value of those other clauses. The reason I say that is that I am a strong believer in conservation for conservation's sake. I am not an advocate—and never have been, having worked in National Parks—of that strong body of opinion that something should be preserved simply for the benefit of humanity so that the tourists can look at it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The utilitarian.

—Yes, the genetic diversity that is required exists for its own sake. The reason I have a concern about the Democrats' amendment is that I am personally aware of a number of animals that have sacred and spiritual value to Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory. This would be an extremely important consideration, in my view, to take into account in giving advice on the preparation of draft recovery plans. I wonder whether Senator Coulter would consider amending the clause so it would read:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) the potential for the species or community to recover;
(c) the genetic distinctiveness of the species or community;
(d) the importance of the species or community to the ecosystem;
(e) the value to humanity of the species or community . . .

In other words, subclause 36(2) would be redrafted so that it reads exactly the same as all the other subclauses and takes out the words `any other value'. I have to say—I know that Senator Coulter would also be aware of this from his background experience—that there are a significant number of animals and birds which have spiritual significance to Aboriginal communities. I would certainly like to see that criterion of `value to humanity' included without the qualification of `any other' added to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has raised another dimension to this subclause which I had not even considered. I think it is an absolutely legitimate thing to be put in there. My concern with this subclause is that it seems to move into the area that Senator Baume was concerned about earlier—that we might, in fact, put more emphasis on a particular species because it had economic value or something other than its value in terms of its endangered status.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased to accept the concept that the Minister is trying to put into that particular subclause. I think it is an excellent idea and is something which should be included. I am just concerned that, if we start asking the Scientific Subcommittee to take economic values into account, it would not be within the competence of that Committee to do that sort of thing.

However, the Scientific Subcommittee does not ultimately make the decision; it advises the Minister. We know that the Minister is going to be in collaboration with her other Ministers who will have different agendas in terms of development. It seems to me that it is at that point that the economic considerations should be taken into account. It should be an open, democratically-made decision which in this particular case would say that, even though a species is endangered, economic considerations override that.

Such a decision should not be hidden behind a scientific committee being asked to take into account those other values. I make it quite clear to Senator Baume that I am not saying that every single species should be saved. These other considerations should be taken into account, but not through this sort of mechanism. That is my concern. I wonder whether we can further clarify that. Perhaps the Minister has a further suggestion to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply point out that if this Advisory Committee were just a scientific committee Senator Coulter's concern would have some validity, but it is not. The Advisory Committee, by policy decision of the Government, deliberately contains representatives of a broad range of community interests. Rural groups and business groups are, deliberately, part of the Advisory Committee to provide a broader input in the preparation of the recovery plan than just the Scientific Subcommittee's input. It is entirely appropriate to have the criterion of `value to humanity of the species' because, by a deliberate decision of policy, the Advisory Committee is not restricted to scientific membership. It is deliberately provided that a broad range of other community groups will be represented on it.

—The Opposition supports the Minister's view. We believe that it is absolutely vital that this paragraph remain. I think the Minister's subtle alteration should cover any feeling of anger or angst about calling it any other. I do not mind much either way, but I would regard as totally unacceptable removing the requirement that social and other non-biological considerations not be included. That seems to me to be moving in a direction which, once again, is unfair to the many other elements that must be given a voice in this process.

PARA.TAB: What concerns me is that the more the Government moves down the track of giving, if you like, a one-eyed, unfair level of access to one element in this debate, and cutting off considerations which are very serious indeed—as we all know, they have led to serious discussions within the Cabinet—once it ends up chopping off that kind of even-handed approach, it ends up bringing the legislation into some form of disrepute. I do not want to see that happen with this legislation. We support the thrust of it. It seems to me that this is unnecessary, and one could almost say unnecessarily provocative, to the people who want non-biological factors such as social and other considerations—as Senator Collins said, perhaps even tribal considerations in some instances—to be a factor. As a result, we will be supporting the Government in this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —As often happens, I find myself agreeing with Senator Baume, but thinking that he has come to the wrong conclusion from his argument. I am not saying that these considerations should not be taken into account, but that they should not be taken into account through this mechanism and at this place. This is a piece of legislation which is designed to protect endangered, vulnerable species and ecological communities. If other considerations are to be taken into account which override the considerations that a species or a community is vulnerable, threatened or endangered, then they should be taken through some instrument which makes it transparent that it is the economic, social or other considerations which have overridden those. It should not be disguised in such a way that it makes it appear as though those considerations have not been taken into account in that very overt and very obvious way.

PARA.TAB: I must agree with the Minister that I was perhaps using the term `scientific committee' rather loosely. I see in clause 139 that the membership of the Advisory Committee and those other people are in there. What I was saying, perhaps not very well, was that while those other people are in there their task under this legislation is to advise in relation to these endangered species and endangered ecological communities. So their orientation is towards that consideration. That is the point I am making. It is certainly wider than a strictly scientific membership. Their task is oriented towards the protection of those species and those communities.

Let us run through a typical example: somebody determines that a species should be listed as it is endangered. Management plans are then put in place. If during the process that is gone through to make that listing and to put those plans in place there are overriding economic considerations which say that that is too expensive, or the impact on a particular human community is too great or too intrusive, then that is a perfectly legitimate decision to be made. But it should not be made by the committee that is advising on the endangered species; it should be made by, say, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), together with her fellow Ministers, deciding that those other considerations were ones which overrode the concerns for the threatened species and overrode either the listing or the management plans. I am not saying the decision should not be made, but it is just being made in the wrong place, and that is what is of concern to me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to stop trying to be constructive.
—Leave it be.

—I will let it be. The clause is very Judeo-Christian in its construction. I note that, fundamentally, as Genesis tells us, everything was put on this earth for our benefit—which is not a proposition that I accept as a practising Christian.
—I agree.
—Does Senator Sowada agree with that? I am horrified! She should be expelled from the Australian Democrats. They usually want to stop the world and get off.
—I reject it.

—Good. I am glad that the Leader of the Democrats rejects it. I feel that I now understand Senator Coulter's concern. It is not raised with any qualifications; the implication is that all of the other criteria are also there because they are of value to humanity. It is the very mention of humanity itself which has offended Senator Coulter, and he wants us removed.

PARA.TAB: I think that I will probably get Senator Sowada's support, considering her interjection. Humanity—as horribly flawed as we are—is part of the environment. This is simply a list of priorities to determine the recovery plans. The Government will certainly not be agreeing to the removal of humanity from the consideration of this matter. I am now sorry I made my helpful suggestion. I am happy to go back to the original construction of the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 24.Clause 56, page 25, line 3, omit "Subject to section 57, the", substitute "The".
25.Clause 57, pages 25 and 26, line 11 (page 25) to line 4 (page 26), clause to be opposed.
28.Clause 61, page 27, paragraph (2)(a), lines 12 to 18, omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:
"(a)until the end of the period of 6 months after it is made; or;".
29.Clause 61, page 27, subclause (3), lines 23 and 24, omit "of the kind referred to in subparagraph (2)(a)(i)".
30.Clause 61, page 27, subclause (3), line 24, omit all words after "of", substitute "6 months".
31.Clause 61, page 27, subclause (4), lines 27 to 30, omit the subclause.

Amendment No. 24 refers to clause 56 on page 25. This is a relatively trivial amendment. Amendment No. 25 is a substantial one which refers to clause 57 on page 25 and which flows over to the first four lines on page 26. The amendment refers to removing the whole of that clause headed `Limitations on the power to make interim conservation orders'.

PARA.TAB: This amendment is about the removal of the limitations on the powers of the environment Minister. The interim conservation order procedure was considerably watered down; Senator Baume has referred to the tortuous processes through which this legislation has passed in the Government's hands. This procedure was one of those considerably watered down by the pro-development Ministers.

There are two types of interim conservation orders: those relating to the non-commercial activities and those relating to commercial activities. Where a commercial activity is threatening a species, the Minister must give notice to the Minister responsible for the activity if that Minister has the power to restrain the activity. That is the point at which the action is taken. The reason for the objection is that the action Minister then ceases to be the Minister for the environment.

The pro-development Minister must make a decision within 24 hours as to whether to use those powers. If he or she decides not to use those powers, no interim conservation order will be applied. Here we have the conservation Minister identifying the need for an interim conservation order and the whole process is passed out of her hands to a different Minister. If that other Minister chooses to make a different decision for other reasons, no action would be taken. It is absolutely outrageous to allow the pro-development Minister to make this sort of decision in this particular way.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where did you find this definition—the pro-development Minister?

—This is in relation to a commercial-type activity. I would have thought that the Minister who is responsible for that type of activity should correctly be pro-development and should look after the interests of those who want to develop, in the same way as the Minister for the environment should look after the interests of the environment. The decision should be made in the resolution of the tension between those two views. It should not pass from one Minister to the other.

PARA.TAB: Also, the commercially applied interim conservation order can be applied using lesser powers than those available to the environment Minister. This bears very much on the sort of argument that we have just had. I stress again that I am not saying—and this is said particularly for Senator Baume's edification—that these other considerations should not be taken into account. It is the appropriate place for them to be taken into account and the mechanism by which that is done which concern me.

This legislation seeks to remove the decision from the environment Minister and pass it over to a Minister who, quite correctly in my view, should represent—if you like, in the democratic processes of the Ministry—those interests, in the same way as the Minister for the environment should represent the environmental interests. Appropriately, the decision should be made by some sort of counsel between those Ministers. The decision should not be made exclusively by the Minister to whom the control is passed by these sections.

We feel very strongly about this matter. It is a very good example of precisely where the environment Minister was rolled, to use a term that the Opposition likes using, in relation to watering down this legislation. The decision in these crucial areas has passed from her hands to somebody else's hands. I am not saying that the other considerations should not be taken into account—they should be, but they should not then be taken entirely out of her hands; they should be taken in some council of Ministers which properly weighs up the merits of both the protection of the species and the commercial interests, which in this instance have been engaged through the fact that there is some commercial activity going on.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be accepting these amendments, which remove limits on the power to make interim conservation orders affecting commercial projects. The Government finds that the amendments are unacceptable as these limits are necessary to ensure that all relevant policy interests are considered. I point out to Senator Coulter in passing something which I am sure he knows: all Ministers are bound by an approved recovery plan and any action that any Minister presumed to take that was contrary to that plan would be illegal.

—Again, it is a matter of timing and chronology. Once the protection is in place, the processes are triggered and other Ministers become bound. Through these mechanisms, as I understand them, the initial decisions pass out of the hands of the environment Minister. That is our objection.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 26.Clause 58, page 26, subclause (2), lines 24 to 27, omit the subclause.
32.Clause 68, page 31, subclause (2), lines 12 to 15, omit the subclause.
Clause 58 refers to the grounds for making interim conservation orders. Subclause (2) of clause 58 says, `For the purposes of paragraph (1)(d)', which reads:

ensuring that particular activities do not adversely affect a listed native species or listed ecological community, or habitat significant to the survival of a listed native species or listed ecological community, before an assessment can be made as to whether any other action should be taken under this Act to protect the species, community or habitat.
That section is then qualified by subclause (2), which says:
For the purposes of paragraph (1)(d), activities affecting the habitat—
and I emphasise that word; I drew attention to the importance of habitat earlier—

of a listed native species or a listed ecological community are relevant only to the extent that they adversely affect features of the habitat that are significant to the survival of the species or community.

We have probably run through these arguments fairly well already, but it is very difficult in a particular habitat to identify clearly those features which are of concern. I used the example earlier of the gouldian finch in the Northern Territory, where there has been an absolutely dramatic decline in this bird's numbers. While there are some fairly reliable theories as to why the decline has occurred, I do not think anybody would positively say that he or she actually knows why that decline has occurred. Consequently, it is a bit difficult to identify precisely which factors in the habitat are so significant.

PARA.TAB: At present, in making an interim conservation order or a permanent conservation order the Minister must take into account only those features of the habitat that would be adversely affected by an activity and that are significant to the survival of the species or the community. The qualifier in clause 58(2) and clause 68(2) fails to take into account the ecological integrity of the habitat as a whole and assumes in some cases, I think, a great deal more knowledge of the ecology of the habitat—in other words, the interactions which occur within the habitat—than perhaps we can reasonably claim.

It is for that reason that we propose these two amendments. We propose to omit those particular subclauses. In other words, the processes by which the Minister would make these interim or permanent conservation orders would take into account the same range of activities and factors but without this qualifier, which assumes that we have a great deal more knowledge than we have and assumes that we can, very significantly in some cases, I suspect, disturb the habitats without interfering with some of those features which we would find, to our surprise, are crucial to the survival of species or a listed ecological community. It is for that reason that we recommend amendments Nos 26 and 32.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will be opposing these amendments. Senator Coulter is correct, the arguments have been gone over before in another place in respect of another amendment. We will not be going over them again.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 27.Clause 59, page 26, lines 28 to 38, clause to be opposed.
33.Clause 69, page 31, lines 16 to 21, omit the clause, substitute the following clause:

PARA.TAB: "69. In considering whether to make a permanent conservation order, the Minister must as far as is practicable ensure that the prohibitions, restrictions and requirements in the order will, consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development, minimise any significant adverse social and economic impacts while ensuring that they are:

TAB.TAB: (a)consistent with furthering the objects of this Act; and
(b)adequately address themselves to the grounds on which the order is made.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 27 refers to clause 59, which is to be found on page 26 of the Bill. It suggests the removal of clause 59. Clause 59 refers to the consideration of the social and economic impact of interim conservation orders. It specifically talks about—and this is rather interesting—principles being `consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development', and seeks to set the factors which must be considered. They have to be consistent with furthering the objects of the Act and adequately address themselves to the grounds on which the order—in this case, the first one; the interim conservation order—is to be made.

PARA.TAB: It is, as I have said before, not appropriate in this particular place—and this is an argument that we have run before—to consider the social and economic impacts in deciding whether to make an interim conservation order, particularly in this case, because the interim conservation order is one which will only be in place for a short time, pending the decision as to whether the interim conservation order is to be replaced by a permanent conservation order, or whether the permanent conservation order would not be put in place at all.

I feel that, again on the grounds of the precautionary principle, and particularly with respect to clause 59, it is inappropriate to be taking into account these wider considerations in this short term interim issue. It may be appropriate further on that they be taken into account, but in this particular case one has been forewarned that one is dealing with an endangered species, a vulnerable species or an ecological community and yet, even with respect to the interim conservation order in clause 59, one is asked to take into account these wider considerations. I feel and the Democrats feel that invoking the precautionary principle would say that, if there is enough evidence to put these interim conservation orders in place, then it would be appropriate for those interim conservation orders to be so placed and for these other considerations to go elsewhere.
Clause 69 deals with permanent conservation orders. It refers to the economic and social considerations in very much the same terms as we have just been considering. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: In considering whether to make a permanent conservation order, the Minister must be satisfied that such action for the conservation of the listed native species or listed ecological community in question is justified, having regard to economic and social considerations that are consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development.

I think that we have fallen into this trap before. It is important that social and economic considerations be taken into account, but the wording in this case is not acceptable. We feel that the wording which is applied to the interim conservation orders, which we say should be deleted altogether, should be applied to the permanent conservation orders. So clause 69 would essentially be replaced by the wording which appears at clause 59.

PARA.TAB: So, to reiterate, in the case of an interim conservation order, in other words, a temporary conservation order, we do not believe that it is appropriate to take these other considerations into account on the basis of the precautionary principle. In relation to the permanent conservation orders, clause 69, which is much briefer in terms, says that the Minister must take these things into account. We believe that the wording which is actually in clause 59 relating to interim conservation orders is a more appropriate set of conditions to apply to the permanent conservation orders. We do not say that, in the case of permanent conservation orders, these matters should not be taken into account. Clause 59, which is more extensive, states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . consistent with the principles of ecologically sustainable development—
as does clause 69—
. . . minimise any significant adverse social and economic impacts, while ensuring that they:
(a) are consistent with furthering the objects of this Act; and
(b) adequately address themselves to the grounds on which the order is made.
It is the exchange of those two clauses to which we would draw the Committee's attention.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Coulter, before I call on the Minister, amendment 27 actually opposes clause 59. I will have to put the questions separately. I will ask the Minister to comment on the amendment to clause 59. The question is that clause 59 stand as printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government opposes this amendment which, of course, removes any reference to ecologically sustainable development. Indeed, I have to say that these arguments have also been canvassed previously. I will not canvass them again. The Government believes that the reference to ESD is essential to be retained in this Bill.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the amendment to clause 69, which will be moved separately, as Senator Coulter says, it also further limits factors that the Government can consider when deciding whether to make a permanent conservation order. For that reason, the Government opposes the amendment. We believe that it would place unacceptable limits on the matters that the Government can take into consideration.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—The question is that clause 59 stand as printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have already indicated, amendment 33 is simply to pick up clause 59 and place it in the position of clause 69, because we believe that the wording is much better. Clause 59(a) applies to the placing of interim conservation orders. But if this amendment were accepted, it would apply to permanent conservation orders so that the actions would be consistent with furthering the objects of this Act. —As I have said, the Government opposes this amendment because permanent conservation orders are to be a decision of the whole Government, based on all relevant criteria, including general, economic and social policies. Indeed, the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly) made that very clear in her second reading speech. SPEECH.PARA: The first amendment seeks to ensure that even more power is not given to any future Ministers for the environment to take decisions that, perhaps as Senator Coulter would suggest, may not necessarily be in the best interests of all Australians. In other words, this amendment will ensure that there is good government, not just government by one particular segment of our society.

PARA.TAB: This really follows very much the principle that the Government adopted in clause 57(1), which it has just supported against the attack of the Australian Democrats. Lines 24 and 25 of clause 57(2) are to the effect that, when making an interim conservation order, the Minister should give notice to each other Minister whose areas of responsibility include a matter which would be affected by such an order. In other words, in making the interim order, those Ministers who are affected have to be advised.

At present there is no requirement on the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), when extending an order, to advise anyone, to get approval or to do anything. Yet this could be a disruptive process. It seems to me extraordinary that the Government, when making an interim order, has on the one hand required these other Ministers to be involved and yet in extending it does not require them to be involved.

I think it would be quite unreasonable for this Government to give powers to any one Minister in such a contentious area which would lead to disaffection and disagreement around the Cabinet table itself. It would be much better if the Government devised a system whereby agreement had to be reached before such an order could be extended. As I said, to make the order in the first place these Ministers have to be informed.

It is interesting to see that the Government in clause 57(1) does not state which Ministers have to be informed. The explanatory memorandum states, `each other Minister whose area of responsibility includes a matter that would be affected' by such an order. In our amendment we have spelt out who in fact those Ministers are. It seems to us that the interim conservation order would clearly relate to the Minister administering the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act, the Minister administering the Export Control Act and the Minister administering the Fisheries Administration Act. This is a self-evident safeguard against the excessive exercise of power by one Minister, particularly in the context of a situation where she had other obligations, at least in the making of an interim order, which she is not bound by in extending that interim order. The same situation obtains for clause 70. It may be appropriate to take clause 70 in conjunction with clause 61 because I would be making exactly the same points in that matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not accept amendment No. 1 moved by Senator Baume. Subclause 61(2) relates to interim conservation orders and states:

PARA.TAB: The order remains in force:
(a) until:

(i)if it prohibits, restricts or imposes requirements on an activity that is carried out, or proposed to be carried out, primarily for a commercial purpose—subject to subsection (3), the end of the period of 28 days after it is made; or
(ii)otherwise—the end of the period of 6 months after it was made; or
(b) until it is revoked by the Minister . . .

SPEECH.PARA: These interim conservation orders have a fairly limited life, although they can be reimposed during their life by the Minister. Certain clauses set that out. What the Opposition is seeking to impose on the Minister is a particularly arduous process which would make it extremely difficult for the Minister to obtain any interim conservation orders at all. The Minister must not only seek the cooperation of these Ministers but also obtain their approval before she can put these interim conservation orders in place. In view of the short time interval during which these interim orders are in place, we believe it is quite inappropriate for the Minister to have to go through this time-consuming process.

PARA.TAB: I draw the Committee's attention to my earlier arguments in relation to pre-emptive action taken by some person who does not have the best interests of threatened species at heart and gets to hear that an interim conservation order may be made. Under a process where the Minister must go to a number of other Ministers and seek their approval, quite a large number of people would become aware of this situation. After a person gets to hear that such an application is in the wind, he may go and destroy the habitat, remove the remaining species or in another way interfere with the environment of these species so that they no longer survive. We would certainly reject the first of Senator Baume's amendments on those grounds.
In relation to the second amendment, where Senator Baume seeks to deal with clause 70 of the Bill, the permanent conservation orders, again he says that the Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: ..must seek and obtain the approval of:
(i) the Minister administering the Primary Industries and Energy Research and Development Act 1989; and
(ii) the Minister administering the Export Control Act 1982; and
(iii) the Minister administering the Fisheries Administration Act 1991'.
Where one is dealing with a permanent conservation order, the provisions in section 70 as it stands state:
Before making a permanent conservation order, the Minister: (a) must seek the Director's advice on whether it should be made;
and
(b) may have regard to any advice of the Advisory Committee on whether it should be made.

Senator Baume has been defending the role of the Advisory Committee and, indeed, the Minister has been defending the role of the Advisory Committee in taking on the role of those wider functions to which we objected earlier. Senator Baume wants to dilute the ability of the Minister even further by having to go much more widely—

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—`Hear, hear!', says Senator Baume. He reveals his real concern for the environment—very little concern. The Democrats are concerned that the net is wide enough already. We certainly would not want to widen it further. We would have to agree—grudgingly and unwillingly—with the Minister now that the provisions in the legislation, with respect to those protective functions which are to be carried out by the Advisory Committee, are adequate. We would certainly not want to take it further.

—I do not think it will come as a profound shock to Senator Baume to hear that we are not supporting these amendments. It is made clear in the second reading speech that it is intended that making permanent conservation orders will be done only with the approval of Cabinet. I point out to the Committee that the reason that was in the second reading speech of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), was that that is a policy decision of the Government, which is part of the Cabinet decision, so that will be the case.

PARA.TAB: The reason it is not in the legislation, apart from anything else—and I agree with it—is that we were advised by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel that it is extremely unusual to make a reference to Cabinet in legislation. Indeed, it is not contained in the Australian Constitution, as Senator Baume knows. I personally cannot think of a single Act of Parliament that contains a reference to Cabinet. It is a categorical policy decision of the Government that this will not be done unless Cabinet approves, and it is part of the Cabinet decision that that be the case.

In the case of the renewal of interim conservation orders, the environment Minister has responsibility only in the case of non-commercial activities on Commonwealth land or waters, or in a case where another relevant Minister does not have power to act. We would not therefore want to single out approval by one or two Ministers, as suggested by the coalition's proposed amendment. The amendment is not, therefore, acceptable to the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the reasons why we have not put up the proposition that the extension should be subject to Cabinet approval is that, although we were of a mind to do it, if under the Government legislation those sorts of matters are to be resolved by Cabinet, we could not see why the interim one could not be a matter for Cabinet approval. But, as the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) rightly says, it has never been done. As a result of that, we took the view that we should have a second best situation of requiring those other Ministers who had an interest in the matter to have the opportunity of participating in any decisions further to delay activity—which is what renewing an interim order means—which may well in some instances be of significant disadvantage. It is all very well for Senator Coulter to say that it is only 28 days in the first instance and then a further 28 days, but there are some instances where delaying something for almost two months, and leaving uncertainty around for that period, may well be a matter of some substance.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I stress that we think this prevents the exercise of excessive power by one Minister. We believe that is in line with the Government's own thinking because it requires other Ministers to be involved in the process in the first instance of making an order, but not in the extending of it. We think the Government's position is illogical, which is not enormously unusual. Of course, it is usual in terms of the Democrats supporting the Government on this matter.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Michael Baume's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

I think we have already run the argument about the need to protect the components of ecological communities and not just the particular species in isolation. These amendments all have the same effect, but they occur in a number of different places.

PARA.TAB: I think we have already rehearsed the arguments about the need to extend beyond the protection of species as such; to recognise that those species do not exist in isolation; and to protect the ecological community of which those species simply form a part.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government will not be accepting these amendments from the Democrats, for the reasons we enunciated earlier in the debate. The amendments have the effect of, once again, widening the ambit of the proposed legislation and would prohibit the killing or taking of a member of a listed ecological community.

PARA.TAB: The effect of these amendments would be to encompass one of possibly a large number of species inhibiting a particular area. We believe that the amendments are unreasonable. They would be almost impossible to properly enforce. For all the reasons that have been canvassed earlier in the debate today, the Government will not be supporting these amendments.
