SPEECH.PARA: 44.Clause 86, page 39, subclause (5), definition of "take", line 20, omit "or collect", substitute "collect, hunt, shoot, poison, net, snare, spear, pursue, capture, disturb, lure or injure and, without limiting the foregoing, also includes significant modification of the habitat of the listed native species or listed ecological community".

I am told that the definition of `take' is modelled very much on the definition of `take' included in the Endangered Fauna (Interim Protection) Act 1991. On the principle that legislation which deals with similar activities should use similar wording so that members of the public, among others, do not become confused—one Act says one thing and another Act says something different—it would be useful if a similar definition were included in this particular piece of legislation.

PARA.TAB: The notion of `taking' there is very limited when it talks only about killing, damaging, destroying or collecting. I do not know whether Senator Collins has something to say about spearing and luring in relation to those areas where Aboriginal cultures are still extant and practised. But on the grounds that it is desirable to include the same types of provisions in one piece of legislation as are contained in another piece of legislation rather than use different definitions for the same activity, I commend this amendment to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —In brief response to that invitation to say something about spearing, it is covered under the current definition of `take'. Once again, the Democrats amendment is trying to widen the ambit of this definition to a point that the Government certainly cannot accept. We believe that this amendment widens the definition to an unacceptable degree in broadening this criminal offence.

PARA.TAB: Let me make two points about spearing. I can guarantee from personal experience that, if a shovel-nosed spear hits its mark, it either kills or damages what it is being thrown at. I also make the point that under the Crimes Act, even if the spear misses, the thrower has still committed an offence by attempting to carry out the act. So the person is caught up under the Crimes Act and certainly the Government believes that the existing definition of `take' is practical, realistic and sensibly cannot be widened.

TALK.START.PARA: —I discussed this with Senator Coulter last night and he told me, I think, that this was the same definition under which the National Parks and Wildlife Service operates. The only problem I have is that, in this particular context where it is a criminal offence, the word `disturb' is in the amendment. One would have thought that one can disturb without criminal intent. I must say that that word causes me a problem and I agree with the Minister that it extends the matter far too far. The benefit of having a similar definition to that contained in the ANPWS legislation seems to me not relevant when, in fact, a different penalty is involved. I certainly could not endorse extending it to `disturb'.

—I am not at all certain whether Senator Coulter mentioned the ANPWS Act or not, but I would just like to make the point that the section quoted by Senator Coulter in fact comes from the New South Wales State legislation and that this wording is not found in Commonwealth legislation.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.PARA: 48.Clause 92, page 42, subclause (1), line 13, after "must", insert "be sent to the applicant and all persons or bodies on the register listed under section 89 and must".
48A.Clause 92, page 42, subclause (1), after "applicant", insert "or a registered person or body" (wherever occurring).
Clause 92 deals with notification of rights to reconsideration. Subclause (1) currently states:
The notice informing a person of a decision to issue, or refusing to issue, a permit, or a decision cancelling a permit, must contain. . .

It then sets out various provisions. We are suggesting that it also include `be sent to the applicant and all persons or bodies on the register listed under section 89 and must. . . ' Subclause (1) would then read:

The notice informing a person of a decision to issue, or refusing to issue, a permit, or a decision cancelling a permit, must be sent to the applicant and all persons or bodies on the register listed under section 89 and must contain. . .
The various subclauses would follow. This recommendation would increase the public awareness, the public input and the public accountability of these provisions.

PARA.TAB: The amendment to which I have just referred ensures that, where the Minister makes a decision about issuing a permit to take a species, the Minister must notify all persons on the register established under clause 89. The person on the register may then ask the Minister to reconsider his or her decision. Quite clearly, if that person is not appropriately notified—and there is nothing in the legislation which would ensure that that would occur unless this amendment is accepted—then that does not trigger that wide awareness of the decision.

As the Minister has agreed beforehand, the effective working of this legislation depends upon wide consensus in the community and an acceptance of the working of the legislation. Every mechanism should be extended to those who participate in these processes so that they would be fully aware of what decisions were made and could then participate fully in the administration of this legislation to the extent that outside persons would do so.

Our recommendation in amendment No. 48A is also to clause 92 on page 42 of the Bill. It deals also with subclause 92(1) where we propose to insert after the word `applicant', wherever that occurs, the words `or a registered person or body'. It simply extends the availability of that information so that people can participate properly in this process and not be dependent upon other less effective ways and means of notification.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is not supporting these amendments; not because we are opposed to third parties having the opportunity to take action against decisions that they think may have contravened the Act, but simply because it bogs down the process with unnecessary provisions that are already well covered. Senator Coulter knows very well that laid out in clause 130 of this Bill are very specific provisions in respect of action that can be taken by third parties, not simply against the Minister but against the director as well, with regard to action that is purportedly in contravention of the Act.

—The Minister's answer is not entirely satisfactory. Again, we propose these amendments on the grounds that unless one is aware of these things the injunctive process cannot necessarily be invoked. I stress again that I do not think the process of extending the notification to the extent that is anticipated by these two amendments bogs down the process. It would be, therefore, quite appropriate and is more likely to trigger clause 130.

—Under clause 89 of the Bill, there is a requirement to advise interested parties of procedures that are taking place. The provisions are in fact laid out under clause 89 of the Bill. In fact, subclause 89(6) details that there is a time requirement of five days imposed on this process. So, in the Government's view, these provisions sensibly provide for people to be advised of what is going on.

PARA.TAB: Clause 130 certainly provides people with very specific avenues for legal redress if they seek it. Fundamentally, as we have said on previous occasions, we understand what the Democrats are doing here in attempting to further dot the i's and cross the t's. But we feel that Senator Coulter's concerns here are misplaced and that the Act in fact already provides sufficient provision for people, firstly, to know what is going on; and, secondly, to do something about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a problem that goes slightly beyond this point. It appears to me that, if the Democrats amendment No. 48A were applied to paragraph 92(1)(b), we would then provide people who were not parties to this matter—who were not the applicants—with the opportunity to appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; a facility which would not otherwise be open to them. In other words, it is inviting third parties to delay, frustrate or interfere with the process. Any appeals are up to the applicant. I can see this having the potential to be part of a stalling process which I do not believe would be in the best interests of good government.
—I can assure Senator Baume that his interpretation of the effect of that amendment is correct.

SPEECH.PARA: These amendments deal with the obligations of Commonwealth agencies. Amendment No. 49 is to clause 97 on page 44 of the Bill. This amendment seeks to insert proposed new clause 97A. Clause 97 as it stands deals with the publication of permit details. It says:
The Director must give to any person who so requests written details of:

PARA.TAB: (a) permits that have been issued; and
(b) applications for permits that have been refused.

SPEECH.PARA: We seek to insert a proposed new clause 97A after clause 97 which would read:
Subject to section 100, a Commonwealth agency must not take any action that is likely to threaten with extinction a listed native species or listed ecological community.
One hopes that that is fairly unexceptional. Amendment No. 50 is to clause 98 which is headed `Compliance with recovery plans and threat abatement plans'. Clause 98 reads:
Subject to section 100, a Commonwealth agency must not take any action that contravenes a recovery plan or threat abatement plan.
We seek to insert proposed new clause 98A entitled `Taking etc. listed species and ecological communities'. It reads:

Subject to subsections 86(1) and 86(4), a Commonwealth agency must not knowingly or recklessly take, trade, keep or move any member of a listed native species or component of a listed ecological community.

We have dealt with amendment No. 51. In our amendments Nos 52 to 56, we are again looking at an amendment to clause 100. We propose to insert after clause 100 proposed new clause 100A. This is a condition which reads:
(1) a governmental approval given by a Commonwealth agency is required before a particular activity is permitted under the law of the Commonwealth or a non-self-governing Territory; and
(2) the activity:

PARA.TAB: (a) is an activity that is likely to threaten or further threaten with extinction a listed native species or listed ecological community;

SPEECH.PARA: The point is that the Commonwealth agency must not give the required governmental approval. Again, we are attempting to ensure that the Commonwealth Government does not behave in a way which is contrary to the intention of this legislation. We also propose to insert new clause 100B. That involves the same sorts of provisions. That is all there is in relation to amendment No. 52. Our proposed new clause 100B runs over quite a few pages. Amendment No. 53 deals with the omission in clause 102 on page 45, subclause 1, line 5, of sections 98 and 99. Subclause 102(1) states:

If a Commonwealth agency (other than a Minister) believes that action that it proposes to take may be an action to which section 98 or 99 applies, the Commonwealth agency must notify the Minister in writing of the proposed action and the grounds for its belief.

That is again coming back over this area of other agencies being involved. Again, it attempts to bind the Commonwealth by this legislation. Amendment No. 53 also relates to clause 102 on page 45, and omits reference to section 98 and substitutes proposed new sections 97A, 98 and 98A. These are the sections that we inserted only a moment ago, if the earlier amendments are accepted. Similarly, amendment No. 54 also refers to a Commonwealth agency and binds that agency. Amendment No. 56 is a tidying up amendment, which relates back to omitting section 98 and substitutes proposed new sections 97A, 98 and 98A.

PARA.TAB: I will now deal with amendment No. 58. Amendment No. 57 has already been dispensed with. Amendment No. 58 relates to clause 103 on page 45 under the heading `Minister to consider proposed actions etc'. The proposal is to omit all words after `action' and substitute `or carry out the activity may make written submissions to the Minister about the proposed action or activity'. That tidies that one up. That is the last of the amendments in this particular group. The effect of all these amendments, in one way or another, is to tie the Commonwealth and the various agencies under the Commonwealth into this legislation. We believe that it is appropriate for that to be done, and that these amendments therefore should be included. The Commonwealth should not become a loophole mechanism through which it can do things that other individuals in the community cannot do. It is dealt with to an appropriate extent, we believe, by the Commonwealth Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act, as amended by the consequential provisions Bill and the obligation of Commonwealth agencies to comply with recovery and threat abatement plans that are contained in clause 98 of this Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very important amendment. It marks quite a diversion from the other clauses in the legislation. The Government, at the time of the 1990 election, said that it would comprehensively and nationally legislate to protect threatened and endangered species. Quite clearly, in the promise which it gave to the conservation groups, it envisaged the use of all those constitutional powers which undoubtedly the Federal Government does have over the whole of the continent. I believe that a promise was given to the conservation groups, therefore, that the corporations power, which is a very extensive power which the Commonwealth has from time to time used, not only in other areas but also in the area of environmental protection, would be included in the Government's legislation. In the private member's Bill which I introduced and which was debated several weeks ago, there was quite heavy dependence upon the use of the corporations power.

PARA.TAB: The Government, in section 5 or section 6 of its own ozone protection legislation which passed, I think, in 1988 used that particular head of power, recognising that it was indeed a very powerful instrument which the Commonwealth Government could use. It used it on that occasion and the use of that particular head of power for the protection of the environment has never been challenged. The Opposition for its part—and Mr Howard specifically—in the battle that is going on between several of the States and the Commonwealth in relation to industrial relations has said that, if necessary, if the coalition forms the next government, it would use the corporations power to impose its pattern of industrial relations on the whole of Australia. So there is no doubt that the Opposition would also use the corporations power for those things which it regards as important.

Therefore, we think that it is very appropriate, given that the Federal Government, in terms of its actual territorial holdings, extends to only about 0.2 per cent of the whole of Australia, that this amendment be inserted into the legislation to extend the powers of this legislation over the States in cases where the States did not pass complementary legislation. Our proposed sections 111A B and C set out quite clearly that if the States do pass complementary legislation, if they do do the right thing by their threatened species, then the Commonwealth would cooperate and fully assist the States in that work. However, in the event that the States fail to act appropriately, the proposed quite extensive amendment, involving section 111C, goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . then the Minister may—
(a) introduce into Parliament proposed legislation which will override any existing State or Territory legislation; and
(b) recommend that the Governor-General make regulations which will override any existing State or Territory legislation; and (c) take appropriate administrative action.

We feel that the plight of the enormously large number of species listed in the schedules to this Bill—and I think that enough has been said about the number of species lost—is desperate and urgent. This is an urgent matter, one in which some of the States have not been particularly forthcoming when it comes to protecting the threatened species within their borders. Many of the threatening processes—and I will be dealing with this matter later—take no notice of State borders. Those threatening processes go right across State borders; they are national problems. I think that Senator Baume will be supporting the inclusion of rabbits as a threatening process.

PARA.TAB: Clearly, the sorts of protective actions that would be put in place may well include things which would, and should appropriately, run right across State borders. The problem with feral foxes, which are listed in schedule 3, is not confined to any particular State or Territory. We believe that to tie this legislation in the way the Government has done is quite inappropriate, given the seriousness and urgency of the problem. We make a very strong appeal for the application of this much wider head of power.

I stress again that it is not that the Opposition is averse to the use of the corporations power in section 51(xx) of the Constitution. The Opposition has said quite clearly that, should it win the next election and find the national circumstance inimical to its interests, it would use it in industrial relations. If it is prepared to use the corporations powers to tie the hands of workers right across this country, surely it should be prepared to use the corporations powers to protect threatened species right across this country, particularly given the failure of the amendments that we put earlier today in relation to widening this legislation.

We already have a much narrower Bill than the Bill that we would prefer to see in place, given that the Opposition should have little concern about simply extending the powers of this somewhat narrowed legislation to the control of the States. There are very considerable safeguards written into it. This amendment is simply to allow those States that are not doing the right thing with threatened species to be brought into line in conformity with the rest of this legislation. I very strongly urge the Committee to accept this series of amendments under amendment 62, which will extend the power of the Commonwealth in that way.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an appalling amendment. We certainly will not be supporting it. Even to put it up I think is a disgraceful act. How does Senator Coulter believe that a power to legislate in relation to financial or trading corporations gives the Commonwealth power to legislate in respect of the environment?

A great deal of legal advice goes to the extent to which that section of the Constitution could be used.

PARA.TAB: I am not sure whether division 5 or division 6 of the Government's ozone depleting control legislation that was passed in 1988 deals with that point, but I simply ask Senator O'Chee to look at that section. TALK.START.PARA: —I find nothing more rivetingly interesting than a debate on constitutional law. I am not being sarcastic when I say that; administrative law and constitutional law interest me more than any other part of the law. PARA.TAB: I want to respond to what Senator O'Chee said and what Senator Coulter, to my interest, has just said. The relevant point in the debate tonight is that, as Senator Coulter has said, these amendments give a very wide ambit to the Commonwealth simply overriding a whole undefined mass of State legislation. TALK.START.PARA: —Are you going to give us the same amount of time to debate industrial relations?
—I say with the greatest respect that it would help enormously if we just kept going with this legislation instead of making political points.
—We have not taken many today.

—No. We have been very restrained about this. I am just a foot soldier in this debate of parliamentary strategy; I take my orders from the generals. I conclude by commenting on the initial point that Senator Coulter made. At least some inference was contained in that statement about the commitments of the Government in respect of this matter. The Government, through the then Prime Minister in March 1990, committed itself to enact legislation to protect endangered species. That was the commitment that was given. With the passage of this legislation, that commitment is being discharged.

—I would like to state quite clearly the coalition's position. In this legislation there is an attempt to have a cooperative arrangement with the States under the IGAE. We are trying to do things by consensus, by agreement, effectively and without confrontation. It is appalling that Senator Coulter has introduced his normal, authoritarian, dictatorial approach to this matter. Proposed section 111C states that, if the Minister is satisfied that a State or Territory has not made sufficient progress, he can introduce into Parliament proposed legislation which will override any existing State or Territory legislation; in other words, negotiate or else. That is not negotiation; it is coming to an agreement with a loaded gun. I do not know whether States are in Senator Coulter's mind as feral animals that have to be exterminated even under his particular arrangements.
—Probably.

—They probably are. I find this a very unattractive way to conduct business. I just wish that we could hurry on through these amendments instead of discussing every particular item ad nauseam. This is a nauseous amendment so I suppose it should be discussed ad nauseam, but for heaven's sake let us defeat it.

—I agree with Senator Baume in relation to paragraph (a) of proposed section 111C. I also note that paragraph (b) of the same proposed section seeks to give the Minister the power to recommend that the Governor-General make regulations that have the effect of overriding State legislation. Senator Collins is a well known and highly respected former Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I understand that there are some honourable senators who, in the committee stage, are becoming a little restless. I would point out that, unlike many other debates, we are working through this piece of legislation clause by clause and we have significant amendments which we wish to consider.

PARA.TAB: The Bill, as it stands, allows only the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service to seek an injunction from the Federal Court to restrain a person from engaging in an activity which threatens a species or an ecological community. An `interested person', as defined on page 59, is permitted to seek an injunction only against the Minister or the Director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service. Amendments Nos 63 to 69 would allow any interested person, as defined under the Act, to seek an injunction from the Federal Court against any person. They would also have the effect of providing immunity from the payment of damages if the case failed in court.

The essence of the amendments is that interested persons should have the right to properly protect endangered species and, therefore, the right to seek an injunction from the Federal Court if there is a breach. In relation to the immunity from payment of damages, if a person were to lodge a claim in a vexatious or frivolous manner, the court would throw that out and the question of payment of damages would not arise. The damages question would arise only if the injunction brought by the interested person were successful in the courts. If it were successful, the court would be responsible—as it rightly should be—for upholding the provisions of this legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I wish I had your confidence about the likely outcome of my amendment. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.After clause 27, page 13, insert the following clause:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Director to refer status requests to Scientific Subcommittee

PARA.TAB: "27A.(1) A person may request the Director to refer to the Scientific Subcommittee for consideration the status of a species or ecological community.
(2) Where a person makes a request for a referral in accordance with subsection (1), the Director must make the referral to the Scientific Subcommittee.

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the amendment is to allow interested people to seek the removal, as well the addition, of species from the list. At the moment, there is no capacity for any person to make a representation that something be deleted from the list, but special arrangements are made for people to make requests to add to the list. I am concerned about this uneven, unfair and unreasonable approach.

PARA.TAB: I understand that my concern is shared by at least some Cabinet Ministers on the Government side. I am surprised that Mrs Kelly has been allowed to get away with restoring to this legislation the sort of one-eyed, unfair approach that I thought Cabinet had gone to great lengths to remove from the legislation in order to make it a fair, proper and reasonable piece of legislation which most reasonable Australians would be comfortable with because it sought an outcome which is in Australia's best interests. That is why the amendment refers to `consideration of the status of a species'. At the moment the proposition is that a person may nominate an item for inclusion on the list, but may not request that an item be de-listed. That is grossly unfair.

The second thing is that this whole question of nomination is, as I have said earlier, one that has been abused and misused by people who seek to claim status for the phrase `has been nominated'—by saying that something has been nominated for inclusion on various lists such as the heritage list—and therefore there is a pretence that it has some status, and that pretence has been accepted in particular by many elements of the media. That is why I deliberately chose to remove the word `nominate' because it is a word that has an unreasonable implication, and instead to insert the words that `a person may request the Director to refer to the Scientific Subcommittee for consideration the status of a species or ecological community'.

In a sense, while I am disappointed that in the cause of good government the Government will not accept my amendment, which improves the Bill and is right down the path of consensus which this is supposed to represent, I suppose that in a sense some benefit will emerge out of this because it will dramatise to Australians the difference between the Government, with its preparedness to bow to the whims of unreasonable and unfair process, and the coalition, which will look at this in a proper, reasoned way and seek to follow a policy of sustainable development. We have in mind the need for action to be taken to reduce the one million unemployed, to reduce the massive and mounting foreign debt and to reduce the balance of payments crisis.

We have been debating this legislation since 9.30 this morning, yet we are surrounded by economic disaster and the jobless queues growing by the minute. We have been talking about something which I accept is very important indeed; but what concerns me is that this proposed clause that the Government will not accept is one aimed at making certain that we have a fair and balanced outcome. Instead of that, the Government has, for political purposes, bowed to the usual pressure from the, if you like, squeaking hinge.

I urge the Government—or at least I urge those Cabinet Ministers who may have been away, may not have been informed or may be unaware of this for some reason or another—to understand that Mrs Kelly has made some extra ground over what Cabinet had allowed her, its having made her retreat considerably from her initial draft. I am disappointed that those Cabinet Ministers are, apparently, not being given a chance to have any basic input to this legislation and have, I suppose in absentia, been rolled.

The amendment that the Government is now accepting from the Democrats is not in keeping with the spirit of the legislation. It is not fair, it does not give a fair go and, quite frankly, the coalition strongly opposes it. We wanted to provide people with the opportunity to have some input; that is why I moved our amendment. It was wrong of the Government to freeze them out altogether, which was what the draft originally suggested. However, it was equally wrong for Senator Coulter to want to give to the people who want to get things added to the list an unfair, and in my view improper, position in relation to those who want things removed.

This clause in the legislation is appalling. It is being rushed through in order somehow to placate the Australian Democrats. I do not know why this is. Perhaps it is to seek some of their constituency; I am not quite certain of the motives but, whatever they are, they are wrong, the conclusion is disastrous and, though it may please Mrs Kelly in the short run, I must say that it will enable us to dramatise to the Australian people which party is really trying to get a decent result and to get sustainable development where all points of view are properly weighed and balanced in this major debate. The Government, by behaving in this silly way, has to an extent, I suppose, helped our cause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to say that I am really surprised at the outburst which we have just heard, but I am not surprised at all. There is no doubt that the economic plight of this country is extreme. There is also no doubt that the plight of our endangered species is equally extreme.

PARA.TAB: Given those two facts, for Senator Baume to argue that to somehow further impose economic activity upon the environment would turn the economy around is simply a non sequitur. It is illogical that somehow we would provide economic prosperity and jobs for people by screwing the economy a little harder. It is just a stupid argument, and it has no foundation at all.

It could be argued, equally strongly, that it is precisely because we have not looked after the environment that we are bearing very heavy costs from the damage that we have done to it. It could also be argued that that is part of the reason we are now in our economic predicament and that if we looked after our environment better our economy would be in much healthier shape.
I direct Senator Baume's attention specifically to clause 24(3) of the Endangered Species Protection Bill, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: A member of the Scientific Subcommittee has a duty not to disclose to any other person the advice, or any information relating to the advice, before the end of that period of 30 days unless the disclosure: . . .

Clearly, implicit in this legislation are strong responsibilities not to use this information in this interim period in the way about which Senator Baume expressed concern. If he also looks particularly at paragraph 158(1)(a), which sets out the functions of the Scientific Subcommittee, he will see that it reads:
to advise the Minister, within 12 months after the commencement of this Act and thereafter at intervals of not longer than 12 months, of amendments (if any) that should be made to the lists;. . .

Clearly in this legislation one has a process in which the information should be protected should such a nomination be made by a member of the public. The legislation clearly envisages that protection so that it would not be widely misused. Also, a definitive decision must be given within at least 12 months and a decision made as to whether the particular application has been accepted or not—in other words, whether the species or the threatened ecological community will appear on the lists.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume's attack on this amendment is nothing but a very thinly disguised attack on the need to protect endangered species and to move very substantially towards what he sees—misguidedly sees—as the need to protect vested financial interests. There is no evidence that the protection of those interests is, indeed, in the long term interests of either the economy or the environment. I think his proposal should be very roundly condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been listening to garbage from that corner of the chamber since 9.30 this morning. This last little bit has really gone right over the top. To suggest—not to suggest; to assert—as Senator Coulter did, that what I was saying was a thinly veiled attack on the concept of protecting endangered species when I have consistently supported the Endangered Species Protection Bill; when I have, in fact, moved amendments, unsuccessfully, which would make it a fairer and more rational Bill; and when I have continually pointed out that the coalition strongly supports the thrust of the Bill, is nonsense. If that Senator from his biased, one-eyed and in my view—I might say, in view of that last comment—totally dishonourable position can, in any way, establish any fact that would support his offensive suggestion, I would be glad to hear it.

PARA.TAB: He said that I was speaking only in support of vested financial interest. If the only reason anyone opposes Senator Coulter's ratbag propositions is that, according to him, that person is supporting some vested interest, 99 per cent of the members of this Senate have some sort of vested interest. Maybe it is a vested interest in the truth and in getting the best legislation through. Maybe we were having an aberration, but we even agreed to some of his amendments. I wonder what vested interest prompted us to do that.

Not only am I disappointed in what he did; I am disgusted by his last remark. Not only am I disgusted; I am astounded at his incompetence. His defence of his position was incredible. He said, `It's wrong to say that people would use the fact that something had been nominated'—as they have misused it in the Heritage Act; as the media has consistently drummed up matters because something has been nominated. Senator Coulter's response is, `No, that couldn't happen because, according to subclause 24(3), a member of the Scientific Subcommittee has a duty not to disclose to any other person'. What rubbish! What about the person who makes the nomination? There is no requirement on the person making the nomination to keep quiet about it. Senator Coulter should use his brains. He should stop making these stupid remarks which are an insult to our intelligence, apart from being insulting to us personally in terms of our motives.

His behaviour over the 12 hours that we have been dealing with this legislation, with other matters interfering every now and again, has been disgraceful. I have shown remarkable restraint. I have bitten my tongue and not responded to some of the silly things he has been saying all day. I have participated minimally in this debate, despite some incredible and nonsensical sentences in some of his proposed amendments to the legislation, which fortunately the Government will not accept anyway. Having had to put up with him all day, this last statement was too much. I believe he should closely examine in his own heart his motives for making that kind of allegation against me. If he is so obsessive about a matter—as he obviously is about this one; and I do not criticise him for feeling deeply—it would make him a better man if he argued it on the merits of the case. I hope that, on reflection, he will recognise that his behaviour is unacceptable.

I regret the Government's decision to go along with this man, whose motives appear to have been so dominated by an obsessive view that anyone who opposes him is somehow in someone else's pay. I regret that the Government does not have the intestinal fortitude to support an amendment which it knows is right and which gives a fair go to people who want a consideration of items to be removed from the list. There is nothing in this Bill, as it stands, that gives any person the opportunity to request that something be delisted. Sure, it says that the Minister can add or delete an item, having considered advice from the Scientific Subcommittee, but nothing gives anyone the opportunity of making the sort of recommendation to delist that is to be given to people who want to list. It is not even-handed. It is not fair. It does not follow the fine point towards consensus that this Government, properly, has been pursuing, which is one of the reasons we are supporting the Bill.

I have been congratulating the Government on following that course, and I regret to say that my congratulations have to be diminished to half a cheer after this very weak-kneed withdrawal which occurred, largely, I presume, because Mrs Kelly has been able to insist on a matter because the other Cabinet Ministers, who clearly would not support the course of action being taken now, are not available or do not know about it or because there is no prospect of having a Cabinet meeting. What has happened now is ridiculous. I hope the Minister will be able to do something about it. Maybe he could defer consideration of this clause or give some sort of undertaking that it will be looked at again. I would like to know why the Minister will not give Australians the same opportunity to recommend that items be taken off the list as he will give to people who want to put things on the list.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with some fear and trepidation that I now have, regrettably, to add injury to insult and advise Senator Baume that the Government, as he anticipated, will not be supporting his amendment. I do not want to prolong the debate. I think Senator Baume has said it all, but I point out to him that, as I know he realises, at the end of the day the primary advice to the Minister in respect of the situation which we all hope will occur—that is, a species no longer having to be considered endangered—will come from the Scientific Subcommittee.

PARA.TAB: I draw to the attention of the Committee that there is a requirement on the Scientific Subcommittee contained in subclause 158(1) of the Bill to consider, at intervals not longer than 12 months—that is, a minimum of every year—what amendments, if any, should be made to the lists. SPEECH.PARA: Some farmer friends of mine think we should add the eastern grey kangaroo, but I imagine that Senator Coulter would go slightly off his face at that suggestion, no matter how reasonable it may be. The reason we are supporting Senator Coulter's proposal here in the main—about feral cats, feral rabbits and feral goats—is that if we proceed the way the Government had suggested, basically limiting it to foxes in terms of their effect on fauna, we would create an effective disaster. I recognise that there is a limited amount of funds and the Government has to set priorities. I understand that. But if the priority is to start off with foxes, what is going to happen to the rabbits? One of the major factors in keeping rabbit numbers down—or rather a factor in holding back the rabbit population—is the effective anti-rabbit activities of foxes. So if we knock off the foxes we will end up increasing the rabbit population. In other words, it cannot be done item by item. We have to adopt a coherent, rational approach. That is why we would strongly support the Democrat proposition to extend the list. As to vegetation clearance, it would be equally rational to include lantana, blackberry, mimosa and a whole lot of other vegetation problems.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about pigs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening we are debating the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill 1992. The purpose of this Bill is to ensure that all persons working in the offshore petroleum industry in Commonwealth waters are protected by occupational health and safety legislation.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition will not support this Bill because it is neither urgent nor necessary. We have a short time remaining until the end of the sittings, and some 76 Bills, maybe more, have been introduced. This is a so-called urgent Bill. The reasons for our opposition to the Bill are as follows.

In his second reading speech, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) stated that the provisions of the Bill will cease to apply once the relevant States move to extend the coverage of their occupational health and safety legislation. It supposedly covers people working in the industry offshore in Western Australia and Queensland because they are not currently covered by the provisions. However, no-one is working offshore in Queensland, and the Western Australian area is already covered.

One problem that the Opposition has with the Bill is that neither the Minister nor the Department has consulted in any way with the industry; in fact, the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, at very short notice, sent the Bill to the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association for review. The association, which is the only body representing the petroleum industry in this country, responded to the Minister on 10 November but received no reply. It is now 3 December. So there has been no response or consultation.

Having had a preliminary look at the draft, the industry believes that the Bill should not proceed. It points out that the specific areas of difference to the proposed Commonwealth legislation are designated work groups and health and safety representatives' provisional improvement notices. The arrangements proposed for health and safety representatives are inappropriate for multiple union, small work force situations.

The result of the Bill will be multiple work groups, each with their own representative having major powers of investigation and the ability to order work to stop; whereas a single health and safety representative should be appointed by and answerable to a single health and safety committee. It is pointed out by the industry that the Western Australian designated authority and Western Australian operators are working towards the speedy introduction of a more modern occupational health and safety regulatory system. The association therefore believes that there is no need for new legislation to cover the interim period until State legislation is enacted.
This Bill is 45 pages long. It is a waste of resources of not only the Department but also the drafting office, the Parliament and so on because, as the second reading speech states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the provisions of the Bill will cease to apply once the relevant States move to extend the coverage of their occupational health and safety legislation.

As I indicated earlier, it applies only to Western Australia anyway, which is already moving in that direction. There is no application in Queensland. It also notes that the amendments to the offshore directions are not reflected in the main body of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. The safety and management systems required as part of a safety case approach embody a wider range of work force occupational health and safety issues than the proposed amendments in the Bill. This inconsistency of approach is of great concern to member companies of APEA.

PARA.TAB: The safety case incorporates the requirements of the proposed amendment in a generalised form, with the exception of the appointment of health and safety representatives. The benefit of the generalised safety case is that the operator must demonstrate a commitment to the health and safety of employees rather than relying on the prescriptive legislation. The industry recommends that a strategy for transition to goal setting regulations be prepared for input from all parties prior to any further enactment or amendment. The association maintains that this is preferable to the inherent instability of the proposed amendments, which have the potential—and this is something that the Australian Democrats should think about—to cause a decline in safety standards as operators and the employees move through different regulatory regimes over a relatively short period.

Here we have a Bill that is only an interim Bill until the States do something that everyone agrees to. No-one disagrees with increasing occupational health and safety standards within the industry. There is no complaint about that. This 45-page Bill comes in as an interim Bill and there has been no consultation whatsoever with the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—Exactly. It shows the arrogance of this Government. I do not know the answer to this, but one wonders what on earth is the hidden agenda of the Government when it brings in an interim Bill, with no consultation, which applies only to what is happening in Western Australia, where these occupational health and safety standards are already employed. For that reason the Opposition will oppose the Bill.

PARA.TAB: It should be pointed out that personnel joining offshore facilities are routinely advised by the operator of the location and availability of the PSLA directions on the facility and are encouraged to read the documents. The inclusion of the prescriptive amendments, which appear to be an absolute waste of time and which will be inapplicable in many offshore areas, will probably create confusion among employees. In all respects, whichever way one looks at this Bill, not only is it not urgent and not only should it not have come in at this stage, but it also appears to be totally unnecessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could attach complete credibility to all that he gave us, the contribution by Senator Parer would normally lead us to some confusion. The second reading speech on the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Bill 1992 states that the Australian Government has responded comprehensively to the Piper Alpha production platform disaster in the North Sea in 1988, when 167 lives were lost, by setting up a consultative committee on safety in the offshore petroleum industry. That committee consisted of State and Commonwealth government, union and industry representatives. Its responsibility was to assess the findings from the United Kingdom and to advise the Government on future direction of offshore safety in Australia. To me, that translates to mean consultation, and the industry was included there. Yet Senator Parer assures us that there was no consultation.

PARA.TAB: It is a bit hard sitting in this position to decide who is telling the truth on whether or not there was consultation. I can only conclude that somebody thought they were consulting but somebody else thought they were not. It is not for me to decide, and I do not think I should attempt to decide, whether consultation took place or not. What I can decide is on the merits of what is proposed here.

This Bill was the subject of some discussion in the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, of which I am a member. The Bill itself is offered as a model for States to reach that standard. It was not the degree of consultation which was the subject of our concern; rather, the feature which was most carefully examined by the Committee was the one which ensured that an employer must not dismiss employees on the grounds of having drawn attention to the inadequacies in occupational health and safety in the employment area. That to me seems a very important component of the Bill because it safeguards the whistleblower—in common parlance—aspect of employees in these situations. This aspect deserves to be and must be safeguarded because inspection and policing of these requirements is difficult unless the employees themselves are afforded the opportunity to draw attention to any inadequacies on the platforms.

I must accept Senator Parer's assurance that the Western Australian Government is moving towards the very direction which is established in this Bill. I must also accept his assurance that it is irrelevant at the moment in Queensland. However, I would have thought that it would be fairly obvious that the establishment of such legislation is not going to do any harm. If there is nobody operating the offshore platforms in Queensland, it will also not be to anybody's detriment there.

However, the purpose of this Bill is to ensure that State legislation is prepared and will be in place when these offshore platforms are established. Offshore platforms are inherently extremely dangerous situations for people to be employed in. It is also a complicated area in which to get the occupational health and safety provisions exactly right. It is for those reasons that we will be supporting the Bill without further discussion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the remarks made by Senator Parer on the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Bill 1992. Senator Bell just said that it would be pretty handy to have a bit of legislation that would cover somebody who does not need any coverage and something that is not even operating. It seems absolutely ridiculous to me that we are introducing legislation, as Senator Parer said, that everyone is moving towards anyway. Why do we want to have more legislation? We already have 73 pieces of legislation going through this place in the last three weeks and we have before us what I regard as a completely unnecessary piece of legislation.

PARA.TAB: Basically, I suppose it is not surprising; this is just another Bill about which the Government has failed to consult sufficiently with industry. It is another example of legislation being jammed through the Parliament for no real purpose and of exposing the industry to potential expense and unforeseen consequences. The legislation essentially applies occupational health and safety provisions for petroleum workers in two States, Western Australia and Queensland, until such time as those two States apply their own occupational health and safety legislation.

The situation in the petroleum industry at present is that operators have what they regard as effective systems to promote occupational health and safety to employees and contractors. My experience, from visiting oil rigs on the North West Shelf, is that the diligence being applied by the people on those rigs at the moment, with their own occupational health and safety, is of the highest standard. So why is there such a rush to have this legislation basically cover Queensland offshore operators? Only the Government would know, and possibly it does not know either because, as I said earlier, the situation in Queensland at present is that there are no offshore operators and there are not likely to be any in the foreseeable future.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is the Barrier Reef.

—That is right. It is this Government which has stopped the drilling there, anyway. It is trying to cover something that is not even happening. I ask again: what is the rush? Have we not already got enough legislation here to cope with without the Government whipping around to get a few more bits of legislation for us to discuss? Is the Government operating on a secret agenda? Perhaps it is so secret that it does not know what it is all about. Why has the Government not undertaken proper consultative processes with industry? What really irks me about this legislation is that the Government has not discussed it with industry. It has made an attempt, apparently, and a draft review of the Bill was sent to the Petroleum Exploration Association for comment. But, having done that, the Government did not give the Association any time to properly scrutinise it. I suppose it is a bit like saying, `We are going to do something; you may as well have a look at it before it happens'.

PARA.TAB: Not surprisingly, the industry is not supportive of the Bill because of the administrative difficulties likely to arise, because it will confuse industry through its inconsistency, because it duplicates current directions and because the Bill will impose significantly increased penalties. I ask again: why are we having to rush this Bill through at the moment? I support Senator Parer. The Opposition will oppose the Bill for all the reasons that I have stated and those expressed by Senator Parer earlier tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been put, on the face of it, a series of objections to this legislation in the form of questions—questions which are meant to expose, in the Opposition's view, reasons why this legislation should not proceed. In commending this legislation to the Senate, I shall deal briefly with those issues. The list of objections that I have taken down is as follows: why the rush; what is the secret agenda; why was there not proper consultation; and it is not necessary, anyway, in Western Australia and Queensland.
—No, in Queensland—well, and in Western Australia.

—I took the view that your colleague Senator Brownhill was saying that he has visited, like I have, the offshore platforms on the North West Shelf. The level of safety is, as he rightly said, very high. Indeed, I think that Woodside has won several awards both in Australia and internationally for its safety levels. But let me go to the questions. This legislation involves, effectively, two things: the provision of the Commonwealth levels of occupational health and safety for offshore operations in Queensland and Western Australia; and, secondly, the provision for future operators of offshore platforms to present a safety case—that is, to design their own safety arrangements and then, in consultation with the Commonwealth and the States, to get them approved so that the risk management of operating offshore can be properly evaluated and contained.

PARA.TAB: To answer the first question, there is no rush here, but there is essential attention to speed. This springs from the disaster in the North Sea in, as I recall, 1989 when the Piper Alpha platform was engulfed in a fireball. There was a considerable loss of life and a considerable loss of the operational use of that platform and the wells it served. As a consequence of that disaster, the British Government set up an inquiry. Because Australia is sensitive to the highest operational levels of safety offshore, and because there is a vibrant offshore industry in this country, I, as the Minister at the time, set up a monitoring group in the Department to follow the evidence to the Piper Alpha inquiry. This meant that we did not have to wait for the inquiry to receive all of its submissions, come to its conclusions, and publish its report. We were following the proceedings—this information was made available to the Australian industry as well—so that if anything came out of the evidence we could act to ensure that the reputation we enjoyed offshore for the highest level of safety was maintained and, if there were anything we needed to amend or improve when the report came through, we could do so. So we were across the game, up with the pace, and always maintaining that enviable reputation we had.

It is out of that long gestation, now over three years, that this legislation arises. There has not been a rush, but there has been a proper regard for levels of safety, and a prudent responsibility exercised by government. What is the secret agenda? It is the same as the public one: we want to maintain our international reputation for operational safety offshore. Has there been proper consultation? The monitoring of the inquiry, and the information that came from it, was shared with the industry, so industry was aware all along of what was going on, what our responses were, and what our feelings were.

Indeed, it was so aware that, as I recall it, in late 1989-early 1990, Woodside itself stopped pumping on the North West Shelf for a couple of days to make a change to a gasket or a joint under water, based on the information it got out of the inquiry. Therefore, what we were doing indicated the strength of our working with industry following the inquiry. Woodside, at a cost of several million dollars, did that. We have all been cycling along together. There is a committee called the Consultative Committee on Safety in the Offshore Petroleum Industry. It is a committee made up of unions, governments, and the industry. It has been through that committee that we have consulted on this legislation. So the consultations arise out of a long prehistory of monitoring shared information, and it is on the basis of that consultation that this legislation arises.

The final question asked was this: why does the legislation apply to Western Australia, since the Western Australian Government has indicated its intention to legislate, and Queensland where there are no offshore platforms? This legislation applies to offshore platforms and to offshore exploration. In the absence of the Western Australian Government yet legislating, despite its honest intent, one has to make the reasonable observation that there will be an election soon in Western Australia; there will be a period of hiatus in government when that occurs—I think the State Parliament is due to be prorogued soon—and there is no reason therefore why we should not get this Bill through and proclaimed to ensure there is the proper level of provision for safety and occupational health until such time as the Western Australian Government catches up.

In Queensland there are no offshore platforms, but there may be—in the Torres Strait, or in the Gulf of Carpentaria, or away from the areas governed by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority—from time to time permits issued or sought for exploration, and it is prudent and sensible government, since we have to carry this Bill in any case, to cover the situation in Queensland until it catches up.The question was not raised about who will administer the Bill. I think I should announce it: the designated authority in this case will be the State Ministers. So, in that sense, it is under their purview.

I think I have replied reasonably and adequately to the questions that I think have been reasonably and sensibly raised. While I do not imagine that I have necessarily persuaded the Opposition to support the Bill, I think it might approach the passage of this Bill with a greater tolerance than hitherto has been the case. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Question put:
That the Bill be now read a second time.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the point that the Opposition does not intend to address any particular clause in the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Bill. I believe we made our position clear in the second reading debate as to why we are opposed to the Bill as a whole.

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, pointed out that it really applied only to Western Australia. The Bill itself will cease to apply once Western Australia and Queensland, where there are no people involved, move to extend the coverage of their occupational health and safety. He referred to the adoption of the Consultative Committee on Safety in the Off-Shore Petroleum Industry and the adoption of the safety case approach, together with the progressive introduction of objective setting regulations to replace prescriptive requirements where possible.

As the Minister pointed out in his second reading speech, I think the adoption of the safety case approach to offshore safety has already been implemented. I reiterate those points and the reason why we are opposed to the Bill as a whole. I think it would be just a waste of the time of this Committee and this Parliament to go through the clauses in the committee stage.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator Cook) read a third time.
Motion (by Senator Cook) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak for just a few minutes about APEC and the application by Chile to be one of the new members perhaps admitted during 1993. If very diligent, honourable senators may recall that in August last year I brought back a number of observations and recommendations from a visit that Senator Hill and I made to Latin America. This was at a time when the inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade into relations with Latin America was at an early stage. Eventually the Senate Committee, of which I am proud to be Deputy Chairman, brought down a very significant report. In my speech in the Senate in August last year, and again in the Senate Committee's report, there is recommendation that Mexico be admitted as a member of APEC and that in due course Chile also be admitted as a member.

PARA.TAB: There were 12 original members of the Asia-Pacific economic consultation process and Australia played a proud part in the early stages of developing that concept and of ensuring that those 12 members in the Asia-Pacific region came together. In November 1991 three new members were added. We know them colloquially as the three Chinas—China, Taiwan and Hong Kong. The only realistic additional membership that is contemplated now, I believe, is that of Mexico and Chile.

Until this point I had argued that Mexico be admitted first and Chile a couple of years later. I really just want to correct, upgrade or advance the argument that has hitherto been put in the Senate over the last 15 months and to argue that during 1993 Australia give consideration to supporting the dual admission of two new members, Mexico and Chile, together. There are a number of reasons for putting that forward and I want very briefly to mention two or three.

This conclusion and the convincing argument emerged from very fruitful discussions that were held one week ago, last Thursday, in Parliament House during the visit to Canberra of Mr Edgardo Boeninger, the Secretary-General of the President in the Government of the Republic of Chile, the most senior representative of Chile who has so far visited this country. We all look forward to Patricio Aylwin, the President, coming to Australia during 1993.

I warmed immensely to Mr Boeninger. I had heard of his reputation and the regard in which he is held by everyone in government, in the Parliament and amongst the people of Chile, and he lived up to those expectations. I was able to meet with him twice—once in my capacity as Deputy Chairman of the Senate Committee and the other as the Secretary of the Australia-Chile friendship group within this Parliament. In both of the conversations we touched upon the admission of Mexico and Chile to APEC. He put an argument to me, because we were ready to assess the question of timing, and I openly admit that argument convinced me.

The argument was that, to complete the Pacific Rim representation in APEC, we should admit Latin American countries, particularly those that are adjacent to the Pacific coast, and that, to make that as dramatic as the admittance of the three Chinas as new members in 1991, we should admit not just one and then another a little later but the two Latin American countries at the same time. The only argument for putting Mexico ahead of Chile is that Mexico is to be a member of the North American Free Trade Association with the US and Canada, both of which are members of APEC. But, alongside that, we need to recognise that Mexico and Chile already have a bilateral free trade agreement and that it is widely acknowledged that, after Mexico, the US and Canada have ratified the agreement and it is expected in the next six or seven months that the next member even of NAFTA will be Chile.

In addition, we should recognise that Chile has a very extensive Pacific coast, as does Mexico; and that Chile has a sound economy, as does Mexico. The two countries are far in advance of the other nations in the Pacific in terms of growth and debt ratio to GNP, and in terms of having an outward looking economy which is seeking to be internationally competitive. Of course, both countries, especially Chile, have been close allies of ours in the Cairns Group in this Uruguay Round of the GATT.

By admitting both Mexico and Chile together we would see an end, for some years, to the agenda of extending the membership of APEC—the original 12, the three Chinas, then the two Latin American countries during 1993. That would be the end of the matter. I think at this stage it would be only towards the end of the 1990s that we could estimate any new countries successfully seeking admission to APEC.

I know that Russia's far east seeks to be represented in APEC. Some have speculated that other Latin American countries such as Colombia—and perhaps Papua New Guinea, Fiji and others on the Pacific Rim—should also be represented. I believe all of these cases are more remote. It is estimable that these countries will not be admitted until the late 1990s at the earliest and that we should get the two candidates that are far in advance of the field, Mexico and Chile, admitted together.

I conclude by noting the advice, arising from the conversations last Thursday that I have described, that was given by Mr Edmundo Vargas, the Vice-Minister for Foreign Relations in that country, whom I met in Santiago a year and a half ago; my good friend the former Ambassador of Chile to this country over the last three years and now Ambassador-at-Large in Chile's foreign service, Mr Juan Salazar, who was accompanying Mr Boeninger on this visit; and the new Ambassador of Chile to Australia, His Excellency Mr Fernando Zegers, with whom I have happened to meet a few times over the last fortnight.
I note their extraordinary unanimity of response to the conversation that Secretary-General Boeninger and I were able to have a week ago. I made the suggestion that they, as

SPEECH.PARA: a group of four very senior Ministers and officials of the Chile Government, put this argument in their own terms.

PARA.TAB: I also suggested that the group, through Ambassador Fernando Zegers, should give that argument in writing to the Australian Government, that is, to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, and to the shadow Minister for foreign affairs, my colleague Senator Robert Hill, so that their argument, in their own terms, is very much on the table.

Therefore, I urge the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade to receive that letter favourably and to give it very careful consideration. I note for the Senate, and for the Australian Government, that I wish my personal view to be recorded as supporting the dual admission of Mexico and Chile together into APEC next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the Senate adjourns, I remind honourable senators that Estimates Committee B will meet tomorrow at 8.15 a.m. in committee room 2S1. The proceedings will be broadcast on television channel 21 and on radio FM band 90.3.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
